of&nbsp;resources you will find useful in this subject.&nbsp;</p><p>Firstly, there are the collection of readings that have been chosen by each of the instructors in this subject to help support your discussions and assignment work. These will be made available to you electronically.</p><p>Secondly, there are the resources available to you in the many and varied texts on climate change in the public domain (social media, news sources, periodicals, literature, film, works of art, etc.). Although these should be examined critically before being incorporated into the arguments you make, they do give you access to information about&nbsp;current and&nbsp;rapidly changing events.</p><p>Finally, there are your own experiences and interests. He has done extensive field-work in the South Pacific, China\nand East Timor.&nbsp;Jon is convenor of the Australian national research\nnetwork on the social, economic and institutional dimensions of climate change,\nwhich is part of the <i>National Climate Change Adaptation Research Facility</i> and\nis a Lead Author for the forthcoming Fifth Assessment Report of the\n<i>Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change</i> (IPCC). He is Executive Editor of the\nadaptation domain of Wiley <i>Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change</i>.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/44/b6b45ca3e5eb2a6f234feb53ffac50/John-Freebairn-2.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\">Prof John Freebairn holds the Ritchie chair\nin economics at the University of Melbourne. He is an applied microeconomist\nand economic policy analyst with current interests in taxation reform and\nenvironmental economics. John has a distinguished academic career, serving as a\nprofessor of economics in faculties of economics at a number of universities,\nincluding the Australian National University, LaTrobe and Monash universities.\nHe has held the positions of Head of Department and Dean at Monash University\nand the University of Melbourne, respectively. John has also served as a senior\neconomist with the New South Wales <i>Department of Agriculture</i>, Deputy Director\nof the <i>Centre of Policy Studies</i>, Research Director at the <i>Business Council of\nAustralia</i> and Director of the <i>Melbourne Institute</i>.</p>\n\n<p><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/bb/968c4074125c40f3a286db753473f1/Jamieson_Photo.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\">Prof David Jamieson is Head of the School of\nPhysics at the University of Melbourne. He is also&nbsp;a member&nbsp;of the\n<i>Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence for Quantum Computer\nTechnology</i>. This Centre is working on new ways of storing and processing\ninformation using the laws of quantum mechanics. He completed his PhD in Physics at the University of Melbourne and then spent 4 years as a postdoctoral\nresearch fellow at Caltech (USA) and the University of Oxford (UK). He has\npublished over 200 papers in scientific journals, 1 book and the occasional\nopinion piece in the media on energy and the environment.&nbsp;He advocates that the laws of Physics are essential to understanding the causes and potential remedies for climate change.</p><p><br></p>\n\n<p><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/42/79682ebfee138c1ab2d509b80683d2/Toscano-Pic.jpeg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\">Dr Maurizio Toscano is a Lecturer in the Melbourne Graduate School of Education&nbsp;&nbsp;with an interest in interdisciplinary approaches to\nunderstanding and communicating climate change. Maurizio\u2019s approach to climate change is informed by the breadth of his academic experiences: his doctoral\ntraining was in astrophysics; he has undertaken and supervised research into\nthe role of aesthetics and the scientific imagination in science education; he\nhas explored the relationship between art and science through collaborations\nwith artists (eg the Syzygy project) and more recently has been examining\nperspectives on environmental and science education that draw upon the works of philosophers such as&nbsp;Wittgenstein, Heidegger and Cavell.</p><p><br></p>\n\n<p><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/e3/05872313965fbb1b32ef726bbf000e/RW.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\">Prof Rachel Webster is an astrophysicist with an active interest in climate change and in particular the development of large-scale renewable energy projects. She has led a study to investigate the potential of geothermal energy in Victoria, Australia. {"about_the_course": "Have you ever wondered if Superman could really fly? What was \nSpiderman's spidey sense? How did Wonder Woman's invisible jet work? \nWhat does it really mean for something to be a scientific \"fact\"? \nExplore how science works and what constitutes \"good\" science through \ncase studies drawn from a wide spectrum of people's experience, for \nexample superheros, movies, and real world issues such as global \nwarming. Analyze an argument explaining a particular natural phenomenon and determine if it is based on modern science or Aristotelian views. Explain the limits of modern science techniques.<br><br><i>Week Two</i>: Numbers and Equations. Determine the accuracy and precision of a measurement. Analyze a numerically based argument in a news article. Interpret a graph.<br><br><i>Week Three</i>:&nbsp; Science Methodology. Execute a quantitative experiment. Propose an explanation of the results of the experiment. Propose further tests of the explanation.<br><br><i>Week Four</i>: Scientific Community. Determine if a particular method of analysis is scientific or not. Discuss the sociology of the practice of science. <br><br><i>Week Five</i>: Classical Mechanics. Describe the motion of an object in terms of its position, velocity, and acceleration.Analyze a physical situation to determine when there is a net force on \nan object from either a description of its motion or the interactions it\n has with other objects. Identify \u201ccorrect\u201d and \u201cincorrect\u201d physical motions and interactions in video clips.<br><br><i>Week Six</i>: Superhero Week! Design your own superhero,Justify the origin and powers of a self-designed superhero. Rate the origin and powers of the other superheroes.<br><br><i>Week Seven</i>: More Science. Explain the range of applicability of a scientific theory. Explain the difference between disproving a theory and expanding a theory.<br><br><i>Week Eight</i>: Science Fiction or Science Fact? Identify fundamental versus technological limits. Use your understanding of these limits to evaluate the likelihood of various technologies.<br><br><i>Week Nine</i>: Science and Society. Explain the arguments presented in the case studies in Chapter 6. Provide your own analysis of at least one of the case studies.<br><br><i>Week Ten</i>: Evaluate whether or not Intelligent Design is a scientific theory. Evaluate the issue of global warming using the criteria developed in this class.<br>", "description": "", "short_name": "scientificthinking", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<b>Will I get a certificate after completing this class?</b><br><br>Yes. {"about_the_course": "<p>\n\t\n\t\n\t\n\n\n</p><p>We make economics\ndecisions every day: what to buy, whether to work or play, what to\nstudy. We respond to markets all the time: prices influence our\ndecisions, markets signal where to put effort, they direct firms to\nproduce certain goods over others. Economics is all around us.&nbsp;</p><p>This\ncourse is a rigorous introduction to the microeconomic theory of\nmarkets: why we have them, how they work, what they accomplish. We\nwill explore what outcomes they generate when they work well\nand what happens when they do not. We will learn why governments are\nimportant and when regulation and intervention is necessary. Examples\nare taken from everyday life, from goods and services that we all\npurchase and use. We will apply the theory to current events and\npolicy debates through weekly exercises. These will empower you to be\nan educated, critical thinker who can understand, analyze and\nevaluate market outcomes. \n</p>\n<p><br>\n</p><p></p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/cc/d29c75169172a7c1b1cdb15bb47b4c/DS_tax.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/25/a4d4bafdf99a50b9b0912510f47d42/DS_tax.png", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/27/9b9866d34641e63662e14bb00abdc8/DS_tax.png", "video": "pz3SyOk6ZgM", "university-ids": ["penn"], "id": 277, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "@pennopencourses", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f3/2ca37fd0d5d009a94e0ba7f284c860/favicon-penn.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 6, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7c/5d03cbe2cb87974be7f83cc1080af8/logo-penn-front.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "City, State, Country", "primary_color": "#0000ff", "abbr_name": "Penn", "website": "http://provost.upenn.edu/initiatives/openlearning", "description": "The University of Pennsylvania (commonly referred to as Penn or UPenn) is a private university, located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. A member of the Ivy League, Penn is the fourth-oldest institution of higher education in the United States, and considers itself to be the first university in the United States with both undergraduate and graduate studies. ", "short_name": "penn", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/2b/573b5eebd7c7d4d249c24f4b20aaaa/quad2.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/aa/e426c7bed595843b5b5f60e85425c9/quad2.jpg", "name": "University of Pennsylvania", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/5e/4003d6fe94ae4089d5daf13129a515/penn-logo.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f1/6cc70ed0c3cedf36b8ee0a737a1512/penn-logo.png", "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p><b>Week One</b>: Where do\nmarkets come from? We will start with understanding the constraints\nthat we face and then discuss how gains from specialization and trade\nallow us to use our resources efficiently.</p><p><b>Week Two</b>: The\nbasic model of Supply &amp; Demand. This is a week full of\nterminology that will allow you to communicate with other economists\nand finally understand those business pages and market updates.\nIntroduction of the concept of elasticity to discuss effects of price\nand income changes on market outcomes.</p>\n<p><b>Week Three</b>: The\ngreat accomplishment of markets: maximizing the size of the pie. What\nhappens when government intervenes in the market? We will analyze\nprice floors and ceilings, taxes and subsidies.</p>\n<p><b>Week Four</b>:\nIntroduction to firms\u2019 decisions: understanding firms\u2019 cost\ncurves and the goal of profit maximization.</p>\n<p><b>Week Five</b>: The\nPerfectly Competitive Market: what is it? does it exist? why is it a\ncrucial benchmark? \n</p>\n<p><b>Week Six and Seven</b>:\nMonopolies of various types: one price monopoly, natural monopoly,\nprice discrimination and monopolistic competition. What market\noutcomes do we get in each case? How should government intervene in\nsuch cases?</p>\n<p><b>Week Eight</b>: When\nmarkets fail: externalities and public good.</p>\n<p><b>Week Nine</b>: Poverty\nand inequality: how do we measure these? How do we balance our\nconcern about poverty and inequality while allowing markets to work\nfor the benefit of society at large? &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "steinmicro", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<li><strong>Will I get a Statement of Accomplishment after completing this class?</strong>\n<p>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a Statement of Accomplishment signed by the instructor.</p>\n</li><br>", "category-ids": ["economics"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "Learn how markets work, what they accomplish well and what their limitations are.", "course_format": "<p>The class will consist of lecture\nvideos which are between 8 and 15 minutes long. Each video will\ninclude integrated questions&nbsp;to help&nbsp;you assess your\ncomprehension. There are weekly assignments. Each assignment includes\n10 multiple choice/ fill-in the blank questions as well as a short\nanswer component that will be peer graded. There is a final exam.</p>\n<p><br>\n</p>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": null, "suggested_readings": "<p>There are many wonderful introductory\ntexts to Microeconomics that you could use to supplement the Coursera\nmaterial. At the University of Pennsylvania I have been using Michael\nParkin\u2019s \u201c Principles of Microeconomics\u201d as I find it\nespecially rigorous and accurate. You are welcome to use any basic\ntext or none at all.</p>\n<p>I do recommend reading economic\nnewspapers and popular books on the topic. My favorite is The\nEconomist, especially the Business and the Finance and Economics\nsections. In particular she studied risk selection in\nthe health insurance market, the connection between health insurance\nand the provision of care and the link between hospitals and quality\nof healthcare. Recent developments in the health care industry have\nencouraged her to look at Hospitalist (hospital based physicians) in\norder to understand the growth of this specialty, the scope of their\nwork and any implication of this change to quality of care provided\nin the hospital.</p>\n<p>Dr. Stein was introduced\nto economics many years ago while studying to be a hotel manager. She\nwas enthralled with the discipline that explains so much of life with\nthese clear logical tools and decided to change her study path to\nfollow her passion. {"about_the_course": "The past decade has seen an explosion of new mechanisms for understanding and using location information in widely-accessible technologies. This Geospatial Revolution has resulted in the development of consumer GPS tools, interactive web maps, and location-aware mobile devices. These radical advances are making it possible for people from all walks of life to use, collect, and understand spatial information like never before.<br>&nbsp;<br>This course brings together core concepts in cartography, geographic information systems, and spatial thinking with real-world examples to provide the fundamentals necessary to engage with Geography beyond the surface-level. We will explore what makes spatial information special, how spatial data is created, how spatial analysis is conducted, and how to design maps so that they\u2019re effective at telling the stories we wish to share. To gain experience using this knowledge, we will work with the latest mapping and analysis software to explore geographic problems.&nbsp;", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/67/675cb1af3e868d0b5463bdf5c694e4/MapsGR_Logo.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/8e/07b7e6bc9d0b1e178eebcf939c1172/MapsGR_Logo.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/5d/d09bd4de6f923c96083e1fe8d91075/MapsGR_Logo.jpg", "video": "9lCwGxEt28w", "university-ids": ["psu"], "id": 418, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "penn_state", "favicon": "", "website_facebook": "pennstate", "id": 51, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "College", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 40.7961111, "location": "University Park, State College, PA, United States", "primary_color": "", "abbr_name": "Penn State", "website": "http://psu.edu/", "description": "", "short_name": "psu", "location_state": "PA", "website_youtube": "pennstate", "banner": "", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/10/3520cc661622b8782d041ab41d1c10/pennstatebanner1.jpg", "name": "Pennsylvania State University", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/bb/5383e352eec991395cf06360b3c901/psumark-square.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/8f/5ee0d53c3310feb105ac12ca1b8b5f/psumark-square.jpg", "display": true, "location_lng": -77.8627778, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/b9/a32161cac89f618e5e39039b4fd573/blueblackmark.png", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<b><i>Week One:</i></b>&nbsp;The Geospatial Revolution; {"about_the_course": "All computing systems, from mobile to supercomputers, are becoming heterogeneous parallel&nbsp;computers using both multi-core CPUs and many-thread GPUs for higher power efficiency and&nbsp;computation throughput. While the computing community is racing to build tools and libraries to&nbsp;ease the use of these heterogeneous parallel computing systems, effective and confident use&nbsp;of these systems will always require knowledge about the low-level programming interfaces&nbsp;in these systems. This course is designed for students in all disciplines to learn the essence&nbsp;of these programming interfaces (CUDA/OpenCL, OpenMP, and MPI) and how they should&nbsp;orchestrate the use of these interfaces to achieve application goals. <br><br>The course is unique in that it is application oriented and only introduces the necessary&nbsp;underlying computer science and computer engineering knowledge needed for understanding.&nbsp;It covers data parallel execution model, memory models for locality, parallel algorithm patterns,&nbsp;overlapping computation with communication, and scalable programming using joint MPI-CUDA&nbsp;in large scale computing clusters. It has been offered as a one-week intensive summer school&nbsp;for the past four years. "<ul>\n<li><strong>Week One:</strong> Introduction to Heterogeneous Computing and a Quick Overview of CUDA C and&nbsp;MPI, with lab setup and programming assignment of vector addition in CUDA C</li>\n<li><strong>Week Two:</strong> Kernel-Based Data Parallel Programming and Memory Model for Locality, with&nbsp;programming assignment of simple and tiled matrix multiplication.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Three:</strong> Performance Considerations and Task Parallelism Model, with programming&nbsp;assignment in performance tuning.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Four:</strong> Parallel Algorithm Patterns \u2013 Reduction/Scan, stencil computation and Sparse&nbsp;computation, with programming assignment of reduction tree.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Five:</strong> MPI in a Heterogeneous Computing Cluster: domain partitioning, data distribution,&nbsp;data exchange, and using heterogeneous computing nodes, with programming assignment of a&nbsp;MPI-CUDA application.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Six:</strong> Related Programming Models \u2013 OpenACC, CUDA FORTRAN, C++AMP, Thrust,&nbsp;and important trends in heterogeneous parallel computing, with final Hwu is a Professor and holds the Sanders-AMD Endowed Chair in the&nbsp;Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. His research interests are in the area of architecture, implementation,&nbsp;compilation, and algorithms for parallel computing. He is the chief scientist of Parallel&nbsp;Computing Institute and director of the IMPACT research group (<a href=\"http://impact.crhc.illinois.edu\" target=\"_blank\">impact.crhc.illinois.edu</a>). He is a co-founder and CTO of MulticoreWare. For his contributions in&nbsp;research and teaching, he received the ACM SigArch Maurice Wilkes Award, the ACM&nbsp;Grace Murray Hopper Award, the Eta Kappa Nu Holmes MacDonald Outstanding Teaching&nbsp;Award, the CAM/IEEE ISCA Influential Paper Award, and the Distinguished Alumni&nbsp;Award in Computer Science of the University of California, Berkeley. He is a fellow&nbsp;of IEEE and ACM. He directs the UIUC CUDA Center of Excellence and serves as&nbsp;one of the principal investigators of the $208M NSF Blue Waters Petascale computer&nbsp;project. Dr. Hwu received his Ph.D. degree in Computer Science from the University of&nbsp;California, Berkeley.</div>\n<div><br>\n<div>In 2007, Hwu teamed up with then NVIDIA Chief Scientist David Kirk to create a course&nbsp;called Programming Massively Parallel Processors (<a href=\"https://ece408.hwu.crhc.illinois.edu\" target=\"_blank\">https://ece408.hwu.crhc.illinois.edu</a>).&nbsp;Thousands of students worldwide follow the course through the web site each semester.&nbsp;The course material has also been used by numerous universities including MIT, Stanford,&nbsp;and Georgia Tech. Hwu and Kirk have also been teaching a VSCSE Summer School&nbsp;version to science and engineering graduate students from all over the world. In 2008,&nbsp;50 graduates from 17 countries and three continents attended the summer school (<a href=\"http://www.greatlakesconsortium.org/events/GPUMulticore/\">http://www.greatlakesconsortium.org/events/GPUMulticore/</a>) in Urbana with another 60 participating&nbsp;remotely. Students in the summer school come from diverse disciplines. In 2009, the summer&nbsp;school was again fully subscribed with 160 students from multiple continents. The 2010 offering&nbsp;was attended by 220 students at four sites linked with HD video. The 2011 attendance further&nbsp;increased to 280 at 10 sites across the U.S. The 2012 summer school is projected to have more&nbsp;than 320 students at 10 linked sites. Due to popular demand, Hwu and Kirk have also been&nbsp;teaching abbreviated versions of their course globally, most recently at the Chinese Academy&nbsp;of Science in 2008, Berkeley in 2010, Braga Portugal in 2010, and Chile in 2011. They have&nbsp;also collaborated with UPC/Barcelona Supercomputing Center to offer an EU PUMPS summer&nbsp;school in Barcelona every year since 2010. In February 2010, Hwu and Kirk published a&nbsp;textbook on programming massively parallel processors. The book has been extremely popular,&nbsp;with more than 10,000 copies sold to date. International editions and translations are available&nbsp;in China, India, Japan, Russia, Spain, Portugal and Latin America. The second edition is&nbsp;already in production.<br>\n<div></div>\n</div>\n<div></div>\n</div>", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/hetero/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [384, 970755], "display": true, "recommended_background": "Programming experience in C/C++."}

{"about_the_course": "Computer technology has transformed how we participate in democracy. The way we cast our votes, the way our votes are counted, and the way we choose who will lead are increasingly controlled by invisible computer software. Most U.S. states have adopted electronic voting, and countries around the world are starting to collect votes over the Internet. However, computerized voting raises startling security risks that are only beginning to be understood outside the research lab, from voting machine viruses that can silently change votes to the possibility that hackers in foreign countries could steal an election. This course will provide the technical background and public policy foundation that 21st century citizens need to understand the electronic voting debate. You'll learn how electronic voting and Internet voting technologies work, why they're being introduced, and what problems they aim to solve. You'll also learn about the computer- and Internet-security risks these systems face and the serious vulnerabilities that recent research has demonstrated. We'll cover widely used safeguards, checks, and balances &mdash; and why they are often inadequate. Finally, we'll see how computer technology has the potential to improve election security, if it's applied intelligently. Along the way, you'll hear stories from the lab and from the trenches on a journey that leads from Mumbai jail cells to the halls of Washington, D.C. You'll come away from this course understanding why you can be confident your own vote will count &mdash; or why you should reasonably be skeptical.", "other_description": null, "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/digitaldemocracy/large-icon.png", "preview_link": "", "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/digitaldemocracy/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/digitaldemocracy/large-icon.png", "video": "eXSF798qnCA", "university-ids": ["umich"], "id": 39, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, Alex Halderman</a>is an assistant professor of computer science and engineering at the University of Michigan. His research spans computer security and tech-centric public policy, including topics such as software security, data privacy, electronic voting, censorship resistance, and cybercrime, as well as technological aspects of intellectual property law and government regulation. He holds a Ph.D. from Princeton University. <br />A noted expert on electronic voting security, Prof. Halderman helped demonstrate the <a href=\"http://citpsite.s3-website-us-east-1.amazonaws.com/oldsite-htdocs/voting/\">first voting machine virus</a>, participated in California's <a href=\"http://www.sos.ca.gov/voting-systems/oversight/top-to-bottom-review.htm\">\"top-to-bottom\" electronic voting review</a>, and exposed election security flaws in India, the <a href=\"http://indiaevm.org/\">world's largest democracy</a>. {"about_the_course": "Healthcare Innovation and Entrepreneurship applies a focused approach toward sustainable healthcare innovation. Students will be introduced to definitions and concepts that include the innovation process, design thinking, \u201cintrapreneurship,\u201d entrepreneurship, six sigma principles of process improvement, regulatory issues, patent law, and the market forces that impact the healthcare innovation process. All students will gain confidence in the basic elements of the initial discovery phase in the healthcare innovation process, including\n<ol>\n<li>Defining and describing key components of the healthcare innovation process.</li>\n<li>Becoming aware of challenges to the quality of healthcare delivery and the opportunity for improved patient care and cost reductions.</li>\n<li>Learning and practicing a step-by-step \u201cneeds finding\u201d process and a \u201cneeds filtering\u201d process for identifying and prioritizing real clinical problems and opportunities for innovation.</li>\n<li>Developing cross-disciplinary collaboration skills.</li>\n<li>Strengthening communication and leadership skills in advocating health systems change.</li>\n</ol>", Prior to joining the Duke University School of Nursing, Lombardi served as Director of the Renaissance Computing Institute (RENCI) Engagement Center at Duke, a supercomputing center and research incubator for deploying advanced technologies to enable research discoveries and practical innovations. &nbsp;She has received funding support from the National Science Foundation and the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation to further her own research in human-computer interaction and the strategic use of emerging technologies for learning, collaboration and simulation.</div>", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/healthcareinnovation/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [218], "display": true, "recommended_background": "Students should have an appreciation for healthcare and its challenges, but otherwise there are no prerequisites for the course."}
{"about_the_course": "In this class, we will be studying, quite literally, everything in the universe. &nbsp;We will start with \"classical\" astronomy, describing the night sky and organizing what we see as was done in ancient times. &nbsp;We will then embark on a journey, starting here on Earth and progressing outward, to study the Solar system, the Milky Way galaxy, and the wonderful and strange objects we observe in deep space, such as black holes, quasars, and supernovae. &nbsp;We will end with some discussion of what scientists know today about the universe as a whole. &nbsp;Along the way we will introduce some of the methods, theoretical and experimental, that have been used to understand all of this, from Newton's laws, through our understanding of light and matter, to Einstein's theory of relativity, and from Galileo's telescope to WMAP.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/introastro/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "course_syllabus": "<u>Week 1: Positional Astronomy (naked-eye Astronomy)</u><br>We will spend our first week familiarizing ourselves with descriptions of the positions and motions of celestial objects.<br><br><u>Week 2: Newton\u2019s Universe</u><br>Newtonian physics revolutionized the way we understand our Universe. &nbsp;We will discuss Newton\u2019s laws of mechanics, the conservation laws that follow from them, his theory of gravity and some applications to Astronomy, as well as some properties of radiation. &nbsp;The last clip will be a quick look at the features of quantum mechanics relevant to our course. &nbsp;This will be a particularly busy and challenging week, but hard work here will pay off later.<br><br><u>Week 3: Planets</u><br>We will not have time in this course to do any justice to the broad and exciting field of planetary science. &nbsp;We will spend the week on a general review of the properties and structure of our Solar System and our understanding of its origins and history. &nbsp;&nbsp;We will end with some discussion of the exciting discoveries over the past decade of many hundreds of extrasolar planets.<br><br><u>Week 4: Stars</u><br>What we know about stars and a bit about how we found out. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We will begin with a quick review of the best-studied star of all, our Sun. &nbsp;We will then talk about classifications; H-R diagrams and main sequence stars; distance, mass, and size measurements; binaries; clusters; and stellar evolution through the main sequence<br><br><u>Week 5: Post-Main-Sequence Stars<br></u>Final stages of stellar evolution and stellar remnants. &nbsp;&nbsp;Giants, white dwarves, novae, variable stars, supernovae, neutron stars and pulsars.<br><br><u>Week 6: Relativity and Black Holes</u><br>We will spend most of this week acquiring an understanding of the special theory of relativity. &nbsp;We will then discuss the general theory in a qualitative way, and discuss its application to black holes, gravitational lensing, and other phenomena of interest.<br><br><u>Week 7: Galaxies</u><br>Galactic structure and classification. &nbsp;Active galactic nuclei, quasars and blazars. &nbsp;Galactic rotation curves and dark matter. &nbsp;Galaxy clusters and large-scale structure.<br><br><u>Week 8: Cosmology</u><br>What we can say about the universe as a whole. &nbsp;Hubble Expansion. &nbsp;Big bang cosmology. The cosmic microwave background. &nbsp;Recent determination of cosmological parameters. &nbsp;&nbsp;Early universe physics.", "description": "", "short_name": "introastro", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Will I get a&nbsp;<strong>Statement of Accomplishment</strong>&nbsp;after completing this course?</strong>\n<p>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a&nbsp;Statement of Accomplishment&nbsp;signed by the instructor.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Do I need to have had college physics or calculus to take this course?</strong>\n<p>No. If you have had any of these, you will find them helpful but it is definitely possible to do this class and enjoy it without them. Supplementary notes reviewing the technical aspects of the physical principles we use will be posted to help keep the class as self-contained as possible.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Is this a hard course?</strong>\n<p>It should be. If done right you will have learned in a few short weeks a lot of truly exciting science, and this will require putting in some time to work on it, and some hard thinking. It should also be a lot of fun.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Do I need a telescope to take this course?</strong>\n<p>No. I will suggest some observing projects for naked-eye observing and some for telescope observing. If you can find a darkish place to look up at the night sky this will be both rewarding and instructive, and a telescope can amplify both effects if you know how to use it. But not all of us have access to such locations or equipment, and installing one of the planetarium software options allows you to make \u201cobservations\" on your monitor.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>", "category-ids": ["physics"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "An introduction to astronomy through a broad survey of what we know about the universe and how we know it.", "course_format": "There will be video lectures broken up into clips 8-15min. long, about three hours of video per week. There will be quizzes to go with these as well as regular homework assignments.", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": "https://www.coursera.org/course/introastro", "suggested_readings": "There are a lot of important and interesting facts to learn about astronomy, and lectures are a very inefficient way to learn facts. &nbsp;It would be extremely helpful, but not absolutely necessary, to read any of the many introductory astronomy texts that are out there as you take this class and to have it handy as a reference. The Wikibook <a href=\"http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/General_Astronomy\">http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/General_Astronomy</a> and Wikipedia entries for the topics mentioned in class would be quite sufficient for this purpose, as would the freely available online notes by Nick Strobel at <a href=\"http://www.astronomynotes.com/\">http://www.astronomynotes.com/</a>. {"about_the_course": "Learn mathematical, programming and statistical tools used in the real world analysis and modeling of financial data. Apply these tools to model asset returns, measure risk, and construct optimized portfolios using the open source R programming language and Microsoft Excel. &nbsp;Learn how to build probability models {"about_the_course": "<p></p><p>In the revival of mysticism today, mysticism has\nbecome more psychological while psychology is increasingly interested in\nmysticism. This course will provide an entry into the complex world of modern\nmysticism, through studying its psychological thought. We shall begin with\nexploring the interpretations of mystical experience offered by psychoanalysts\nin the twentieth century, starting with Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung and ending\nwith contemporary thinkers such as James Hillman. However, we will see that the\nEuropean mystical traditions, including Kabbalah in the Jewish world and those\nof the Catholic and Protestant worlds, developed their own elaborate systems of\npsychological thought. Thus, we will mostly examine mystical psychology on its\nown terms. We shall especially look at two terms that are very much in use also\nin general culture: the heart (as an emotional rather than as a physical center!...)\nand the soul, looking at the unique mystical concepts of their nature and destiny\nand asking if there were influences and meetings between the different\nreligions.&nbsp;</p><p></p>", "other_description": "", "photo": {"about_the_course": "<p>The American health care system has many problems. 50 million people are uninsured. Quality is extremely uneven, with peaks of greatness at leading academic centers but overall poor quality in both process measures and outcomes such as asthma deaths. Finally, the U.S. health care system spends over $8000 per patient per year, nearly double the next highest country. In March 2010, the Affordable Care Act was enacted. Over the next decade or more, the Act will dramatically re-structure the American health care system.</p>\n<p>This course will explore the history and structure of the current American health care system, including the history of and problems with employment-based health insurance, the challenges surrounding access, cost and quality, and the medical malpractice conundrum. The course will then explore the history of health care reform and the challenges that were overcome to achieve health reform in America. Finally, we will delineate the specific ways that the Affordable Care Act improves access and quality, and will control costs. Throughout lessons regarding health economics, health policy, and medical practice will be elucidated.</p>\n<p>This class is open to anyone that is interested in gaining a better understanding of the US health care system and the challenges of health care reform. There are no prerequisites or required knowledge of the health system.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/healthpolicy/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/healthpolicy/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/healthpolicy/large-icon.png", "video": "I9HDz30z6Kk", "university-ids": ["penn"], "id": 33, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "@pennopencourses", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f3/2ca37fd0d5d009a94e0ba7f284c860/favicon-penn.ico", "website_facebook": "", "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7c/5d03cbe2cb87974be7f83cc1080af8/logo-penn-front.png", "background_color": "", "id": 6, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "City, State, Country", "primary_color": "#0000ff", "abbr_name": "Penn", "website": "http://provost.upenn.edu/initiatives/openlearning", "description": "The University of Pennsylvania (commonly referred to as Penn or UPenn) is a private university, located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. A member of the Ivy League, Penn is the fourth-oldest institution of higher education in the United States, and considers itself to be the first university in the United States with both undergraduate and graduate studies. ", "short_name": "penn", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/aa/e426c7bed595843b5b5f60e85425c9/quad2.jpg", "mailing_list_id": null, "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/2b/573b5eebd7c7d4d249c24f4b20aaaa/quad2.jpg", "location_state": "", "name": "University of Pennsylvania", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/5e/4003d6fe94ae4089d5daf13129a515/penn-logo.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f1/6cc70ed0c3cedf36b8ee0a737a1512/penn-logo.png", "square_logo_svg": "", "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "display": true}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<b>Week 1 \u2013 Growth in US Health Care</b><br>Much of the impetus for health care reform is provided by\nthe need to \u201cbend the cost curve.\u201d &nbsp;Over\nthe past few decades, health care cost growth has consistently outpaced overall\neconomic growth, taking up an increasing share of our Gross Domestic Product (GDP)\nand government budgets. &nbsp;We will discuss\nthe factors that drive cost growth.<br><p> <i><b>Live Q &amp; A with\nDr. Emanuel</b></i><br>Dr. Emanuel will host a live online Q &amp; A session on\ntopics related to health care and current events. </p><p><b>Week 2 \u2013 Structure of the US Health Care</b><br>How do Americans get their health care? Who pays\nfor it? How did the system we have today come to be? &nbsp;These are some of the questions we will answer\nthis week when we look at the structure of the US health care system</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><b>Week 3 \u2013 Access to and Quality of Health Care in the US</b><br>Most Americans receive insurance through their employer or\nthe government (e.g. Medicaid, Medicare, CHIP).&nbsp;\nBefore the ACA, approximately 50 million Americans did not have health\ninsurance. This week we explore access to health care insurance, the profile of\nthe average uninsured person, disparities in quality and outcomes, and the link\nbetween insurance and access to health care.</p>\n\n\n\n<p><b>Week 4 \u2013 Health Care Malpractice</b><b></b><br>In some physician specialties, as many as one in four\npractitioners a year have a medical malpractice claim filed against them,\nmaking this a matter of frequent public and policy debate. We will discuss medical\nerrors, the workings of the malpractice system, liability insurance, and the\ncontribution of negligence and malpractice costs to the health system\u2019s overall\nbottom line.&nbsp; </p>\n\n<p><b>Week 5 \u2013 History of health care reform; The ACA: An Overview </b><br>Health care reform in America has been 100 years in the\nmaking, starting with Theodore Roosevelt and continuing through the Clinton\nadministration. We discuss past attempts at health care reform and why they met\nwith resistance. We then move on to an overview of the 2010 Affordable Care\nAct.</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><b>Week 6 - The ACA: Access to Health Care</b><br>The overview of the ACA continues with a discussion of the provisions\ndesigned to expand access to health care.&nbsp;\nWe will cover employer-sponsored health insurance provisions. This session will feature a guest\nlecture by J. Sanford Schwartz, M.D.</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><b>Week 7 \u2013 The ACA: Cost Control</b><br>This week we will discuss projections of health care cost\ngrowth under the ACA, followed by mechanisms through which the ACA aims to\ntackle health care cost growth. <br></p>\n\n<p><b>Week 8 \u2013 The ACA: Health Care Delivery and Quality</b><br>The final topic of\nthe course is the ACA\u2019s impact on the quality and delivery of care. The ACA includes\nprovisions for institutional innovations, i.e. changes in how the system\ndelivers care. &nbsp;It also contains rules\nand incentives for providers to cut down on mistakes and deliver proven,\nvaluable care. This week will provide a forward-looking overview of what we\nwill change in the medical sector.<br></p><br>", "description": "", "short_name": "healthpolicy", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<b><u>Course</u></b><br><br><ul><li><b><i>Will this content be available after the course is over?</i></b> <br>Yes, we intend to maintain this information online.</li><li><b><i>Will I receive college credit for this course?<br></i></b>Coursera and the University of Pennsylvania do not provide\ncollege credit for this course, however, students who satisfactorily complete\nthe course requirements will receive a certificate of completion.</li><li><b><i>How many students are in this class?</i></b><br>This information reaches a large number of people.&nbsp; In the summer of 2012, 17,246 people were\nsigned up to take the course on the first week of lectures and 31,967 people\nwere registered by end of the course.&nbsp;\nHowever, of those students, 3,428 submitted the first assignment and\n1,066 submitted the final assignment.&nbsp;\n1,340 people completed at least five assignments and 1,023 people passed\nthe course.&nbsp; While there is more attrition\nthan in a traditional classroom, this is in part due to the online, free aspect\nof the course as people may sign up who are curious, but are not interested in\ncompleting the course.<b><i>&nbsp; </i></b>This\ncourse offers significant flexibility for students in terms of not only when\nyou do the work, but also how much you complete.&nbsp; Some students wish to learn as much as\npossible about the topic while others are interested in learning only a portion\nof the material.&nbsp; Students complete the\nwork because they are genuinely interested in learning the material.\n\n</li><li><b><i>I joined the class late.&nbsp; Can I\nstill participate?</i></b>\n\n\n\n<span><br>The top 6 of 8 assignments are calculated for\nyour grade.&nbsp; Thus you may miss 2\nassignments without impacting your grade.&nbsp;\nEven if you joined too late to pass the course, you may participate in\nthe class at any point by watching the videos, reading the material, and\nparticipating in the forums.</span> <br></li></ul>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><b><u>Readings:</u></b><b><i><br></i></b></p><ul><li><b><i>Why did you select these\nreadings?</i></b><br>The readings are limited to those\nwhich are freely available to the public, to facilitate anyone participating in\nthe course.&nbsp; Students widely range in their background and health care\nexperience.&nbsp; Thus, while the selected readings are generally at college\nlevel, they assume a student will have only a basic understanding of the\nAmerican health care system.&nbsp; Additional optional readings are provided\nfor those who wish to delve deeper into a particular topic.</li><li><b><i>Why do you have optional\nreadings?</i></b><br>Some people may be interesting in\nlearning more about a topic.&nbsp; For those students, we have identified\noptional readings.&nbsp; These optional readings provide background material or\nmore in-depth information on a topic.&nbsp; You will&nbsp;be graded only on\ninformation in the required readings. </li></ul>\n\n\n\n<p><b><u>Assignments</u></b>:</p><ul><li><b><i>I can\u2019t complete an assignment.&nbsp;\nWill I fail?</i></b><br>The top 6 of 8 assignments are calculated for your\ngrade.&nbsp; Thus you may miss 2 assignments\nwithout impacting your grade.<b><i>&nbsp;</i></b></li><li><b><i>How will I be graded?</i></b><br>You are given one assignment each week.&nbsp; The top 6 of 8 assignments are calculated for\nyour grade.&nbsp; Thus you may miss 2\nassignments without impacting your grade.&nbsp;\nFor each assignment, you will be graded by a minimum of four other\npeople.&nbsp; The high and low score for each\nassignment will be tossed out and the other scores averaged.</li><li><b><i>Am I required to participate in the forums?&nbsp; Are the quizzes graded?</i></b><br>Participation in the forums and quizzes available through\nthe video content are not graded.</li><li><b><i>How will I grade others?</i></b><br>Reviewers will receive a grading rubric and sample answer.</li><li><b><i>How will you ensure that the grades are fair?</i></b><br>We expect students are motivated to participate in their\neducation and we ask that everyone grade each other in an objective, fair, and\nunbiased manner.&nbsp; Grading will be\ndouble-blind; graders will not know whose work they are grading, and students\nwill not know who graded their work.&nbsp;\nEach assignment is graded by several different people, which will reduce\nany potential bias, with the high and low scores dropped for each student.&nbsp; Furthermore, the selection of assignments to\ngrade for each person will be random each week, so any given student is\nunlikely to have his/her work graded by any given student grader more than once.&nbsp; Finally, we will be checking the grading for\nconsistency (e.g. by comparing against grades assigned by the instructor to a\nfew \"sample\" assignments).</li><li><b><i>Why do you require students to grade each other?</i></b><br>This course is freely available on the internet.&nbsp; During the summer 2012 course, 31, 967\nstudents signed up for the course.&nbsp;\nCoursera and the University of Pennsylvania are not able to support\nproviding this course free for everyone without utilizing innovative and\nnon-traditional grading mechanisms.&nbsp; We\nalso believe that in grading each other, you will learn the material\nbetter.</li><li><b><i>What happens if I grade more assignments one week than the minimum\nrequired?&nbsp; Will I get extra credit?</i></b><br>You will receive the appreciation of your classmates and\nhopefully a greater understanding of the material.&nbsp; You will not, however, receive any extra\ncredit.</li><li><b><i>Can I grade extra assignments one week to make up for grading fewer\nassignments another week?</i></b><br>No.&nbsp; You are required to grade a minimum\nof five assignments each week.</li></ul>\n\n\n\n<p><b><u>Technical</u></b></p>\n\n<ul><li><b><i>Please\nprovide a spell-check option.</i></b><br>Until Coursera is able to provide this option, we suggest that you draft\nyour answer in Word, spell-check it, and then copy and paste your answer into\nthe answer box.</li><li><b><i>How\ndo I copy my answer into the assignment submission box?&nbsp; It does not work.</i></b><br>This is possibly a browser issue; Coursera is optimized for Google\nChrome.&nbsp; Try using the command keys to\ncopy and paste your answer from Word: Ctrl-A (highlight all), Ctrl-C (copy),\nand Ctrl-V (paste).</li><li><b><i>How\ndo you close the window for the multiple-choice question to resume the lecture\nvideo after the quizzes pop up?</i></b><br>This is possibly a browser issue.&nbsp; Coursera supports modern web standards and\nthe many devices that run browsers that support these features.&nbsp; Chrome, Firefox, IE (9-10), and Safari meet\nthese requirements.&nbsp; <br></li></ul>\n\n\n<br>", "category-ids": ["economics", "health"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "This course will explore the many problems of the American health care system and discuss the specific ways that the Affordable Care Act will impact access, quality, costs, as well as medical innovation.", "course_format": "<p>This class is eight weeks long.  Each \nweek, students will watch approximately 30 - 40 minutes of lectures delivered by Dr.\n Emanuel.  Students should expect to spend 2 - 5 hours per week reading \nrelated materials from the reading list, all of which are freely \naccessible online.  </p>\n\n<p>Students taking the course for a grade will complete one short essay \nquestion (approximately 1 page) per week, which will be peer-graded \nbased on a detailed answer key provided after the due date.  Of the \neight scores earned for assignments, the lowest two scores will be \ndropped in calculating the final grade.  The remaining six scores will \nbe weighted equally.  As a result, students who miss a homework \nassignment can still earn full credit in the course.  There are no exams\n or final projects in this course.  Students not taking the course for a\n grade may choose not to complete the assignments.  </p>\n\n<p>The details of these logistics are subject to change; if changes are \nmade, students will be notified via an announcement and this page will \nbe updated.</p><br>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": "https://www.coursera.org/course/healthpolicy", "suggested_readings": "<p>Below are the readings for each week. Students should read the \nmaterials in their entirety unless a subset of pages is indicated. Where\n page ranges are indicated, they are inclusive, and students should \nbegin and end reading at section breaks in the text.  Please note all \npage numbers refer to the printed pages of the article, not the page \nnumber in your pdf reader, if applicable.</p>\n\n<p>Abbreviations used: </p>\n\n<p>Kaiser Foundation = The Henry J. (Use zip code\n 02138 and choose the plan you think would be best for you. {"about_the_course": "<p>English Composition I provides an introduction to and foundation\nfor the academic reading and writing characteristic of college. Attending\nexplicitly to disciplinary context, you will learn to read critically, write\neffective arguments, understand the writing process, and craft powerful prose\nthat meets readers\u2019 expectations. You will gain writing expertise by exploring questions about expertise itself: What factors impact expert achievement? What does it take to succeed? Who determines success? Since personal investment yields better writing, you can select an area of expertise meaningful to you (a hobby, trade, profession, discipline, etc.) for your major writing projects, which will be drafted and revised in sequenced stages: a critical response to an argument about expertise (2pp.); an explication of a visual image (2pp.); a case study of an expert (4pp.) and an Op-Ed (2 pp.). Your writing will be central to the course as we create a seminar/workshop structure with peer response and selected instructor feedback.&nbsp;</p><p>Two overarching assumptions about academic writing will shape our work:&nbsp; 1) it is transferable; 2) it is learnable. Being an\neffective academic writer involves asking meaningful questions and\nengaging in complex dialogue with texts and ideas. These skills are useful across\nvirtually all academic disciplines and they provide a valuable means for making sense of non-academic experiences as well.\nPerhaps even more important, though, is that learning how to write effectively does not require inspiration\nor genius, but hard work, reflection, and feedback. This means that, with\npractice, dedication, and working with others,<i> you</i> can be an effective academic\nwriter and contribute your ideas to important, ongoing conversations. Let's start now.</p>\n<span>\n<span><p> <a href=\"https://duke.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_eWEH2NWLXc39gJT\"><b>Share why you want to improve your writing</b></a></p><p><a href=\"https://duke.qualtrics.com/WRReport/?RPID=RP2_9tVOvczFExmWknP&amp;P=CP\"><b>Find out what others say about writing</b></a><br></p></span>\n</span>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/24/3061bb92f2ab2bd892dbf6665dfefd/wordlemap.jpeg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/30/858861451d5799f69c4c41629034f2/wordlemap.png", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/d7/0b0fec4bac0eb2c60314224f8b53a1/wordlemap.png", "video": "ppE4ntBbKHs", "university-ids": ["duke"], "id": 327, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/65/b1eae360095757f04b8bfda5fdbb62/Duke_University_Logo.svg", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "DukeNews", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/cc/500c9f41731d797a0e108a4edd8bc1/favicon-duke.ico", "website_facebook": "DukeUniv", "id": 7, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/67/20d9fca42bddac2034668d7b589cad/dukewidelogo_vert.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Durham", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 35.9940329, "location": "Durham, NC, USA", "primary_color": "#003366", "abbr_name": "Duke", "website": "http://duke.edu/", "description": "Home of the Blue Devils, Duke University has about 13,000 undergraduate and graduate students and a world-class faculty helping to expand the frontiers of knowledge. The university has a strong commitment to applying knowledge in service to society, both near its North Carolina campus and around the world.", "short_name": "duke", "location_state": "NC", "website_youtube": "duke", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d9/bf7afd854801040ae40408c12843c1/banner-duke.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/8f/89065d522f7cccfd3db9f5412a8923/dukepanorama_coursera.jpg", "name": "Duke University", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/6d/3cb3e06c357d40ef60000fb3d12d72/dukesquare_blue.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/3e/8c76d14f11465d26e6d87c707dd239/dukesquare_blue.jpg", "display": true, "location_lng": -78.898619, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/8c/3fea3c61b899a0e79075dc8c96195d/dukewidelogo2.png", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<b>Unit 1 (Weeks 1-3): Critical Response</b><br>How do we become experts? I will ask you to draft and revise a critical response to an article about expertise by Daniel Coyle. You will draw on your selected area of expertise to respond to Coyle's arguments. Specifically, we will focus on how to:<br><ul><li>read critically;</li><li>summarize, question, analyze, and evaluate written text;</li><li>engage with the work of others;</li><li>understand the stages of the writing process;</li><li>workshop writing;</li><li>respond towards revision;</li><li>incorporate reader feedback;</li><li>integrate quotes/evidence;</li><li>cite the work of others; and</li><li>craft effective titles.</li></ul><b>Unit 2 (Weeks 4-5): Explicating a Visual Image</b><br>What does expertise look like? How do we define it? I will ask you to select a visual image depicting your selected area of expertise and then explicate that image in order to make an argument about what expertise looks like and how it can be defined. Specifically, we will continue to work with the elements we learned in Unit 1, as well as build on them by focusing on how to:<br><ul><li>summarize, questions, analyze, and evaluate visual texts;</li><li>argue and support a position;</li><li>use evidence;</li><li>achieve cohesion;</li><li>develop paragraph unity;</li><li>revise; and</li><li>edit</li></ul><b>Unit 3 (Weeks 6-9): Case Study</b><br>What can we learn about expertise in a particular area? What does it take to succeed? I will ask you to research a particular example of expert achievement in your selected area and, drawing on multiple resources, make an argument about expertise. Specifically, we will continue to work with the elements we learned in Units 1 and 2, as well as build on them by focusing on how to: <br><ul><li>conduct research;</li><li>write an extended argument;</li><li>examine disciplinary expectations;</li><li>develop an intertextual conversation;</li><li>understand popular sources and scholarly sources;</li><li>create effective introductions; and</li><li>write strong conclusions.</li></ul><b>Unit 4 (Weeks 10-12): Writing an Op-Ed</b><br>What do you think people need to know about expertise in your selected area? In this fourth and final unit, we will turn to a more public form of writing as I ask you to write an op-ed (opposite the editorial page) about your selected area of expertise for a publication of your choosing (you do not actually have to submit it to that publication). We'll also be working together to collaboratively crowdsource a bibliography of potential resources. Specifically, we will continue to work with the elements we learned in Units 1,2, and 3, as well as build on them by focusing on how to:<br><ul><li>write for publics;</li><li>write concisely;</li><li>edit and proofread thoroughly;</li><li>decide whether to use active or passive verbs; and</li><li>transfer writing skills to new writing contexts.</li></ul>", "description": "", "short_name": "composition", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<ul><li>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<b>Will I get a Statement of Accomplishment&nbsp;after completing this class?</b> <br></li></ul><blockquote>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will\nreceive a&nbsp;Statement of Accomplishment&nbsp;signed by the instructor. <br></blockquote><ul><li><b>Will I get feedback on my written work?</b> <br></li></ul><blockquote>Yes. There are peer evaluations of your work that are the basis of the course grade. In addition, Professor Comer and her teaching staff will model effective feedback practices so class members can respond productively to one another. We will also hold several in-time virtual workshops, and use selected student writing for examples (anonymously and with your permission).<br></blockquote><ul><li><b>Will this course provide instruction on grammar?</b> <br></li></ul><blockquote>No. Although grammar is important and resources on grammar will be provided, this course is focused primarily on how to write effective arguments. This involves asking meaningful questions, engaging with the work of others, and writing powerful prose. We will focus at times on sentence-level aspects of writing, including how to write more concisely, but our primary interest is in communicating your ideas effectively to readers through the use of argument and evidence.<br></blockquote><ul><li><b>Will the course be especially difficult if a student is not very proficient in the English language?</b> <br></li></ul><blockquote>We welcome cultural and linguistic diversity, and will tailor the course to meet the needs of learners with varying levels of familiarity and facility with the English language. Part of our work will involve discussions about how different people use language, and what different expectations people bring to writing. These conversations will be strengthened with the inclusion of people who speak a wide variety of languages. We will have an expert on English as a Second Language working with our course to provide resources, model feedback practices, facilitate productive conversations, and provide instruction at times.<br></blockquote><ul><li><b>Will this course be geared primarily to writing in English Literature courses?&nbsp;</b>No. This course will help you with academic writing in all disciplines. We will have experts working with the course who have doctorates across the social sciences, natural sciences, and humanities, and we will address disciplinary conventions explicitly. We will ask you to reflect on how you can transfer the writing knowledge you gain in this course to other writing experiences you might have in various disciplines.</li></ul><ul><li><b>What is the song in the promo video and why is it there?</b> Throughout the course, we will be including songs about writing. We will include links to the songs and (if available) the artist web pages on our course wiki page. The song in the intro video is <a href=\"http://www.jamendo.com/en/track/944174/writing-backwards\">\"Writing Backwards\"</a> by the group impossible songs.<br></li></ul><br>", "category-ids": ["humanities", "education", "socsci"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "You will gain a foundation for college-level writing valuable for nearly any field. Students will learn how to read carefully, write effective arguments, understand the writing process, engage with others' ideas, cite accurately, and craft powerful prose. We will create a workshop environment. ", "course_format": "By engaging with ~40 interactive instructional\nvideos (each ~six-eight minutes in length), students will research, draft, and\nrevise the following four major projects in sequenced stages and with feedback\nfrom their peers: a critical response to an argument about expertise (2pp.); an\nexplication of a visual image (2pp.); a case study of an expert (4pp.); and an\nOp-Ed about expertise (2pp.). Smaller assignments enable students to build up\nto these projects; these include directed reflections, forum participation,\nresponse papers, peer review, practice quizzes, polls, discussions, and\nsurveys. \n\n<br>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": null, "suggested_readings": "Students are encouraged to refer to the materials in this open-source textbook for additional help with their writing:<a href=\"http://writingcommons.org/open-text\"> Writing Commons</a> <br><b></b>", "instructor": "Denise Comer", "categories": [{"mailing_list_id": 11, "description": "Our wide range of courses allows students to explore topics from many different fields of study.
