Her leadership, collaboration, and innovation designing first-year\nwriting courses and training first-year writing faculty have helped earn Duke\nUniversity\u2019s Thompson Writing Program national recognition with the 2006 CCCC\nWriting Program Certificate of Excellence and the 2012 <i>U.S. News & World\nReport</i>, which commended Duke for \u201cmaking the writing process a priority at all\nlevels of instruction and across the curriculum.\u201d1<br></p>\n\n\n\n<p>She has led several initiatives for Duke and the Durham\ncommunity that demonstrate her investment teaching writing to <i>all</i> learners:\nlaunching a writing course for students who need more time and preparation with\ncollege-level writing, many of whom are first-generation/low-income;\nintegrating responsiveness to English Language Learners across all first-year\nwriting courses; developing writing workshops for low-income, high-potential\nurban middle-school children; and creating a writing-based program for\nchronically and fatally ill children staying at the Ronald McDonald House of\nDurham. Prior to Duke, she taught writing for public universities, community\ncolleges, and a military base. Her scholarship explores writing pedagogy,\nwriting program administration, and the intersections between technology and\nthe teaching of writing. She has two books forthcoming from Fountainhead Press\nin 2014:<i> Writing in Transit: A Reader</i> (ed.) and <i>It\u2019s Just a Dissertation:\nTransforming Your Dissertation from Daunting to Doable to Done </i>(co-written with\nBarbara Gina Garrett).</p><p>1 <a href=\"http://www.ncte.org/cccc/awards/writingprogramcert\">http://www.ncte.org/cccc/awards/writingprogramcert</a>, <a>; http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/rankings/writing-programs</a></p>", "small_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/30/858861451d5799f69c4c41629034f2/wordlemap.png", "course-ids": [970454], "display": true, "recommended_background": "<p>Students should have basic English proficiency and exposure\nto secondary-level English or composition. </p>"}
{"about_the_course": "<p>One hundred thousand years ago, <i>Homo\nsapiens </i>was still an insignificant animal minding its own business in a\ncorner of Africa. Our ancestors shared the\nplanet with at least five other human species, and their role in the ecosystem\nwas no greater than that of gorillas, fireflies, or jellyfish. Then, about\n70,000 years ago, a mysterious change took place in the cognitive abilities of <i>Homo\nsapiens, </i>transforming it into the master of the entire planet and the\nterror of the ecosystem. Today it stands on the verge of becoming a god,\nmolding not only its surroundings but also its own body and mind.</p>\n\n<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The\ncourse will explain how <i>Homo sapiens</i> conquered planet Earth, and what it\ndid with its newly acquired power. How did <i>Homo sapiens</i> manage to drive\nall other human species to extinction, along with about half of the world\u2019s\nlarge terrestrial mammals? When did money and gods appear, and why? How did\nempires rise and fall, and why is it possible for small minorities to lord it\nover vast numbers of subject populations? Why did almost all societies believe\nthat women are inferior to men? What was the role of religion in history, and\nwhy did monotheism become the most widespread type of religion? How did science\nand capitalism become the dominant creeds of the modern era? Does history have\na direction? Did people become happier as history progressed? And what are the\nchances that <i>Homo sapiens</i> will still be around in a hundred years?</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/d4/67be62c268689fb920785cddb926f1/LOGO-hands-cave.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/b7/f1c2dd78e1eee4d1255aba2ac62bea/LOGO-hands-cave.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/c9/598923eb2c6911166d8156eff414e3/LOGO-hands-cave.jpg", "video": "xQ4eg7Zj5OY", "university-ids": ["huji"], "id": 292, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/48/7cac159746dca5674234142a147d0f/HebrewSmallIcon2.png", "website_facebook": "", "id": 24, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/66/b7a799a8992913a9a702a22ae8bdcb/HebrewLogo4.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "", "primary_color": "#c12127", "abbr_name": "Hebrew University", "website": "", "description": "", "short_name": "huji", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/03/fadb443f52e728749d13bb0fdcbb32/HebrewBanner.jpg", "landing_page_banner": null, "name": "Hebrew University of Jerusalem", "square_logo": null, "square_logo_source": null, "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": null, "square_logo_svg": null}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p><b>Part I: The Cognitive Revolution</b><b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 1: An Animal of No Significance</b><br></p>\n\n<p>One hundred thousand years ago, at\nleast six different species of humans inhabited planet Earth. Who were they?\nWhere did they come from? Why is there today only one species of humans\u2014<i>Homo\nsapiens</i>\u2014and what happened to all the others?<b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 2: The Tree of Knowledge\n</b></p>\n\n<p>The Cognitive Revolution, about\n70,000 years ago, enabled <i>Homo sapiens</i> to conquer the world and drive\nall other human species to extinction. <i>Homo sapiens</i> developed new\ncognitive abilities, which manifested in the appearance of \u201cmodern language.\u201d\nHow was this language different from the languages of earlier human species and\nof other animals? Why can we consider the appearance of this new type of\nlanguage as the beginning of history? How is history different from biology?<b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 3: A Day in the Life of\nAdam and Eve</b></p>\n\n<p>What was life like for the people\nwho lived between the Cognitive Revolution (c. 70,000 years ago) and the\nAgricultural Revolution (c. 10,000 years ago)? What did they do when they woke\nup in the morning? What were their societies like? Did they have monogamous\nrelationships and nuclear families? Did they have religions, revolutions, and\nwars?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 4: The Flood</b></p>\n\n<p>Following the Cognitive Revolution,\n<i>Homo sapiens</i> spread all over the planet. While doing this, it drove\nnumerous other species into extinction. In Australia, up to 95% of all large\nanimal species vanished. In America,\n84 of 107 large mammal species likewise disappeared. Altogether, about half of\nthe large terrestrial mammal species that populated Earth became extinct. How\ncould a few million individuals who possessed no more than stone-age technology\nhave wrought such devastation?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b><br></b></p><p><b>Part II: The Agricultural Revolution</b><b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 5: History\u2019s Biggest\nFraud</b></p>\n\n<p>About 10,000 years ago, people in\nthe Middle East, China, and Central America began domesticating plants and animals.\nIn the process, <i>Homo sapiens</i>,<i>\n</i>too, was domesticated, abandoning a life of hunting and gathering\nfor the pleasures and discomforts of permanent settlements. For most people,\nthe discomforts outweighed the pleasures. The Agricultural Revolution made the\nlife of the average person harder and grimmer. Why, then, did it occur?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 6: Building Pyramids</b></p>\n\n<p>For millions of years, humans lived\nin intimate bands of no more than a few dozen individuals. Our biological\ninstincts evolved as an adaptation to this way of life. Humans were therefore\nill-equipped to cooperate with large numbers of strangers. This hasn\u2019t changed\nmuch. Yet within a few millennia after the onset of the Agricultural\nRevolution, humans established cities, kingdoms, and empires. How did people\nmanage to organize stable societies based on intensive cooperation between\nmillions of strangers when our biological makeup seems to preclude such\narrangements?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 7: A Revolution in\nData-Processing </b></p>\n\n<p>One of the critical factors that\nenabled millions of strangers to cooperate successfully was the invention of\nwriting. How was writing invented, and what was its historical significance?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 8: There is No Justice\nin History </b></p>\n\n<p>Another critical factor in the\nformation of complex societies was the division of the population into a\nhierarchy of groups. Agricultural and industrial societies have been built on\nhierarchies of class, race, ethnicity, or gender. Why was it impossible to\ncreate a just and equal society? What is the deep root of prejudice and\ninjustice? In particular, why have almost all known societies over the past\n10,000 years believed that men are superior to women?<b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Part III: The Unification of Humankind</b><b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 9: The Arrow of History\n</b></p>\n\n<p>In the millennia following the\nAgricultural Revolution, humans created many different cultures. How did these\ncultures relate to one another? Are there universal patterns governing the\ninteraction between them?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 10: The Scent of Money</b></p>\n\n<p>Commerce has played a crucial role\nin connecting and merging cultures. Of particular importance was the\ninvention\u2014and spread\u2014of money. Money is a system of mutual trust. It is in fact\nthe most universal, most open-minded, and most successful system of mutual\ntrust ever devised. How did it happen that people who believe in different gods\nand obey different rulers nevertheless trust the same money?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 11: Imperial Visions</b></p>\n\n<p>The idea of empire is seen today in\na very negative light, but empires have played such a central role in human\nhistory that it\u2019s hard to regard them as solidly evil. What exactly is an\nempire? How have empires succeeded in uniting under their aegis different\necological regions, ethnic groups, and religious communities? How can we\nbalance the positive contribution of empires with their record of violence and\noppression? And what is the future of the imperial ideal? Is the world destined\nto be ruled by a new global empire?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 12: The Law of Religion</b></p>\n\n<p>The role of religion in history is\nextremely controversial. Some see religion as the root of all evil, while for\nothers it is the primary source of happiness, empathy, and progress. Can we\narrive at a balanced judgment? What were the main landmarks in the religious\nhistory of the world? In what ways did different cultures understand the\nuniverse, distinguish good from evil, and grapple with the ubiquitous presence\nof suffering?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 13: The Secret of\nSuccess</b></p>\n\n<p>Why did some religions spread like\nwildfire while others disappeared? Why did some empires last for centuries, yet\nothers were as ephemeral as sand castles? Can we identify the secret of historical\nsuccess, and will it help us to predict the future course of history?</p><p>&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Part IV. The Scientific Revolution</b><b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 14: The Discovery of\nIgnorance</b></p>\n\n<p>During the last 500 years there has\nbeen an explosive and exponential growth in the power of humankind, due, above\nall, to the formation of the modern scientific tradition and its ideal of\n\u201cprogress.\u201d Humankind has become increasingly convinced that the only thing\nthat limits its power is its own ignorance, and that the discovery of new\nknowledge can enable it to do almost anything. How is the modern scientific\ntradition different from all previous traditions of knowledge? What accounts\nfor its sudden rise and for its unparalleled achievements?<b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 15: The Marriage of\nScience and Empire</b></p>\n\n<p>The modern scientific tradition\ndeveloped in symbiosis with the modern imperial tradition. For many of their\npractitioners, science and imperialism were almost indistinguishable. The\nconquest of new knowledge depended upon and made possible the conquest of new\nterritories. Why did all of this begin in Europe\nof all places, an area that previously had played no important role in world\nhistory? How did science help build empires, and how did empire-builders repay\nthe scientists?<b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 16: The Capitalist Creed</b></p>\n\n<p>The close relationship of science\nand imperialism was in fact just one part of a m\u00e9nage-\u00e0-trois. The third\ncrucial member of this trio was modern capitalism, which financed both science\nand empire, and which orchestrated an unprecedented growth in the world\neconomy. How does a capitalist economy function? How is it different from\ntraditional economies? Is capitalism natural, or is it really a modern\nreligion?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 17: The Wheels of\nIndustry</b></p>\n\n<p>During the last 200 years, the\ncombination of science, imperialism and capitalism gave humankind control of\nenormous new energy resources that revolutionized human production. How did this\nchange the global ecology, daily life, and human psychology?<b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 18: A Permanent\nRevolution</b></p>\n\n<p>The industrial revolution unhinged\nthe world, opening an era of permanent revolution. The late modern\nsocio-political order is in constant flux, never settling into any stable\npattern. The pillars of human order\u2014most notably, the family and the intimate\ncommunity\u2014are crumbling around us. How do humans deal with the resulting vacuum\nand chaos? How do society and politics function without stability? Is the world\nbecoming more violent and dangerous, or is it actually more peaceful and secure\nthan ever before?&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 19: And They Lived\nHappily Ever After </b></p>\n\n<p>Have 500 years of unimaginable\ndiscoveries, developments, and revolutions made people happier? If not, what\nwas the point of all these changes? Most history books ignore these issues, yet\nthese are the most important questions we can ask about history. New insights\nfrom biology, economics, and psychology are offering fascinating paths of\ninquiry into the history of human happiness.<b>&nbsp;</b></p>\n\n<p><b>Lecture 20: The End of <i>Homo Sapiens</i>\n</b></p>\n\n<p>Over the last few decades humans\nhave began to bend and break the laws of natural selection\u2014laws that have\ngoverned life on Earth for the past four billion years. Genetic engineering,\ncyborg engineering, and the engineering of completely non-organic life promise\nto dislodge natural selection\u2014in favor of intelligent design\u2014as the supreme\nprinciple of life. We are acquiring unprecedented abilities to design not only\nthe world around us, but also our own bodies, our personalities, and our\ndesires. How will this influence society and culture? Does anybody know where\nwe are heading? What exactly do we want to become?<b></b></p>", "description": "", "short_name": "humankind", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "", "category-ids": ["humanities"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "The course surveys the entire length of human history, from the evolution of various human species in the Stone Age up to the political and technological revolutions of the twenty-first century.", "course_format": "<p>The course includes 20 lectures.\nEach is 60-120 minutes long, divided into 6-12 short segments.</p><p>Students can watch each lecture in one go, or break it up into several segments.</p>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": null, "suggested_readings": "<p>Participating in the course does\nnot require any reading, but students may consult the book <i>From Animals into Gods:&nbsp;A Brief History\nof Humankind</i> which has inspired the course (the book is&nbsp;available at&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.amazon.com/From-Animals-into-Gods-Humankind/dp/1478237856/\">http://www.amazon.com/From-Animals-into-Gods-Humankind/dp/1478237856/</a>).&nbsp;</p>", "instructor": "Dr. Yuval Noah Harari", "categories": [{"mailing_list_id": 11, "description": "Our wide range of courses allows students to explore topics from many different fields of study. Sign up for a class today and join our global community of students and scholars!", "id": 6, "short_name": "humanities", "name": "Humanities "}], "estimated_class_workload": "2-4 hours/week", "name": "A Brief History of Humankind", "language": "en", "courses": [{"grading_policy_distinction": "", "ace_track_price_display": null, "signature_track_certificate_design_id": null, "ace_semester_hours": null, "start_year": null, "duration_string": "", "signature_track_last_chance_time": null, "id": 970359, "start_month": null, "certificate_description": "", "start_date_string": null, "eligible_for_ACE": false, "signature_track_regular_price": null, "grades_release_date": null, "creator_id": null, "signature_track_price": null, "statement_design_id": null, "signature_track_registration_open": false, "topic_id": 292, "eligible_for_signature_track": false, "start_date": null, "status": 1, "start_day": null, "end_date": null, "notified_subscribers": true, "instructors": [1804614], "active": false, "eligible_for_certificates": true, "deployed": true, "ace_close_date": null, "name": "001", "signature_track_open_time": null, "grading_policy_normal": "", "ace_open_date": null, "home_link": "https://class.coursera.org/humankind-001/", "certificates_ready": false, "proctored_exam_completion_date": null, "university_logo": null, "signature_track_close_time": null}], "about_the_instructor": "<p>Dr. Yuval Noah Harari lectures at\nthe Department of History, the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. He specializes\nin World History, medieval history and military history. For the past decade he\nhas been teaching an introductory course in World History to various groups of\nstudents at the Hebrew University, including Israelis, Palestinians and foreign\nexchange students; Jews, Christians, Muslims and atheists. His\nteaching philosophy is focused on provoking the students to question the basic\nnarratives of our world, to connect past developments with present concerns,\nand not to be afraid of controversial issues.&nbsp;<img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/63/4f2c87e17bcb505b81ed78d8849583/Harari-picture.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"></p>\n\n<p>His most recent\nbook, <i>From Animals into Gods:&nbsp;A Brief History of Humankind</i> (2012) was originally published in\nHebrew. After becoming a national bestseller in Israel, it is now being translated\ninto English and German. His current studies focus on the connection between\nhistory and biology, on the ethics of history, and on the history of happiness\nand suffering. </p>\n\n<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; His\nmany other publications include <i>Special Operations in the Age of Chivalry,\n1100-1550</i> (2007); <i>The Ultimate Experience: Battlefield Revelations and\nthe Making of Modern War Culture, 1450-2000</i> (2008); \u201cThe Concept of\n\u2018Decisive Battles\u2019 in World History\u201d, <i>The Journal of World History</i> 18:3\n(2007), 251-266; and \u201cArmchairs, Coffee and Authority: Eye-witnesses and\nFlesh-witnesses Speak about War, 1100-2000\u201d, <i>The Journal of Military History</i> 74:1\n(January 2010), pp. 53-78.<br><br></p>", "small_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/b7/f1c2dd78e1eee4d1255aba2ac62bea/LOGO-hands-cave.jpg", "course-ids": [970359], "display": true, "recommended_background": "<p>There are no entry requirements.\nThe course is intended both to people who have never studied history seriously,\nand wish to gain an overview of the human past, and to people who have studied\nhistory before, but who would like to get a fresh and challenging perspective\non it.&nbsp;</p>"}
{"about_the_course": "My course on Neuroethics originally scheduled for this spring has been postponed until September.&nbsp; I recognize that this will be an inconvenience for some and for that I apologize, but teaching an online course is a new experience for me, as taking one is for many of you, and as I've been preparing the sessions I have discovered that there is some fine-tuning to be done.&nbsp; Since I don't want to compromise on quality I hope you will all understand and bear with me.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;-- Jonathan D. Moreno, Ph.D.<br><br>\u201cPerhaps a man really dies when his brain stops, when he loses the power to take in a new idea.\u201d --George Orwell<br><br> Neuroethics might well be the most rapidly growing area within bioethics; indeed, in some respects neuroethics has grown as an independent field, with its own journals, professional society and institutional centers. This growth over the past decade is partly attributable to the growth of neuroscience itself and to the challenging philosophical and moral questions it inherently raises. A 2012 Royal Society report observes that \u201c(a)n increasingly mechanistic understanding of the brain raises a host of ethical, legal, and social implications. This has laid the foundation for the emergent field of Neuroethics, which examines ethical issues governing the conceptual and practical developments of neuroscience. Irrespective of their validity, even the claims that modern neuroscience entails the re-examination of complex and sensitive topics like free will, consciousness, identity, and responsibility raises significant ethical issues. As such, neuroethics asks questions that extend beyond the usual umbrella of biomedical ethics.\u201d This course will, therefore, consider the new knowledge and ways of learning about the brain from scientific and ethico-legal and social standpoints. We will examine the core themes of neuroethics, including cognitive enhancement, the nature of the self and personhood, neuroimaging and privacy, and the ways that all these themes are brought together in matters affecting national security.<br><br> <strong><br></strong>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/neuroethics/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/neuroethics/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/neuroethics/large-icon.png", "video": "-p3iFE06q14", "university-ids": ["penn"], "id": 50, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "@pennopencourses", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f3/2ca37fd0d5d009a94e0ba7f284c860/favicon-penn.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 6, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7c/5d03cbe2cb87974be7f83cc1080af8/logo-penn-front.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "City, State, Country", "primary_color": "#0000ff", "abbr_name": "Penn", "website": "http://provost.upenn.edu/initiatives/openlearning", "description": "The University of Pennsylvania (commonly referred to as Penn or UPenn) is a private university, located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. Moreno, Ph.D. is the David and Lyn Silfen University Professor of Ethics at the University of Pennsylvania, where he is also Professor of Medical Ethics and Health Policy, of History and Sociology of Science, and of Philosophy. Nominated by the U.S. government, Moreno is a member of the UNESCO International Bioethics Commission. He was an Andrew W. Mellon post-doctoral fellow, holds an honorary doctorate from Hofstra University, and is a recipient of the Benjamin Rush Medal from the College of William and Mary Law School and the Dr. Jean Mayer Award for Global Citizenship from Tufts University. {"about_the_course": "Fantasy is a key term both in psychology and in the art and artifice of humanity. The things we make, including our stories, reflect, serve, and often shape our needs and desires. We see this everywhere from fairy tale to kiddie lit to myth; from \"Cinderella\" to <i>Alice in Wonderland </i>to <i>Superman</i>; from building a fort as a child to building ideal, planned cities as whole societies. Fantasy in ways both entertaining and practical serves our persistent needs and desires and illuminates the human mind. Fantasy expresses itself in many ways, from the comfort we feel in the godlike powers of a fairy godmother to the seductive unease we feel confronting Dracula. From a practical viewpoint, of all the fictional forms that fantasy takes, science fiction, from <i>Frankenstein</i> to <i>Avatar</i>, is the most important in our modern world because it is the only kind that explicitly recognizes the profound ways in which science and technology, those key products of the human mind, shape not only our world but our very hopes and fears. This course will explore Fantasy in general and Science Fiction in specific both as art and as insights into ourselves and our world. <br><br>\n<h2>Work Expectations</h2>\nFor further information about the coursework, please see the <a href=\"http://spark-public.s3.amazonaws.com/fantasysf/Documents/WorkExpectations.html\"> Work Expectations</a> page.", "other_description": "", "photo": "This course comprises ten units. Each will include a significant reading, typically a novel or a selection of shorter works. I will offer video discussions of each of the readings and also of more general topics in art and psychology that those readings help illuminate. Each unit will include online quizzes and ask you to write a brief essay offering your own insights into the reading. In order, the units are:<ol>\n<li>Grimm \u2014 <i>Children's and Household Tales</i></li>\n<li>Carroll \u2014 <i>Alice's Adventures in Wonderland</i> and <i>Through the Looking-Glass</i></li>\n<li>Stoker \u2014 <i>Dracula</i></li>\n<li>Shelley \u2014 <i>Frankenstein</i></li>\n<li>Hawthorne &amp; Poe \u2014 Stories and Poems</li>\n<li>Wells \u2014 <i>The Island of Dr. Moreau</i>, <i>The Invisible Man</i>, \"The Country of the Blind,\" \"The Star\"</li>\n<li>Burroughs &amp; Gilman \u2014 <i>A Princess of Mars</i> &amp; <i>Herland</i></li>\n<li>Bradbury \u2014 <i>The Martian Chronicles</i></li>\n<li>LeGuin \u2014 <i>The Left Hand of Darkness</i></li>\n<li>Doctorow \u2014 <i>Little Brother</i></li>\n</ol>\n<p>In Unit I, the specific stories are the ones in the Lucy Crane translation (1886) which was published by Dover and is available online through Project Gutenberg. In Unit V, the specific readings are: Hawthorne's \"The Birthmark,\" \"Rappaccini's Daughter,\" \"Dr. Heidegger's Experiment,\" and \"The Artist of the Beautiful\"; Poe's \"The Fall of the House of Usher,\" \"The Tell-Tale Heart,\" \"The Black Cat,\" \"The Oval Portrait,\" \"The Facts in the Case of M. Valdemar,\" \"The Bells,\" \"The Raven,\" \"Annabel Lee.\" All the readings except Ray Bradbury's <i>The Martian Chronicles</i> and Ursula K. LeGuin's <i>The Left Hand of Darkness</i> will be available online at no charge.</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "fantasysf", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Will I get a certificate after completing this class?</strong>\n<p>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a certificate signed by the instructor.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What resources will I need for this class?</strong>\n<p>For this course, all you need is an Internet connection, copies of the texts (most of which can be obtained for free), and the time to read, write, discuss, and enjoy some marvelous literature.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What is the coolest thing I'll learn if I take this class?</strong>\n<p>In addition to dealing with some terrific fiction, this course aims to help everyone think more imaginatively, read more deeply, and write more powerfully.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>", "category-ids": ["humanities"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "We understand the world \u2014 and our selves \u2014 through stories. Then some of those hopes and fears become the world.", "course_format": "This course includes an introductory unit of video clips discussing how one should proceed plus ten content units. &nbsp;Each content unit asks for the reading of a book or book-length selection of writings in the field of fantasy and science fiction and offers the chance to write a brief essay about that unit\u2019s reading and to comment on the writing of four other participants. &nbsp;Each content unit begins with a video clip with some advice about that unit\u2019s reading and later provides a series of clips, totaling about 1 1/2 hours, discussing both the unit\u2019s reading and general matters that that reading helps explore. &nbsp;The course also offers an enrichment quiz (ungraded) for each unit and an on-going forum for participant discussion. &nbsp;That forum will be monitored and may stimulate the creation of a supplementary clip or two per unit. &nbsp;If any participant desires a grade, the grade will be determined by the quality and quantity of the writing and responses to the writing of others.", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": "https://www.coursera.org/course/fantasysf", "suggested_readings": "I do not ask participants in this course to use any specific editions. However, for some works I believe some editions are better than others. For example, some editions of <i>The Island of Dr. Moreau</i> omit Charles Edward Prendick's \"Introduction\"; however, since that \"Introduction\" was actually written by H. G. Wells and included in the original publication of the book, it should not be omitted. For some works, I believe that a printed text is preferable. For example, the paper versions of <i>Alice in Wonderland</i> printed with <i>Through the Looking-Glass</i> along with James Tenniel's illustrations for both give one a sense of Lewis Carroll's original intent and design. The University of Adelaide's eBooks@Adelaide site makes available both <i>Alice in Wonderland</i> and <i>Through the Looking-Glass</i>with Tenniel's illustrations placed approximately where they were in the original text, although the chapters themselves are not broken into pages. Thus that online edition, for many people, is a reasonable although not exact substitute for the printed book. For those who choose to use online editions in this course, links for the currently available ones that I would suggest are listed below. <br><br><ol>\n<li>Grimm \u2014 <i>Children's and Household Tales</i> (<a href=\"http://openlibrary.org/books/OL14013824M/Household_stories\">Lucy Crane translation with Walter Crane illustrations</a>)</li>\n<li>Carroll \u2014 <a href=\"http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/c/carroll/lewis/alice/\"><i>Adventures in Wonderland</i></a> and <a href=\"http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/c/carroll/lewis/looking/\"><i>Through the Looking-Glass</i></a></li>\n<li>Stoker \u2014 <a href=\"http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/s/stoker/bram/s87d\"><i>Dracula</i></a> (This reading is somewhat longer than most of the others. You may want to begin it in advance.)</li>\n<li>Shelley \u2014 <a href=\"http://openlibrary.org/books/OL20443134M/Frankenstein_Or_The_Modern_Prometheus\"><i>Frankenstein</i></a></li>\n<li>Hawthorne &amp; Poe \u2014 Stories and Poems (Hawthorne's <a href=\"http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/512\"><i>Mosses from an Old Manse</i></a> includes \"The Birthmark,\" \"Rappaccini's Daughter,\" and \"The Artist of the Beautiful\" and his <a href=\"http://www.gutenberg.org/files/13707/13707-h/13707-h.htm\"><i>Twice-Told Tales</i></a> includes \"Dr. Heidegger's Experiment\"; <a href=\"http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=3&amp;ved=0CG4QFjAC&amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Fmikicafilolosko.pbworks.com%2Ff%2FThe%252BPortable%252BEdgar%252BAllan%252BPoe.pdf&amp;ei=0zjrT5fyPIiS9QTzy73bBQ&amp;usg=AFQjCNFInjyZaqCbms232WCphZaYmPeWug\"><i>The Portable Poe</i></a> includes all the suggested Poe stories and poems</li>\n<li>Wells \u2014 <a href=\"http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/w/wells/hg/\"><i>The Island of Dr. Moreau</i>, <i>The Invisible Man</i>, \"The Country of the Blind,\" \"The Star\"</a></li>\n<li>Burroughs &amp; Gilman \u2014 <a href=\"http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/62\"><i>A Princess of Mars</i></a> &amp; <a href=\"http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/g/gilman/charlotte_perkins/herland\"><i>Herland</i></a></li>\n<li>Bradbury \u2014 <i>The Martian Chronicles</i> (not available for legal, free download)</li>\n<li>LeGuin \u2014 <i>The Left Hand of Darkness</i> (not available for legal, free download)</li>\n<li>Doctorow \u2014 <a href=\"http://craphound.com/littlebrother/download/\"><i>Little Brother</i></a> (This reading is somewhat longer than most of the others. You may want to begin it in advance.)</li>\n</ol>In whatever form, I hope you enjoy your reading! <br><br>\n<h2>Reading Advice</h2>\nShould you read the works for this course as they come up each week or in advance? Different people work best different ways. I like to read slowly, underline, write in the margins, and make up an index to a work when I've finished reading it. For me reading in advance often works nicely because I can, just before the moment when I need to discuss the work, review the underlinings and the index to fully refresh my memory and get an overview of the work. For other people, particularly those who don't take extensive notes, reading quite close to the moment of discussion or of writing about the work is crucial. I think individuals will need to judge for themselves which way to read for this course.", "instructor": "Eric Rabkin", "categories": [{"mailing_list_id": 11, "description": "Our wide range of courses allows students to explore topics from many different fields of study. {"about_the_course": "<p>Principles of Public Health&nbsp;introduces the major concepts of public health and the\ndeterminants of health status in communities. The course emphasizes the\necological model that focuses on the linkages and relationships among multiple\nnatural and social determinants affecting health. As a relative concept, the\nhealth of populations is assessed through comparisons of temporal, spatial, and\ndemographic dimensions of disease burden. The goal of public health is to\nunderstand why and how different populations carry different kinds and amounts\nof disease burden, and to use that knowledge for improving health by preventing\ndisease.&nbsp;</p>\n\n\n\n<p>Students in the course will explore successful examples in\npublic health, including how scientific discoveries and regulatory policies\nhave both contributed to mitigate risk factors and improve health outcomes. How\nsocioeconomic and cultural factors modify the effectiveness of risk\nintervention and disease prevention strategies. How individual actions and\ncollective initiatives play important roles in determining the status of\nhealth. In addition, how the various methodological approaches that guide\ndiscoveries in public health have been applied from the local scale to the\nglobal level.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/bf/296fa0eb9f2325ead65d02bc2bb05c/iStock_000011822057XSmall.jpeg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/96/b4073c6a86832dfcd5c3ad5f3a4fac/iStock_000011822057XSmall.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/01/796e8a34fcb8d5dd688b5b3883952a/iStock_000011822057XSmall.jpg", "video": "zQqwww_DOgs", "university-ids": ["uci"], "id": 190, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/33/e75ec0e47204f7a8f928ca487d52ee/logo_uci_rectangle_vector.svg", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "UCIrvine", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/21/fe2ddd0d8a37bbb16033878eac3d75/16x16_uci.png", "website_facebook": "", "id": 30, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/30/f54378236f5403bb12ad3d06123fa9/logo_uci_rectangle_160x60.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Irvine", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 33.6839473, "location": "Irvine, CA, USA", "primary_color": "#008C44", "abbr_name": "UC Irvine", "website": "http://uci.edu/", "description": "Since 1965, the University of California, Irvine has combined the strengths of a major research university with the bounty of an incomparable Southern California location. "course_syllabus": "\u201cA Look at Nuclear Science and Technology\u201d is an overview course that provides broad subject-area coverage to introduce students to application of theory to practical aspects of nuclear science and technology in the world today with special emphasis on commercial nuclear power. The course will begin with a general overview of nuclear physics and the practical applications covered by the field of nuclear engineering. The majority of the course will focus on the theory, design and operation of commercial nuclear power reactors. The course will also touch on contemporary issues regarding nuclear power generation including: the nuclear fuel cycle, the economics of nuclear power, and nuclear non-proliferation.<br><br>The course will begin with a grand tour of the commercial nuclear fuel cycle and power reactors so the student will have some perspective before delving into the theory that is important to understanding the unique aspects of nuclear energy. The course then will return to the fundamentals of basic nuclear physics, reactor physics, energy removal and power conversion to prepare students for in-depth looks at the theory and function of commercial nuclear power reactors.<br><br>This course is intended for students who have had little to no academic instruction in nuclear engineering. Some of my incentives to teach this class are (1) to stimulate interest and excitement about nuclear science and technology, and (2) to create a more informed citizenry on the subject of nuclear energy utilization in the future. <br><br><ol><li>Introduction \u2013 A Grand Tour of the Nuclear Fuel Cycle</li><li>Atomic and Nuclear Physics \u2013 The Einstein Connection</li><li>Nuclear Reactions and Radiation \u2013 The Life and Trials of Neutrons and the Things They Create</li><li>Radiation and Radiation Protection \u2013 Radiation and Realism</li><li>Fission Reactor Basics \u2013 Links in the Chain Reaction</li><li>Overview of Power Reactors and Nuclear Systems \u2013 Over 440 in the World and Growing</li><li>Power Conversion Systems and the Balance of Plant \u2013 From Heat to Electricity</li><li>Fuel Design and Energy Removal \u2013 The Balance Between Resiliency and Power Density</li><li>The Time-Dependent Reactor \u2013 Thanks for Delayed Neutrons</li><li>Putting It All Together \u2013 Depletion, Plant Ops and a Virtual Tour</li><li>Nuclear Non-Proliferation and Terrorism: How much should I worry?</li><li>Examinations and Final</li></ol>", "description": "", "short_name": "nuclearscience", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<b>Although I have a college degree, I don\u2019t have a very strong background in science. Do you think I have a chance at succeeding in this class?</b><br><ul><li>Yes. I\u2019ve structured it with you in mind.</li></ul><b>Will I get a certificate after completing this class?</b><br><ul><li>Students who successfully complete this class will receive a Statement of Accomplishment signed by the instructor.</li></ul><b>What resources will I need for this class?</b><br><ul><li>You will need a computer that can access high speed Internet. While it will help to have a copy of the text by Knief (see recommended text listed above), the course materials are mostly self-contained and reading materials can be accessed on the Web or available from within the course.</li></ul><b>What are the coolest things I\u2019ll learn if I take this class?</b><br><ul><li>You will learn that a tiny fuel pellet less than 0.2 cubic inches will provide the energy equivalent of approximately 2,000 pounds of coal. There will be no CO2 emission from reactor operation and the volume of waste produced will be on the order of the volume of the fuel pellet.</li><li>You will learn what the real danger of radiation is. You will examine myths and misconceptions about splitting the atom to make energy.</li><li>You will learn that the old alchemist's dream of transferring one element into another is possible with nuclear transmutations.</li></ul><b>What is the format of the class?</b><br><ul><li>The course will be essentially recorded lectures of 10 to 30 minutes with assessment material at the end of each segment. You should expect to spend 4 to 6 hours per week viewing the material, doing extra readings, participating in discussions with fellow students and taking the assessments.</li></ul><b>What about timing?&nbsp; Can I take this self-paced?</b><br><ul><li>Probably not. There will be due dates for each assessment to keep us moving forward together. So you won\u2019t be able to wait until the last week and do all the material in a day or two. We expect that you will be committed to work on the course each week as you would for any other college class.</li></ul><b>Can we contact the professor?</b><br><ul><li>The professor will be nearby and monitoring the course. If problems come up, he will address them in the Announcement section or in the discussion forum. The discussion forum is an important part of the course and much of the learning happens when you interact with other students, so I encourage you to do that.</li></ul>", "category-ids": ["ee", "physics", "chemistry"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "This course will focus on the theory, design and operation of commercial nuclear power reactors. {"about_the_course": "This course will highlight the most interesting experiments within the field of psychology, discussing the implications of those studies for our understanding of the human mind and human behavior. &nbsp;We will explore the brain and some of the cognitive abilities it supports like memory, learning, attention, perception and consciousness. &nbsp;We will examine human development - both in terms of growing up and growing old - and will discuss the manner in which the behavior of others affect our own thoughts and behavior. &nbsp;Finally we will discuss various forms of mental illness and the treatments that are used to help those who suffer from them. &nbsp;<br><br>The fact of the matter is that humans routinely do amazing things without appreciating how interesting they are. &nbsp;However, we are also routinely influenced by people and events without always being aware of those influences. &nbsp;By the end of this course you will have gained a much better understanding and appreciation of who you are and how you work. &nbsp;And I can guarantee you that you'll learn things that you'll be telling your friends and family about, things that will {"about_the_course": "There\u2019s a songwriter lurking somewhere inside you, peeking\naround corners, wondering if it\u2019s safe to come out. Now it is. This course is an\ninvitation to let your inner songwriter step into the sunlight. All it takes is\na simple \u201cyes\u201d and you\u2019ll be climbing that windy hill, marveling at the view.<br><br>If you haven\u2019t written any or many songs, this course will show you\nan efficient, effective process for tailoring songs to express your ideas and\nemotions. If you have, you\u2019ll look at your process differently, taking control\nof aspects of the process you may have not noticed.<br><br>The course will start by examining the tools available to you, all\nrevolving around the essential concept of <i>prosody</i>. You\u2019ll learn to use your\ntools to enhance your message\u2014to work compositionally at the same time you\u2019re\ndeveloping your ideas.<br><br>You\u2019ll be working both lyrically and musically, though\nmusically it\u2019s not necessary that you either read music or play an instrument.\nIf you play, great, and you\u2019ll be encouraged to play and record your musical\nresponses to the assignments. If you don\u2019t play, the course offers you a number\nof musical loops to work with. All you\u2019ll have to do is sing your melodies over\nthe loops.<br><br>Assignments will ask you to post something for peer review\u2014sometimes lyric lines or sections, sometimes\nmelodies, sometimes both. None of it has to be polished. The course is about writing,\nnot performing.<br><br>Most important, you\u2019ll have a lot of fun.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/f4/b0deaed64e4c56f50bf71385d5bc1d/songwriting-large.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/0c/ec10bb4adb3831a5fbbacf5ad4b47a/songwriting-large.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/24/77aee99d2b34a08a8423bc4a6178e6/songwriting-large.jpg", "video": "X6-5B7IG6zU", "university-ids": ["berklee"], "id": 220, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/10/bb37f439a00f92524143611e504b27/favicon.png", "website_facebook": "", "id": 21, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/c4/885ec60036341f549253081e8784d1/berklee_logo.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "", "primary_color": "#0088CC", "abbr_name": "Berkleemusic", "website": "", "description": "", "short_name": "berklee", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/ce/77a045e73e76620497bd0992177021/masthead.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "", "name": "Berklee College of Music", "square_logo": "", "square_logo_source": "", "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p><b>Lesson 1: The Journey of the Song</b></p><blockquote><p>By the end of this lesson, you will see how to develop your song\nidea so it creates an interesting journey from start to finish. You\u2019ll\nunderstand your options developing the point of view of your song and will be\nintroduced to the songwriter\u2019s six best friends.</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Lesson 2: Stopping and Going</b></p><blockquote><p>By the end of this lesson, you will understand the concept of\nprosody as it relates to the number of lines/musical phrases in a section and\nto line lengths/musical phrases, the school crossing guards of your song. You\u2019ll\ncreate both stable and unstable line/musical groupings, using an odd or even\nnumber of lines and musical phrases. Using these tools, you\u2019ll write a verse\nand chorus.</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p><b>Lesson</b><b> 3: Sonic GPS\u2014Mapping Your Song with Rhyme</b></p><blockquote><p>By the end of this lesson, you will understand the relationship\nof rhyme schemes to prosody. You\u2019ll create both stable and unstable sections,\nusing various rhyme schemes to show your ear the way to go home. Using these\ntools, you\u2019ll write a new verse and chorus.</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Lesson 4: Making It Move<br></b></p><blockquote><p>By the end of this lesson, you will understand language rhythms\u2014the difference between stressed and unstressed syllables and how to put rhythm\nin your lines, preparing them to join into the dance with musical rhythm. Using\nthese tools, you\u2019ll put last week\u2019s verse and chorus to music.</p>\n\n\n\n\n\n</blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p><b>Lesson 5: Writing the Song<br></b></p><blockquote><p> In this\nlesson, you\u2019ll select a new song title and create a worksheet to help develop\nyour ideas. You\u2019ll write your lyric and set it to music, matching your lyric\nrhythms to melodic rhythms. You\u2019ll create a melody, using stable and unstable\nnotes to support your ideas.\n\n\n\n</p></blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p><b>Lesson 6: Crossing the Finished Line</b></p><blockquote><p>By the end of\nthis lesson, you will understand the role of phrasing to create the body\nlanguage of your song, using the relationship of your phrases to musical\ndownbeats to create stability or instability. Then you\u2019ll put the finishing\ntouches on your song from lesson 5.\n\n\n\n</p></blockquote>", "description": "", "short_name": "songwriting", "target_audience": 3, "faq": "<ul><li><b>Do I need to have prior songwriting experience or musical ability?</b></li></ul><blockquote>No. Playing an instrument, such as the guitar or keyboard, is helpful but not necessary.<br></blockquote><ul><li><b>Can I work on my own music?</b></li></ul><blockquote>Absolutely. If you do not have your own music, you will be able to use musical loops supplied in the course.<br></blockquote><ul><li><b>What do I need in order to submit recording assignments?</b></li></ul>\n<blockquote>During the course, you will be asked at times to submit recorded \nexamples of your song ideas. In order to do this, you will need your \ncomputer's built-in microphone or an external microphone plugged \ndirectly into \nyour computer (via built-in ports or an external audio interface), in \naddition to basic audio recording software, such as <a href=\"http://audacity.sourceforge.net/%22\">Audacity</a>, that will allow you to record yourself and save the recording in MP3 \nformat. </blockquote><br>", "category-ids": ["music"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "Learn an efficient, effective process for writing songs that express your ideas and emotions, including a range of tools that revolve around the concept of prosody\u2014the matching of lyrics and music to support your underlying message. {"about_the_course": "An introduction to fundamental data types, algorithms, and data structures,\nwith emphasis on applications and scientific performance analysis of Java\nimplementations. Specific topics covered include: union-find algorithms;\nbasic iterable data types (stack, queues, and bags); sorting algorithms\n(quicksort, mergesort, heapsort) and applications; priority queues; binary\nsearch trees; red-black trees; hash tables; and symbol-table applications.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/algs4partI/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/algs4partI/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/algs4partI/large-icon.png", "video": "gZV5jVF8lJ8", "university-ids": ["princeton"], "id": 26, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "princeton", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d4/29daf4b768e1aa467202d4d2dcf8d8/favicon-princeton.ico", "website_facebook": "PrincetonU", "id": 4, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/94/cc9200e336d38ce029873b13cbe93b/logo-princeton-front.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "", "primary_color": "#BA632D", "abbr_name": "Princeton", "website": "http://www.princeton.edu/", "description": "Princeton University is a private research university located in Princeton, New Jersey, United States. Topics include\n            depth-first search, breadth-first search, topological sort, Kosaraju-Sharir,\n            Kruskal, Prim, Dijkistra, Bellman-Ford, Ford-Fulkerson, LSD radix sort,\n            MSD radix sort, 3-way radix quicksort, multiway tries, ternary search tries,\n            Knuth-Morris-Pratt, Boyer-Moore, Rabin-Karp, &gt;regular expression matching,\n            run-length coding, Huffman coding, LZW compression, and the Burrows-Wheeler\n            transform.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Are there any associated resources available on the web?</strong>\n\n        <p>Yes. Our free<a href=\"http://algs4.cs.princeton.edu\" target=\"_blank\"> booksite</a> contains\n            synopses of the text, web exercises, Java implementations of all the algorithms\n            covered (any many more) that are designed for you to be able to download\n            and use with one click, test data, and many other resources.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>How does this course differ from Design and Analysis of Algorithms?</strong>\n\n        <p>The two courses are complementary. This one is essentially a programming\n            course that concentrates on developing code; that one is essentially a\n            math course that concentrates on understanding proofs. This course is about\n            learning algorithms in the context of implementing and testing them in\n            practical applications; that one is about learning algorithms in the context\n            of developing mathematical models that help explain why they are efficient.\n            In typical computer science curriculums, a course like this one is taken\n            by first- and second-year students and a course like that one is taken\n            by juniors and seniors.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>I am/was not a computer science major. Is this course for me?</strong>\n\n        <p>Yes. This course is for anyone using a computer to address large problems\n            (and therefore needing efficient algorithms). At Princeton, over 25% of\n            all students take the course, including people majoring in engineering,\n            biology, physics, chemistry, economics, and many other fields, not just\n            computer science.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>If I have no familiarity with Java programming, can I still take the course?\n        </strong>\n        <p>Our central thesis is that algorithms are best understood by implementing\n            and testing them. Our use of Java is essentially expository, and we shy\n            away from exotic features, so we expect you would be able to adapt our\n            code to your favorite language. However, we require that you submit the\n            programming assignments in Java. If you have some experience programming\n            in another language, you might find it worthwhile to learn our programming\n            model by studying our book An Introduction to Programming in Java: An Interdisciplinary\n            Approach and associated free <a href=\"http://introcs.cs.princeton.edu\" target=\"_blank\">booksite</a>.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>If I have not programmed before, can I still take the course?\n        </strong>\n        <p>Probably not.</p>\n        <p></p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Does Princeton University award credentials or reports regarding my work in this course?</strong>\n     \n        <p>No certificates, statements of accomplishment, or other credentials will\n            be awarded in connection with this course.</p>\n    </li>\n</ul>", "category-ids": ["cs-theory", "cs-programming"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "This course covers the essential information that every serious programmer needs to know about algorithms and data structures, with emphasis on applications and scientific performance analysis of Java implementations. class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"> <br> Robert Sedgewick is the William O. Baker Professor of Computer Science at Princeton, where he was the founding chair of the Department of Computer Science. He received the Ph.D. degree from Stanford University, in 1975. Prof. Sedgewick also served on the faculty at Brown University and has held visiting research positions at Xerox PARC, Palo Alto, CA, Institute for Defense Analyses, Princeton, NJ, and INRIA, Rocquencourt, France. He is a member of the board of directors of Adobe Systems. Prof. Sedgewick's interests are in analytic combinatorics, algorithm design, the scientific analysis of algorithms, curriculum development, and innovations in the dissemination of knowledge. He has published widely in these areas and is the author of several books.<br> <br> <img src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/algs4partI/instructor-2.png\" style=\"width: 150px; float: left; padding: 0 40px 10px 10px;\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"><a href=\"http://www.cs.princeton.edu/~wayne/\">Kevin Wayne</a> is the Phillip Y. Goldman Senior Lecturer in Computer Science at Princeton University, where he has been teaching since 1998. He received a Ph.D. in operations research and industrial engineering from Cornell University. His research interests include the design, analysis, and implementation of algorithms, especially for graphs and discrete optimization. With Robert Sedgewick, he is the coauthor of two highly acclaimed textbooks, Introduction to Programming in Java: An Interdisciplinary Approach (Addison-Wesley, 2008) and Algorithms, 4th Edition (Addison-Wesley Professional 2011). For his teaching, he has won the School of Engineering and Applied Science's Distinguished Teacher Award and the Engineering Council's Excellence in Teaching Award.", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/algs4partI/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [104, 970302, 970400], "display": true, "recommended_background": "All you need is a basic familiarity with programming in Java. {"about_the_course": "<p>This\ncourse will introduce the student to contemporary Systems Biology focused on\nmammalian cells, their constituents and their functions.&nbsp; Biology is moving from molecular to modular.\nAs our knowledge of our genome and gene expression deepens and we develop lists\nof molecules (proteins, lipids, ions) involved in cellular processes, we need\nto understand how these molecules interact with each other to form modules that\nact as discrete functional systems.&nbsp;\nThese systems underlie core subcellular processes such as signal\ntransduction, transcription, motility and electrical excitability. In turn\nthese processes come together to exhibit cellular behaviors such as secretion,\nproliferation and action potentials. What are the properties of such subcellular\nand cellular systems?&nbsp;&nbsp; What are the\nmechanisms by which emergent behaviors of systems arise?&nbsp; What types of experiments inform systems-level\nthinking? Why do we need computation and simulations to understand these\nsystems?</p>\n\n<p>The course will develop multiple lines of\nreasoning to answer the questions listed above. Two major reasoning threads\nare: the design, execution and interpretation of multivariable experiments that\nproduce large data sets; quantitative reasoning, models and simulations.&nbsp; Examples will be discussed to demonstrate\n\u201chow\u201d cell- level functions arise and \u201cwhy\u201d mechanistic knowledge allows us to\npredict cellular behaviors leading to disease states and drug responses.<br></p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/f2/189f2000aa98ae02d2d07b2a7afef9/Introduction_SB_logo_460X270_v2.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/73/6cd405d11bc3ff4878da9481bfc4f1/Introduction_SB_logo_460X270_v2.png", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/b9/e9ad4b94d9f77264646f5a07436f5d/Introduction_SB_logo_460X270_v2.png", "video": "", "university-ids": ["mssm"], "id": 178, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "mountsinainyc", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/6e/050cc941c1081a711d979b25b7b108/Course_catalog_page_16x16.png", "website_facebook": "MountSinaiMedicine", "id": 27, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/40/20e4ab932508164766302a9bf01c5c/mount_sinai.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "New York", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 40.7143528, "location": "New York, NY", "primary_color": "#0f487c", "abbr_name": "Mount Sinai", "website": "http://www.mssm.edu/", "description": "The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, formerly the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, is an American medical school in the borough of Manhattan in New York City. {"about_the_course": "A computer program is a set of instructions for a computer to follow, just as a recipe is a set of instructions for a chef. Laptops, kitchen appliances, MP3 players, and many other electronic devices all run computer programs. Programs have been written to manipulate sound and video, write poetry, run banking systems, predict the weather, and analyze athletic performance. This course is intended for people who have never seen a computer program. It will give you a better understanding of how computer applications work and teach you how to write your own applications. More importantly, you&rsquo;ll start to learn computational thinking, which is a fundamental approach to solving real-world problems. Computer programming languages share common fundamental concepts, and this course will introduce you to those concepts using the Python programming language. By the end of this course, you will be able to write your own programs to process data from the web and create interactive text-based games.", "other_description": null, "photo": Her current research projects explore student experiences in introductory computer science courses and the factors that contribute to success. During his time at UofT, Paul has won numerous teaching awards, including UofT&rsquo;s most prestigious teaching award, the President&rsquo;s Teaching Award, and a provincial award, the Ontario Confederation of University Faculty Association&rsquo;s (OCUFA) Teaching Award. &nbsp;In addition to being an outstanding classroom teacher, Paul has also co-authored two textbooks and has been a leader in departmental curriculum design and renewal. &nbsp;His other talents include singing, sword fighting and consuming good scotch.", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/programming1/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [252, 970455], "display": true, "recommended_background": "<p class=\"p1\">This course assumes no particular background.</p>"}
{"about_the_course": "<p>The classical economic theory of markets cannot account for some important issues, such as the coexistence of unemployment and vacancies; credit market rationing; or bubbles and crashes in asset prices. {"about_the_course": "Popularized by movies such as \"A Beautiful Mind\", game theory is the mathematical modeling of strategic interaction among rational (and irrational) agents. Beyond what we call 'games' in common language, such as chess, poker, soccer, etc., it includes the modeling of conflict among nations, political campaigns, competition among firms, and trading behavior in markets such as the NYSE. How could you begin to model eBay, Google keyword auctions, and peer to peer file-sharing networks, without accounting for the incentives of the people using them? The course will provide the basics: representing games and strategies, the extensive form (which computer scientists call game trees), Bayesian games (modeling things like auctions), repeated and stochastic games, and more. We'll include a variety of examples including classic games and real-world applications.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/gametheory/large-icon.png", "square_logo_svg": null}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p><b>Week 1. Introduction:</b>&nbsp; Introduction, overview, uses of game theory,\nsome applications and examples, and formal definitions of: the normal form,\npayoffs, strategies, pure strategy Nash equilibrium, dominated strategies.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 2. Mixed-strategy\nNash equilibria:</b> Definitions, examples, real-world evidence.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 3. Alternate\nsolution concepts: </b>iterative removal of strictly dominated strategies,\nminimax strategies and the minimax theorem for zero-sum game, correlated equilibria.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 4.\nExtensive-form games:</b> Perfect information games: trees, players assigned to\nnodes, payoffs, backward Induction, subgame perfect equilibrium, introduction\nto imperfect-information games, mixed versus behavioral strategies.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 5. Repeated\ngames:</b> Repeated prisoners dilemma, finite and infinite repeated games,\nlimited-average versus future-discounted reward, folk theorems, stochastic\ngames and learning.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 6. Coalitional games:\n</b>Transferable utility cooperative games, Shapley value, Core, applications.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 7. Bayesian\ngames: </b>General definitions, ex ante/interim Bayesian Nash equilibrium.</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "gametheory", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Will I get a statement of accomplishment after completing this class?</strong>\n<p>Yes. You may watch the lecture videos at your convenience. Lower-resolution videos are also available for those with slow internet connections.<br></li><li><b>\nSlides.&nbsp;</b> We have made available pdf files of all the lecture slides.<br></li><li><b>\nQuizzes.&nbsp; </b>There will be non-graded short \"quiz\" questions that will follow some of the videos to help you gauge your understanding.</li><li>\n<b>Online Lab Exercises&nbsp; </b>After some of the videos, we will ask you\n to go online to play some games.  These are entirely optional, and are designed to illustrate some of the concepts from the course.</li><li><b>\nProblem Sets.&nbsp; </b>There will also be graded weekly problem\n sets that you will also answer online, but may work through offline; \nthose must be completed within two weeks of the time that they are \nposted in order to be graded for full credit.  If you miss a problem set\n deadline, you may complete it before the end of the course for half \ncredit.  You may discuss problems from the problem sets with other \nstudents in an online forum, without providing explicit answers.</li><li><b>\nFinal Exam.&nbsp; </b>There will be an online final exam that you will \nhave to complete within two weeks of its posting.  Once you begin the \nexam, you will have four hours to complete it.  </li><li><b>\nScreen-side Chats.&nbsp;  </b>Each week on Thursday (Pacific time; Friday\n in some parts of the world) we will hold a brief online chat where we \nanswer&nbsp; questions and discuss topics relevant to the course.</li></ul>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": "https://www.coursera.org/course/gametheory", "suggested_readings": "The following \nbackground readings provide more detailed coverage of the course \nmaterial:<ul><li><a href=\"http://www.morganclaypool.com/doi/abs/10.2200/S00108ED1V01Y200802AIM003\">Essentials of Game Theory</a>, by Kevin Leyton-Brown \nand Yoav Shoham; Morgan and Claypool Publishers, 2008. Jackson</a> is the William D. Eberle Professor of Economics at Stanford University and an external faculty member of the Santa Fe Institute and a fellow of CIFAR. Jackson's research interests include game theory, microeconomic theory, and the study of social and economic networks, on which he has published many articles and the book Social and Economic Networks. Jackson is a Fellow of the Econometric Society and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and his honors include the Social Choice and Welfare Prize, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and the B.E.Press Arrow Prize for Senior Economists. He has served as co-editor of Games and Economic Behavior, the Review of Economic Design, and Econometrica.<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br></p>\n\n<p><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/a9/0d3f51f7dd30b86881074d6b22dd2e/Kevin-Leyton-Brown14-square-150.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"><a href=\"http://cs.ubc.ca/~kevinlb\" target=\"_blank\">Kevin Leyton-Brown</a> is an Associate Professor of Computer Science at the University of British Columbia, where he has been since receiving his PhD from Stanford University in 2003. He works at the intersection of computer science and microeconomics, addressing computational problems in economic contexts and incentive issues in multiagent systems. He also studies the application of machine learning to the automated design and analysis of algorithms for solving hard computational problems. With coauthors, he has received numerous paper awards (JAIR, ACM-EC, AAMAS and LION) and medals in international SAT competitions (2003-12). He was program chair for the ACM Conference on Electronic Commerce in 2012, and serves as an associate editor for the Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research, the Artificial Intelligence Journal, and ACM Transactions on Economics and Computation.<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br></p>\n\n<p><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/61/118e18f0a95bb279a476eb92ca9f6f/Yoav-cropped.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"><a href=\"http://robotics.stanford.edu/~shoham/\" target=\"_blank\">Yoav Shoham</a> received his PhD in computer science from Yale University in 1987, and has been a Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University since then. His research interests include logic-based knowledge representation, game theory, and electronic commerce. He has published numerous articles in these areas, and five books. The last one, Essentials of Game Theory (co-written with K. Leyton-Brown), covers the material in this course. Prof. Shoham has also founded several successful internet companies.<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;<br></p>\n\n<div class=\"coursera-course-faq\"></div>", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/gametheory/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [46, 86, 970449], "display": true, "recommended_background": "You must be comfortable with mathematical thinking and rigorous \narguments. Relatively little specific math is required; the course \ninvolves lightweight probability theory (for example, you should know \nwhat a conditional probability is) and very lightweight calculus (for \ninstance, taking a derivative).<br>"}
{"about_the_course": "Hamburger or hummus? Organic or conventional? Mediterranean&nbsp;diet or&nbsp;McDonald's? What dietary choices are truly the most sustainable when&nbsp;we consider that what we eat affects not just our health but also the&nbsp;environment and the well-being of others?<br><br>This course will provide you with an overview of our world\u2019s&nbsp;food system&nbsp;and its many impacts from the individual to the global scale. You&nbsp;will&nbsp;gain further appreciation of the complex implications of&nbsp;choices that are made&nbsp;along the food&nbsp;supply chain. You&nbsp;will be challenged to think critically about how the&nbsp;global food system may&nbsp;need to change to adapt to future economic&nbsp;and environmental conditions.<br><br>Our world\u2019s population is projected to grow both in numbers and in wealth in the coming decades. Meeting future food demand, and doing so in a sustainable fashion, will require that we greatly increase the amount&nbsp;we produce and improve the efficiency by which it makes it to our tables.&nbsp;Join us as we explore today\u2019s global food system and how we might improve its sustainability for our benefit and that of future generations.<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/7e/1ceb4e281dfe038babae68d58d5571/large.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/72/020dd47bdf806d546cd7d9553fa18f/large.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/44/e431f018d3e315b325966667622c56/large.jpg", "video": "oXEePhCcr9g", "university-ids": ["minnesota"], "id": 383, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "UMNews", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f2/c0c3766390def44d6704f82d4d7955/favicon.ico", "website_facebook": "UofMN", "id": 50, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Minneapolis", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 44.983334, "location": "Minneapolis, MN, USA", "primary_color": "#7A0019", "abbr_name": "Minnesota", "website": "http://www.umn.edu/", "description": "The University of Minnesota is among the largest public research universities in the country, offering undergraduate, graduate, and professional students a multitude of opportunities for study and research. {"about_the_course": "<p>Our course demonstrates how a new scholarship of discovery is redefining\n    what is singular about modern China and modern Chinese history. The current\n    understanding of human history and social theory is based largely on Western\n    experience or on non-Western experience seen through a Western lens. This\n    course offers alternative perspectives derived from Chinese experience\n    during the last three centuries. We present specific case studies of the\n    new scholarship of discovery divided into three independent parts, which\n    means that students can take any part without prior or subsequent attendance\n    of the other parts.Part 1 addresses the issue of \u201cWho Gets What\u201d and covers\n    sequentially inequality and education, education and social mobility, social\n    mobility and wealth distribution, wealth distribution and regime change,\n    and regime change and inequality. Part 2 turns to the related issue of\n    \u201cWho Survives\u201d and includes studies of inequality and population behavior,\n    population behavior and human development, human development and social\n    organization, and social organization and social stratification. Part 3\n    deals with issues of identification and motivation and presents studies\n    of religion and gender, ethnicity, and nationalism from late imperial times\n    to the present-day.</p>\n<p>Our class, in other words, eschews the standard chronological narrative\n    arc for an analytic approach that focuses on specific discoveries and on\n    how these new facts complicate our understanding of comparative societies,\n    human behavior, and the construction of individual and group identities.\n    That being said, while we do not emphasize the temporal narratives of late\n    imperial, early modern and contemporary China, we of course also discuss\n    change over time as China progresses from a largely domestic imperial history\n    to the shared stories of imperialism and semi colonialism, communism and\n    collectivization, and reform and globalization.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": {"about_the_course": "<p>Natural language processing (NLP) deals with the application of computational models to text or speech data. Application areas within NLP include automatic (machine) translation between languages; dialogue systems, which allow a human to interact with a machine using natural language; and information extraction, where the goal is to transform unstructured text into structured (database) representations that can be searched and browsed in flexible ways. NLP technologies are having a dramatic impact on the way people interact with computers, on the way people interact with each other through the use of language, and on the way people access the vast amount of linguistic data now in electronic form. From a scientific viewpoint, NLP involves fundamental questions of how to structure formal models (for example statistical models) of natural language phenomena, and of how to design algorithms that implement these models.</p>\n\n<p>In this course you will study mathematical and computational models of language, and the application of these models to key problems in natural language processing. The course has a focus on machine learning methods, which are widely used in modern NLP systems: we will cover formalisms such as hidden Markov models, probabilistic context-free grammars, log-linear models, and statistical models for machine translation. The curriculum closely follows a course currently taught by Professor Collins at Columbia University, and previously taught at MIT.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/26/761dfb7b58773c88fe4cb2aed26a3c/iStock_000020359734_Small.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/c5/42ab154bbf6f76f51b74b8347deab5/iStock_000020359734_Small.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/7e/0150790f6c92c48d03bf6178ea9193/iStock_000020359734_Small.jpg", "video": "", "university-ids": ["columbia"], "id": 225, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "GradSEAS", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/72/c9b56e3ff66fa6e1ca52bdea9440ae/ColumbialittleLOGO4.png", "website_facebook": "ColumbiaEngineering?fref=ts", "id": 40, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/9b/42f2eca2f10769400d1f8519892413/ColumbiaLOGO.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "New York", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 40.7143528, "location": "New York City, NY, USA", "primary_color": "#1f2f60", "abbr_name": "Columbia", "website": "", "description": "", "short_name": "columbia", "location_state": "NY", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/0d/6b60ecae321cd9d6e02b5a1376e7cb/columbia-banner.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "", "name": "Columbia University", "square_logo": "", "square_logo_source": "", "display": true, "location_lng": -74.0059731, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/8e/592ba6a9789657a5a0912204491332/logo_cu_background_trans.png", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "Topics covered include:\n\n<p>\n1.
