They require calculus as a\nprerequisite. In this course, the goal is to instill <i>the economic&nbsp;</i><i>way of thinking </i>about\nbusiness. Little math is used in the lectures (and Professor McKenzie's\ntextbook to which the lectures are tied), but that does not mean the analysis\nwill not be sophisticated, challenging, and rewarding. &nbsp;Indeed, on\nfinishing this course,&nbsp;students will be impressed with how challenging\nand sophisticated business decisions can be and how useful the economic\nway of thinking can be in understanding business problems&nbsp;and in guiding\nbusiness decisions.\n<br>"}
{"about_the_course": "Paper or plastic?&nbsp; Hybrid or conventional vehicles?&nbsp; Which is\nbetter for the environment?&nbsp; To answer these questions, one must take\na holistic systems view using a quantitative approach known as life cycle\nassessment.\n<br>\n<br>Life cycle assessment (LCA) is a fundamental method for assessing the\nenvironmental impacts of products and technologies from a \"cradle to grave\"\nsystems perspective.&nbsp; It is an essential tool for anyone who performs\nenvironmental analyses or uses the results of such analyses for decision\nmaking.&nbsp;\n<br>\n<br>The course will provide an introduction to LCA methods and applications.&nbsp;\nStudents taking this course will emerge with a solid understanding of why\nan LCA systems perspective is important, basic skills for sound application\nof the LCA method and proper interpretation of its results, and an appreciation\nfor the strengths and limitations of LCA in practice.&nbsp; The course\nwill cover the four major steps in LCA: (1) goal definition and scope;\n(2) life-cycle inventory compilation; (3) life-cycle impact assessment;\nand (4) interpretation and management.&nbsp; The course will include a\nhands-on modeling project, which the students will perform in parallel\nto the lectures to reinforce learning objectives and to gain experience\nin LCA application.\n<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/15/7647feef7d1807f638f6dfddf2a2c2/tree-logo-600x340.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/29/7f2aa812cc8b3fe20ddf1a7d4fd139/tree-logo-600x340.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/57/47b01348dd0747aae23180b3d6a8cf/tree-logo-600x340.jpg", "video": "", "university-ids": ["northwestern"], "id": 477, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "NorthwesternU", "favicon": "", "website_facebook": "NorthwesternU", "id": 54, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Evanston", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 42.0411414, "location": "Evanston, IL", "primary_color": "#480058", "abbr_name": "Northwestern", "website": "http://www.northwestern.edu/", "description": "Founded in 1851, Northwestern University is a private research and teaching university with an enrollment of approximately 8,000 full-time undergraduate students, 8,000 full-time graduate and professional students, and 2,000 part-time students on campuses in Evanston and Chicago, Illinois, and Doha, Qatar. {"about_the_course": "<p>Digital images and videos are everywhere these days \u2013 in thousands of\nscientific (e.g., astronomical, bio-medical), consumer, industrial, and\nartistic applications. Moreover they come in a wide range of the\nelectromagnetic spectrum - from visible light and infrared to gamma rays and\nbeyond. The ability to process image and video signals is therefore an\nincredibly important skill to master for engineering/science students, software\ndevelopers, and practicing scientists.&nbsp;&nbsp;\nDigital image and video processing continues to enable the multimedia\ntechnology revolution we are experiencing today. Some important examples of\nimage and video processing include the removal of degradations images suffer\nduring acquisition (e.g., removing blur from a picture of a fast moving car),\nand the compression and transmission of images and videos (if you watch videos\nonline, or share photos via a social media website, you use this everyday!),\nfor economical storage and efficient transmission.&nbsp;</p>\n\nThis course will cover the fundamentals of image and video processing.&nbsp; We will provide a mathematical framework to describe and analyze images and videos as two- and three-dimensional signals in the spatial, spatio-temporal, and frequency domains. In this class not only will you learn the theory behind fundamental processing tasks including image/video enhancement, recovery, and compression - but you will also learn how to perform these key processing tasks in practice using state-of-the-art techniques and tools. We will introduce and use a wide variety of such tools \u2013 from optimization toolboxes to statistical techniques. Emphasis on the special role sparsity plays in modern image and video processing will also be given.&nbsp; In all cases, example images and videos pertaining to specific application domains will be utilized.<br><br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/3e/8166be0abcc2a8803d91b7aa55135c/logo_aggelos.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/bf/d1a80b022b8abf215d1f977c071c2f/logo_aggelos.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/6d/c49bbac1cbaecf9a2ff557e517634c/logo_aggelos.jpg", "video": "", "university-ids": ["northwestern"], "id": 485, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "NorthwesternU", "favicon": "", "website_facebook": "NorthwesternU", "id": 54, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Evanston", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 42.0411414, "location": "Evanston, IL", "primary_color": "#480058", "abbr_name": "Northwestern", "website": "http://www.northwestern.edu/", "description": "Founded in 1851, Northwestern University is a private research and teaching university with an enrollment of approximately 8,000 full-time undergraduate students, 8,000 full-time graduate and professional students, and 2,000 part-time students on campuses in Evanston and Chicago, Illinois, and Doha, Qatar. "<ul><li>Introduction,\nImage and Video Processing vs Image and Video Analysis vs Computer Vision, the\nelectromagnetic spectrum, applications of image and video processing</li><li>2D and 3D\nsignals and systems, linear and shift invariant systems (convolution)</li><li>2D and 3D\nFourier transform, 2D and 3D discrete-Fourier transform, uniform sampling\n(rectangular, arbitrary {"about_the_course": "In this course, you will learn how to design technologies that bring people\njoy, rather than frustration. You'll learn several techniques for rapidly\nprototyping and evaluating multiple interface alternatives -- and why rapid\nprototyping and comparative evaluation are essential to excellent interaction\ndesign. You'll learn how to conduct fieldwork with people to help you get\ndesign ideas. How to make paper prototypes and low-fidelity mock-ups that\nare interactive -- and how to use these designs to get feedback from other\nstakeholders like your teammates, clients, and users. You'll learn principles\nof visual design so that you can effectively organize and present information\nwith your interfaces. You'll learn principles of perception and cognition\nthat inform effective interaction design. And you'll learn how to perform\nand analyze controlled experiments online. In many cases, we'll use Web\ndesign as the anchoring domain. A lot of the examples will come from the\nWeb, and we'll talk just a bit about Web technologies in particular. When\nwe do so, it will be to support the main goal of this course, which is\nhelping you build human-centered design skills, so that you have the principles\nand methods to create excellent "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "", "description": "", "short_name": "hci", "target_audience": null, "faq": "<ol>\n    <li><strong>What is the format of the class?</strong>\n\n        <p>The class will consist of lecture videos, which are broken into small\n            chunks, usually between eight and twelve minutes each. Some of these may\n            contain integrated quiz questions. There will also be standalone quizzes\n            that are not part of video lectures. There will be approximately two hours\n            worth of video content per week.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Will the text of the lectures be available?</strong>\n\n        <p>Your fellow classmates have contributed subtitles of lecture content in\n            a number of languages. We encourage you to contribute captions as well!</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Do I need to submit assignments in English?</strong>\n\n        <p>We are excited to announce a brand-new Spanish language option. Students\n            can submit assignments in Spanish, as well as perform and receive assessment\n            from the Spanish-language pool. In addition, some materials will be translated\n            into Spanish, though most will remain in English.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>How are assignments graded?</strong>\n\n        <p>Each assignment is peer graded -- you'll spend some time for each assignment\n            grading others' work.&nbsp;As a result, other students in the class will\n            also&nbsp;be viewing your work. The peer grading process is anonymous.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Do I need to watch the lectures live?</strong>\n\n        <p>No. You can watch the lectures at your leisure.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Can online students ask questions and/or contact the professor?</strong>\n\n        <p>Yes, but not directly. There is a Q&amp;A forum in which students rank\n            questions and answers, so that the most important questions and the best\n            answers bubble to the top. Teaching staff will monitor these forums, so\n            that important questions not answered by other students can be addressed.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Will other Stanford resources be available to online students?</strong>\n\n        <p>No.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>How much programming background is needed for the course?</strong>\n\n        <p>None.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Are there any prerequisites for the course?</strong>\n\n        <p>No.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Do I need to buy a textbook for the course?</strong>\n\n        <p>No.</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>How much does it cost to take the course?</strong>\n\n        <p>Nothing: it's free!</p>\n    </li>\n    <li><strong>Will I get a statement of accomplishment after completing this class?</strong>\n\n        <p>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a statement\n            of accomplishment signed by the instructor.</p>\n        <p>There are three&nbsp;tracks of certificates&nbsp;for this class. He co-directs the Human-Computer Interaction Group and holds the Bredt Faculty Scholar development chair. Organizations around the world use his lab's open-source design tools and curricula; several books and popular press articles have covered his research and teaching. He has been awarded the Katayanagi Emerging Leadership Prize, Sloan Fellowship, NSF CAREER award, Microsoft Research New Faculty Fellowship, and several best paper awards at the premier HCI conferences (CHI and UIST). His former PhD students are leaders at top universities, research organizations, in Silicon Valley, and social entrepeneurship. He has a dual BA in Art-Semiotics and Computer Science from Brown University, Graphic Design work at RISD, and an MS and PhD in Computer Science from UC Berkeley. {"about_the_course": "<p>This course will discuss the major ideas used today in the implementation of programming language compilers, including lexical analysis, parsing, syntax-directed translation, abstract syntax trees, types and type checking, intermediate languages, dataflow analysis, program optimization, code generation, and runtime systems. As a result, you will learn how a program written in a high-level language designed for humans is systematically translated into a program written in low-level assembly more suited to machines. Along the way we will also touch on how programming languages are designed, programming language semantics, and why there are so many different kinds of programming languages.</p>\n<p>The course lectures will be presented in short videos. To help you master the material, there will be in-lecture questions to answer, quizzes, and two exams: a midterm and a final. There will also be homework in the form of exercises that ask you to show a sequence of logical steps needed to derive a specific result, such as the sequence of steps a type checker would perform to type check a piece of code, or the sequence of steps a parser would perform to parse an input string. This checking technology is the result of ongoing research at Stanford into developing innovative tools for education, and we're excited to be the first course ever to make it available to students.</p>\nAn optional course project is to write a complete compiler for COOL, the Classroom Object Oriented Language. COOL has the essential features of a realistic programming language, but is small and simple enough that it can be implemented in a few thousand lines of code. Students who choose to do the project can implement it in either C++ or Java.<br>I hope you enjoy the course!\n<p><strong>Why Study Compilers?</strong></p>\nEverything that computers do is the result of some program, and all of the millions of programs in the world are written in one of the many thousands of programming languages that have been developed over the last 60 years. Designing and implementing a programming language turns out to be difficult; some of the best minds in computer science have thought about the problems involved and contributed beautiful and deep results. Learning something about compilers will show you the interplay of theory and practice in computer science, especially how powerful general ideas combined with engineering insight can lead to practical solutions to very hard problems. Knowing how a compiler works will also make you a better programmer and increase your ability to learn new programming languages quickly.\n<div></div>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/compilers/large-icon.png", "preview_link": "https://class.coursera.org/compilers//lecture/preview", "small_icon_hover": "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "", "description": "", "short_name": "compilers", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Will I get a statement of accomplishment after completing this class?</strong>\n<p>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a statement of accomplishment signed by the instructor.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>How is the class structured?</strong>\n<p>Each week there will be a number of videos to watch, most of which will include an in-video quiz question to answer. Most weeks there will also be homeworks (done on-line) and a quiz. There will be also be a midterm and a final exam. For those doing the course project, there will be 5 programming assignments, which you will do on your own using infrastructure that we provide.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Are the lectures available in a file format?</strong>\n<p>Yes. The slides from the lectures will be available in both annotated and unannotated form.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Do I need a textbook?</strong>\n<p>No, no textbook is required for the class. However, you may find a textbook useful as a reference or to learn more details of some of the ideas discussed in the course. There are a number of good textbooks on compilers; here are three in particular:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools (Second Edition)<br>Alfred Aho, Monica Lam, Ravi Sethi, and Jeffrey Ullman.<br>Addison-Wesley</li>\n<li>Modern Compiler Implementation in Java (Second Edition)<br>Andrew Appel and Jens Palsberg.<br>Cambridge University Press</li>\n<li>Engineering a Compiler<br>Keith Cooper and Linda Torczon<br>Morgan Kaufman</li>\n</ol></li>\n<li><strong>How do I ask questions?</strong>\n<p>There will be an on-line discussion forum in which students can ask questions and receive answers. While the scale of an on-line class means that often the fastest (and best!) answer comes from another student, the course staff will monitor the discussions for accuracy and to address questions where the student community particularly wants to hear from the staff.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Is the compiler project required?</strong>\n<p>No. You can take the class without doing the programming assignments.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>How difficult is the compiler project? What background and tools do I need?</strong>\n<p>This question is very hard to answer as the level of difficulty will vary depending on your programming background. As a rough guide, you should already be an experienced programmer and be comfortable writing substantial C++ or Java programs; writing a compiler is not a good way to learn either programming or these particular languages. The project also makes use of software tools, so you should also be comfortable learning to use new tools on your own. It is not a problem if you start the project but don't finish it; we will just consider you to be enrolled in the non-project option of the class in this case.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>", "category-ids": ["cs-systems", "cs-programming"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "This course will discuss the major ideas used today in the implementation of programming language compilers. "signature_track_close_time": null}], "about_the_instructor": "<p><img src=\"http://theory.stanford.edu/~aiken/personal/pictures/aiken2010b.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"> <a href=\"http://theory.stanford.edu/~aiken/\">Alex Aiken </a> is a Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University, where he holds the Alcatel-Lucent Chair. Alex received his Bachelors degree in Computer Science and Music from Bowling Green State University in 1983 and his Ph.D. from Cornell in 1988. Alex was a Research Staff Member at the IBM Almaden Research Center (1988-1993) and a Professor in the EECS department at UC Berkeley (1993-2003) before joining Stanford in 2003. He is an ACM Fellow, a recipient of Phi Beta Kappa's Teaching Award, a former National Young Investigator, and has served on a number of corporate advisory boards. Alex's research interests cover a range of topics in programming languages, compilers, and software engineering.</p>", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/compilers/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [76, 150, 378, 970514], "display": true, "recommended_background": ""}
{"about_the_course": "<span>We are Generation Rx. <br><br>As a society, we have become more and more \u201cpharmaceuticalized\u201d. We expect a quick fix for almost any medical problem. We refer to ample amounts of medical information (or mis-information) online, sometimes without the guidance of a health professional. We are taking prescription and over-the-counter medications at unprecedented rates, and there are benefits to this phenomenon, including in many cases, improved disease treatment. Sadly, a darker consequence has also emerged: the epidemic rise of injuries and fatalities due to prescription drug abuse. <br><br>This course uses science to investigate the prevalence, dangers, and misperceptions regarding this growing health problem. Using a myth-busting design, we will investigate the biology behind both therapeutic and illicit drug action and tie that biology to the real dangers of abusing prescription drugs. Additionally, we will explore societal influences on drug-taking behaviors and identify best medication-taking practices for our benefit as well as others\u2019.</span>", "other_description": "", {"about_the_course": "<p>This course will look into the process of creating live\nsite-specific choreography/performance works from conception, production to\nperformance. Site-specific dance/performance is work created in response to a\nparticular place, site, inspired by its architecture/design, the history and\ncurrent use. We will investigate&nbsp;urban, architectural and\nenvironmental inspired site projects ranging from large-scale to small\n(guerrilla) style productions. We will&nbsp;delineate definitions of\nsite-specificity, and&nbsp;look across the history of the field, focusing primarily on\ndance.<br></p>\n\n<p>Specific techniques and approaches towards generating site\ninspired choreography, developed over the last 25 years by site artist Stephan\nKoplowitz will be introduced. Aspects of navigating technical issues (lighting,\nsound, media) including a primer on producing (budgeting, obtaining\npermissions, insurance, fundraising, audience/event design) will&nbsp;also&nbsp;be\ncovered.&nbsp;</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/22/e70475751f77332297c6f8fe15bff4/Koplowitzsitedance.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/0c/f8398653f338b7a131f88627dfa730/Koplowitzsitedance.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/f2/b383caa9257d2ff02851f02a645882/Koplowitzsitedance.jpg", "video": "", "university-ids": ["calarts"], "id": 442, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "calarts", "favicon": "", "website_facebook": "calarts", "id": 59, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Santa Clarita", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 34.3898162, "location": "Valencia, Santa Clarita, CA", "primary_color": "0090D0", "abbr_name": "CalArts", "website": "http://calarts.edu/", "description": "The California Institute of the Arts (CalArts) has earned an international reputation as the leading college of the visual and performing arts in the United States, and was recently ranked as America\u2019s top college for students in the arts by Newsweek/The Daily Beast. A look at the range of site work and how environment,\nspace and intention influences the artist\u2019s and audience\u2019s experience.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 2:\nStarting the Process</b></p>\n\n<p>Overview of\nthe production process and the first creative decisions: selecting a site,\ndesigning the event, creating a budget, getting permissions, everything that\nneeds to be done before you start your first rehearsal.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 3:\nWorking from the Outside In: Conception and Creative Planning:</b></p>\n\n<p>Elements\nthat influence creation: site/physical inventory, history, current use and\ncurrent perceptions.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 4:\nCreating Content</b></p>\n\n<p>Methods of\ngenerating content inspired by the site: creating a specific movement\nvocabulary, text, visuals, and sound.</p>\n\n<p><b>Week 5:</b><span> <b>Creative and Production Challenges</b></span></p>\n\n<p>Working on\nsite and off site; finding the right balance. A look at issues when making work\nfor urban and natural environments: site adaptive vs. site specific; working\nwith collaborators (composers, costume, lighting, media and sound designers);\nfinding the right method of promoting and marketing your site performance; and\ndocumentation, a brief over-view of options with video and still photography.</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "sitedance", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<p><b>Will I get a\nStatement of Accomplishment after completing this class?</b></p>\n\n<p>Yes. {"about_the_course": "<p>This course\nwill develop students\u2019 abilities to understand Latin American culture at both\nthe national and regional levels. It has developed into a body of law which has\nevolved through the development of case law. </p>\n\n <li><b>Will\n     this cover other jurisdictions?</b></li>\n\n<p>English Common Law\nunderpins the law in many Commonwealth jurisdictions which in turn have\ncontributed to the evolution of the common law.</p>\n\n <li><b>Will\n     this course count towards the study of a qualifying law degree?</b></li>\n\n<p>No. Most\njurisdictions will have their own rules regarding what is required to qualify\nas a solicitor or a barrister and you should refer to the appropriate bodies in\nthe country where you wish to practice.</p>\n\n <li><b>Where can I find out about\n     more information regarding this subject and the University of London\n     programmes?</b></li>\n\n<p>The content of this course is\ndrawn from the extensive world renowned portfolio of flexible study programmes\noffered through the University of London International Programmes.&nbsp; These\nprogrammes result from a collaboration between the University of London International\nAcademy and 12 Colleges of the University of London. &nbsp;Established in 1858,\nthe International Programmes is the world\u2019s oldest provider of flexible\nlearning. {"about_the_course": "<p>In this class we will cover the essentials of genomics to help you better\nunderstand your own life (know thy genome, know thyself), and how advances in\nbiotechnology are radically changing the scientific landscape.</p>\n\n<p>We will begin with some of the most basic issues\nof genetics, such as the composition of genomes and how the information in them\nis processed so we can get an adult human from an egg. Then we\u2019ll see that much\nof the power of genomics is in comparisons. If I only had your genome there's\nnot much I could do with it. But if I lined it up against a chimpanzee genome\nI\u2019d see that they are 98.5% identical. It\u2019s that 1.5% difference that we study to\ndetermine what makes a chimp a chimp and a human a human.&nbsp; </p>\n\n<p>In the next few years you\u2019ll be able\nto get your genome done for a few hundred dollars, and we will look at the\nchallenges you might face dealing with this new self-knowledge. We shall\nparticularly focus on behavior. How can genes predispose some of us to be nice\nand others of us to be psychopaths? We will be examining behavior as a complex\nunfolding of interactions between your genome and the environment. </p>\n\nThanks in large part to genomics we are\nbeginning to understand the living processes that constitute ourselves, where\nwe can begin to intervene to take control of our own future. We will look at\nthe technologies involved and the consequences of this new power. Genetic\nengineering has already changed what you eat and the medicines you take, and will\nlikely therefore change how long you live. If we choose to genetically engineer\nourselves as some advocate then we may also change how we view ourselves as\nhuman beings. We do not know where our ability to intervene in our own living\nprocesses is going to lead us. Depending on your point of view that is the\npromise or the threat of the era we live in. Scientists today already envisage\ncreating life from scratch, and we are entering a world where political considerations,\nand imagination, may be the only brakes on biotechnology.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/9d/700b2427e5b2413b3baa34c4287dcd/Genes.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/47/dbc72025125b1fcf426aedc02be1b4/Genes.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/a1/136c177d13b81a589adeb2bcd6f994/Genes.jpg", "video": "fbRSkMVb_Ek", "university-ids": ["umd"], "id": 295, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "UofMaryland", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/98/81bc9a607b97fadd8a2fdd6b66bfc2/favicon_16x16.ico", "website_facebook": "UnivofMaryland", "id": 32, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/fd/01ba206b961003d2e4eb052d0ceac6/primarylogosm.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "21, Berwyn", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 38.9896967, "location": "College Park, Maryland, USA", "primary_color": "#990000", "abbr_name": "UMD", "website": "http://www.umd.edu/", "description": "The University of Maryland is the state's flagship university and one of the nation's preeminent public research universities. Beyond The Genes, Nature via Nurture, and Epigenetics\n&nbsp;</p>\n\n<p><b>Week\n5.</b> An Introduction to Genetic Engineering and Learning the Lingo &nbsp;</p>\n\n<span><b>Week&nbsp;6.</b> The Future is Now, Biotechnology\nand&nbsp;Final Exam (cumulative)<br></span>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><b>Learning Outcomes</b></p>\n\n<p>Students\nwill be able to describe/demonstrate:</p>\n\n<p><b>I.</b> A\nconceptual and holistic understanding of genetics that includes the major\nquestions arising at the intersection of genetics, genomics and society. The\ncourse will stress human genetics.</p>\n\n<p><b>II.</b> An\nunderstanding of terms, concepts, and approaches used in studying genetics and\ngenomics. As a case study, the course will examine behavioral genetics: James\nWatson likes to say \u201cthe 20th century saw the fusion of genetics and\nbiochemistry, so the 21st century will see the fusion of genetics and\npsychology.\u201d</p>\n\n<p><b>III.</b>\nAn understanding of the power of comparative genomics. {"about_the_course": "<p>This is a survey course in modern world history for\nstudents, beginning or advanced, who wish to better understand how the world\ngot to be the way it is today. In order to understand modern history, a global\nperspective is essential. This is true whether you are interested in economics,\nwarfare, philosophy, politics, or even pop culture. This course can therefore\nbe essential for students in many fields, a base equipping them with tools for\nlifelong learning.&nbsp; </p>\n\n<p>In its current form, the course on Coursera is not offered\nfor college credit. But it is a vital part of the for credit course on this\ntopic being offered at the University of Virginia in the spring semester of\n2013. Both the Coursera and the UVA students will use the same online material as\na common foundation for their different learning experiences.&nbsp; This is the material to survey 'what\nhappened' and the big questions about how to explain so many changes \u2013 some of\nthose questions that start with:&nbsp;\n\"Why?\"&nbsp; (The students in\nthe UVA course then supplement this online material with a lot of additional\nreading, research projects about the histories of particular communities around\nthe world, in-person tutorials and discussions both with me and with their\ngraduate teaching assistants, and examinations.) </p>\n\n<p>It is tempting to think that if we can just understand the\nbig patterns, we don't have to get too caught up in the details. In this\ncourse, though, we care about chronology. We care about individuals. Without some\ncareful attention to sequences of cause and effect, without tracing how big\nchanges come from the choices made by particular people, history can turn into\njust a series of descriptions, a somewhat tiresome recitation of one thing\nafter another. Not this course. So a big part of what we will do is not only\noffer a set of remarkable stories, but also offer you training in how to\nanalyze a situation and&nbsp;how to think about problems of explaining change.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/53/8222e51c172488b83cb9b707f35145/Flag-Globe.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": Then repeat, at your convenience, for the remaining ten or so topics\nof that week. {"about_the_course": "It is hard to imagine living in modern society without participating in or interacting with organizations. The ubiquity and variability of organizations means there is ample room for complexity and confusion in the organizational challenges we regularly face. Through this course, students will consider cases describing various organizational struggles: school systems and politicians attempting to implement education reforms; government administrators dealing with an international crisis; technology firms trying to create a company ethos that sustains worker commitment; and even two universities trying to gain international standing by performing a merger.<br><br> Each case is full of details and complexity. So how do we make sense of organizations and the challenges they face, let alone develop means of managing them in desired directions? While every detail can matter, some matter more than others. This is why we rely on organizational theories -- to focus our attention and draw out relevant features in a sensible way.<br><br>Through this course you will come to see that there is nothing more practical than a good theory. Every week, you\u2019ll learn a different organizational theory, and it will become a lens through which you can interpret concrete organizational situations. Armed with a toolset of theories, you will then be able to systematically identify important features of an organization and the events transforming it \u2013 and use the theories to predict which actions will best redirect the organization in a desired direction.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/organalysis/large-icon.png", "preview_link": "", {"about_the_course": "For students who have long thought about picking up the acoustic or electric guitar, this course will provide an easy-access foundation that will get you playing. When first learning guitar, it is important to have the material presented in stages, in an enjoyable way that allows you to grasp the basics of the instrument and music. The course begins simply with the parts of the guitar, the names of the strings, tuning, and technique\u2014whether finger-style or pick. It then explores the basics of music theory with such topics as scales, triads, power chords, and fingering and shapes.<br><br>At the end of this course, students will understand the structure, parts, and accessories of the instrument, in addition to an understanding of its basic maintenance. Electric guitar players will learn the \noperation of their instrument along with basic options for \namplification, effect pedals, and sounds. Students will also learn to develop correct technique and apply theory concepts to their playing. They will have the foundational knowledge necessary to pursue most intermediate guitar courses. <br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/8f/d4aece023b1764926a3c9adb680b0d/guitar-large.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/ee/e6e3cb2cd2ea22f792fd5126d98f7b/guitar-large.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/65/df272436bfad82debc760cb5c90ce5/guitar-large.jpg", "video": "iUxpwYUlWDc", "university-ids": ["berklee"], "id": 219, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/10/bb37f439a00f92524143611e504b27/favicon.png", "website_facebook": "", "id": 21, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/c4/885ec60036341f549253081e8784d1/berklee_logo.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "", "primary_color": "#0088CC", "abbr_name": "Berkleemusic", "website": "", "description": "", "short_name": "berklee", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/ce/77a045e73e76620497bd0992177021/masthead.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "", "name": "Berklee College of Music", "square_logo": "", "square_logo_source": "", "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<b>Lesson 1: Acoustic or Electric Guitar? {"about_the_course": "Often called \u201cthe cornerstone\u201d of public health, epidemiology is the study\nof the distribution and determinants of health conditions or events among\npopulations and the application of that study to control health problems.\nBy applying the concepts learned in this course to current public health\nproblems and issues, students will&nbsp; understand the practice of epidemiology\nas it relates to real life and makes for a better appreciation of public\nhealth programs and policies. {"about_the_course": "This course investigates how to make mobile robots move in effective, safe, and predictable ways. The basic tool for achieving this is \"control theory\", which deals with the question of how dynamical systems, i.e., systems whose behaviors change over time, can be effectively influenced. In the course, these two domains - controls and robotics - will be interleaved and we will go from the basics of control theory, via robotic examples of increasing complexity - all the way to the research frontier. The course will focus on mobile robots as the target application and problems that will be covered include (1) how to make (teams of) wheeled ground robots avoid collisions while reaching target locations, &nbsp;(2) how to make aerial, quadrotor robots follow paths in the presence of severe disturbances, and (3) how to locomotive bipedal, humanoid robots.", "other_description": "", "photo": Some exposure to differential equations is recommended."}
{"about_the_course": "This course is a survey of ancient Greek history, covering the roughly\n13 centuries that extended from the Minoan / Mycenaean Bronze Age (ca.\n1800-1200 BCE) down to the death of Socrates in 399 BCE.&nbsp; Along with\nstudying the most important events and personalities, we will consider\nbroader issues such as political and cultural values and methods of historical\ninterpretation.\n<br>Some of the topics we will cover include: relations between the Greeks\nand their neighbors to the East; Homer and the heroic ideal; the development\nof the type of community called the \"polis\"; the diffusion of Greek civilization\nfrom Southern Italy to the shores of the Black Sea; gods and mortals in\nmyth, religion and ritual; the roles of women; Athenian drama; the treatment\nof slaves and foreigners; and the birth and evolution of democracy. We\nwill strive to get as full an understanding as we can of this extraordinary,\nand extraordinarily influential, society.\n<br>\n<br>Almost all the reading assignments are from ancient sources in translation.\nNo previous knowledge of ancient history is assumed.\n<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/36/feeefc3aabeeca9639b583f0a6b2f2/ancientgreek.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/c2/a9fe83a156d3fff4e32c6cd9caa0e5/ancientgreek.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/0e/fc442ac5d032b9e36b07b42c97ed8f/ancientgreek.jpg", "video": "2k9VQhMvWd4", "university-ids": ["wesleyan"], "id": 193, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "wesleyan_u", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/03/3d1139223689f57de761dd6783d8c3/6-wesleyan_small_icon.gif", "website_facebook": "wesleyan.university", "id": 34, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/e6/00d8a35e2324a3a5448474f800cbc4/1-wesleyan_logo.gif", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Middletown", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 41.5623209, "location": "Middletown, CT, United States", "primary_color": "#990000", "abbr_name": "Wesleyan", "website": "http://www.wesleyan.edu/", "description": "Wesleyan University is known for the excellence of its academic and co-curricular programs. About 2,900 undergraduates\u2014and some 200 graduate students\u2014from around the world pursue their classroom studies, research projects, and co-curricular interests in ways that are demanding and intensely rewarding. Here, on a beautiful campus overlooking the Connecticut River, students learn to do productive and innovative work that makes a positive difference in the world\u2014that\u2019s what Wesleyan is about.", "short_name": "wesleyan", "location_state": "CT", "website_youtube": "user/Wesleyan", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/04/a9643370f11e2364539b639cf75974/2-wesleyan_banner.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/12/beece90e30364449cdd4853e32f84b/WESLEYAN_banner.jpg", "name": "Wesleyan University", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7b/787ec5fba7ed2cc96d4b830e9e12b3/WESLEYAN_squarelogo.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/81/bbebd7691e781666dd7636eece0771/WESLEYAN_squarelogo.png", "display": true, "location_lng": -72.6506488, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "There follows a complete course outline, with a brief descriptive title\nfor each of the lectures. The list also includes the reading assignments,\nwhich you&nbsp; should try to complete before viewing the lecture. All\nthe assignments can be accessed online.\n<br>\n<br>WEEK 1: Prehistory to Homer\n<br>1.1 Introduction: the natural setting, geography and climate.\n<br>1.2 Minoan civilization (ca. 1800-1500 BCE)\n<br>1.3 Mycenaean civilization (ca. 1500-1150 BCE)\n<br>1.4 The Dark Ages (ca. 1150-800 BCE)\n<br>1.5 Homer 1 -<i> Iliad</i>\n\n<br>Assignment: <i>Iliad</i>, Books 1, 2, 6, 9, 18, 24. As you read these selections,\npay close attention to how the characters interact with each other.\n<br>There are at least four excellent, widely available modern English translations\nof both epics, by (in chronological order) Richmond Lattimore, Robert Fitzgerald,\nRobert Fagles, and Stanley Lombardo.\n<br>Available online is a fine contemporary translation by Ian Johnston \u2013\n<br><a href=\"http://records.viu.ca/~johnstoi/homer/iliad1.htm\">http://records.viu.ca/~johnstoi/homer/iliad1.htm</a>\n\n<br>1.6 Homer 2 -<i> Odyssey<br></i>Assignment: <i>Odyssey</i>, Books 1, 5,\n9-12, 21-24. As you read, think about how this poem is similar to, and\ndifferent from, the<i> Iliad</i>.\n<br>Also available online are: a late-19th-century version by Samuel Butler\n\u2013\n<br><a href=\"http://www.online-literature.com/homer/odyssey/\">http://www.online-literature.com/homer/odyssey/</a> \n<br>and an early-20th-century version by A. T. Taylor \u2013\n<br><a href=\"http://www.theoi.com/Text/HomerOdyssey1.html\">http://www.theoi.com/Text/HomerOdyssey1.html</a>\n\n<br><i></i>\n\n<br>WEEK 2: The Archaic Age (ca. 800-500 BCE)\n<br>2.1 The polis.\n<br>Assignment: read the following selection from Book 1 of Aristotle's <i>Politics</i><i></i>:\n<br><a href=\"http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/ancient/Aristotle-politics-polis.asp\">http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/ancient/Aristotle-politics-polis.asp</a>\n\n<br>What are the main elements in Aristotle's definition of the <i>polis</i>?\n<br>Also read: these selections from Plutarch's <i><a href=\"http://demo.fragmentarytexts.org/en/plutarch/plutarch-theseus-24-28-perrin-english.html\">Life of Theseus</a></i>,\nand think about how the myth of Theseus serves as a kind of retrospective\nstory about the foundation of the Athenian <i>polis</i>.\n<br>2.2 \"The Greeks overseas\": colonization.\n<br>Assignment: examine this interactive <a href=\"http://learningobjects.wesleyan.edu/greek_colonies/\">map</a> [created\nat Wesleyan] for a vivid overview of the colonial enterprise; as you click\nthe boxes along the bottom of the map, you will see how many Greek communities\nwere established between the 8th and 6th centuries BCE. You can also click\non the names of several of the colonies for links to additional information.&nbsp;\n<br>Also read: a selection from <a href=\"http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/ancient/630cyrene.asp\">Herodotus, Bk. 4&nbsp; </a>for\nthe story of the foundation of Cyrene in North Africa (in modern Libya).\n<br>2.3 Literacy, lawgivers and law codes.\n<br>Assignment: read Plutarch's <a href=\"http://mkatz.web.wesleyan.edu/Images2/cciv243.Solon.html\">Life of Solon</a>,\nchapters 1-16; also read some of Solon's <a href=\"http://www.classicalideals.com/Solon%20Poetry.htm\">poetry</a>,\nin particular # 4, 5, 6, 7, 9 and 36.\n<br>2.4 The works of Ares \u2013 hoplite warfare.\n<br>Assignment: read the excellent short <a href=\"http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/gwar/hd_gwar.htm\">essay</a> on\nhoplite warfare produced by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.\n<br>2.5 New voices, the lyric poets.\n<br>Assignment: read some selections from\n<br><a href=\"http://www.abettergreece.com/Archilochus%20poetry.html\">Archilochus</a>\n\n<br><a href=\"http://www.poemhunter.com/poem/fragments-lines-0001-0004/\">Theognis</a> [there\nare 20 short sections; you have to click on \"next poem\" to get from one\nto another]\n<br><a href=\"http://www.poetryintranslation.com/PITBR/Greek/Sappho.htm\">Sappho</a>\n\n<br><a href=\"http://mkatz.web.wesleyan.edu/Images2/cciv243.Alcaeus.html\">Alcaeus</a>\n\n<br>\n<a href=\"http://www.poetryintranslation.com/PITBR/Greek/Sappho.htm\"></a>2.6 Hesiod: gods and farmers.\n<br>Assignment: read Hesiod's <a href=\"http://www.msu.edu/~tyrrell/theogon.pdf\"><i>Theogony</i></a> [This\nis a pdf file, for which you will need Adobe Reader; if you don't have\nAdobe, you can read an older but good version <a href=\"http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/hesiod/theogony.htm\">here</a>.]\nAlso read Hesiod's <a href=\"http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/hesiod/works.htm\">Works and Days</a>,\nparticularly lines 1-266. For each poem, don't even try to remember all\nthe names and details, but pay attention to the main themes. For the <i>Theogony</i>,\nthe principal concerns include the development of order in the universe\nand the ultimate triumph of Zeus; for <i>Works and Days</i>, think about\nhuman and divine justice, and the central role of agricultural labor.\n<br>\n<br>WEEK 3 Two City-States: Sparta and Athens\n<br>3.1 Sparta 1 \u2013 conquest.\n<br>Assignment: read <a href=\"http://uts.cc.utexas.edu/~sparta/topics/articles/academic/poetry.htm#tyrtaeus\">the poems</a> of\nTyrtaeus, Terpander and Alcman.\n<br>3.2 Sparta 2 \u2013 consolidation and the Spartan way of life.\n<br>Assignment: read the so-called \"<a href=\"http://ancienthistory.about.com/library/bl/bl_text_xenophon_lacedaemonians.htm\">Constitution of Sparta</a>,\"\nand skim Plutarch's <a href=\"http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Lycurgus*.html\">Life of Lycurgus</a>.\n<br>3.3 Tyrants and Sages.\n<br>3.4 Athens 1 \u2013 the social and economic situation through 600 BCE.\n<br>3.5 Athens 2 \u2013 Solon: poetry, politics and economics.\n<br>Assignment: re-read Plutarch's <a href=\"http://mkatz.web.wesleyan.edu/Images2/cciv243.Solon.html\">Life of Solon</a>;\nalso read the excerpt from Herodotus 1 about <a href=\"http://ancienthistory.about.com/library/bl/bl_solon_croesus.htm\">Solon and Croesus</a>,\nthe king of Lydia, and [Aristotle's] <i>Constitution of Athens</i>  <a href=\"http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/athenian_const.1.1.html\">chapters </a>\n\n<a href=\"http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/athenian_const.1.1.html\">5-12</a>(scroll down). You can also look back over Solon's <a href=\"http://www.classicalideals.com/Solon%20Poetry.htm\">poetry</a>,\n    as for Lecture 2.3 above. You can <a href=\"http://www.agathe.gr/democracy/solon_the_lawgiver.html\">look here</a> for\n    a succinct but accurate account of Solon's reforms.\n    <br>3.6 Athens 3 \u2013 Peisistratos: tyranny and civic identity.\n    <br>Assignment: read Herodotus <a href=\"http://www.parstimes.com/history/herodotus/persian_wars/clio.html\">Book 1, chapters 59-64</a> [you'll\n    have to scroll down; the \"chapters\" are each about one paragraph]; [Aristotle's] <i>Constitution of Athens</i> \n    <a href=\"http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/athenian_const.1.1.html\">chapters 13-16</a>.\n        <br>\n        <br>WEEK 4 Democracy. The Persian Wars\n        <br>4.1 The end of Athenian tyranny and the democratic revolution.\n        <br>Assignment: read <a href=\"http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0126%3Abook%3D5%3Achapter%3D55\">Herodotus Book 5, chapters 55-57</a> [you'll\n        have to click the forward arrow], <a href=\"http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/pwh/thuc6.asp\">Thucydides Book 6, chapters 53-60</a>,\n        and [Aristotle's] <i>Constitution of Athens</i>  <a href=\"http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/athenian_const.1.1.html\">chapters 17-18</a>.\n        Is there any agreement among the sources as to what happened?&nbsp; &nbsp;\n        <a href=\"http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/pwh/thuc6.asp\"></a>\n            <br>4.2 The reforms of Kleisthenes.\n            <br>Assignment: <a href=\"http://www.agathe.gr/democracy/political_organization_of_attica.html\">look here</a> for\n            a map of Attica and a solid account of Kleisthenes' reforms. Read: [Aristotle's] <i>Constitution of Athens</i> \n            <a href=\"http://www.constitution.org/ari/athen_03.htm\">chapters 19-22</a>.\n                <br>4.3 Herodotus and the creation of historical writing.\n                <br>Assignment: read Herodotus <a href=\"http://www.parstimes.com/history/herodotus/persian_wars/clio.html\">Book 1, chapters 1-96</a> [you\n                have already read some of this, but it's always good to re-read]. Things\n                to consider: how does Herodotus define the purpose of his history; what\n                are his sources of information; how does he present other cultures; can\n                you get some idea of his intended audience?\n                <br>4.4 Persian Wars 1 \u2013 from the Ionian Revolt (499-494 BCE) to the Battle\n                of Marathon (490 BCE).\n                <br>Look <a href=\"http://ancienthistory.about.com/od/geography/ig/Maps-of-Ancient-Greece/Persian-Empire-Map.--lv.htm\">at this map</a> of\n                the Persian Empire.\n                <br>Assignment: read Herodotus,&nbsp; <a href=\"http://www.parstimes.com/history/herodotus/persian_wars/erato.html\">Book 6, chapters 102-140</a>.\n                <br>4.5 \"Wooden Walls\": Themistocles and the Athenian fleet.\n                <br>Assignment: Read Herodotus, <a href=\"http://www.parstimes.com/history/herodotus/persian_wars/polymnia.html\">Book 7, chapters 138-144</a>.\n                Also read <a href=\"http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Themistocles*.html\">Plutarch's <i>Life of Themistocles</i>, chapters 1-4</a>.\n                <br>If you're interested in the practical aspects of ancient naval combat,\n                you can look at <a href=\"http://www.triremetrust.org.uk/index.asp\">this modern reconstruction</a> of\n                a trireme.\n                <br>4.6 Persian Wars 2 \u2013 endgame - to the Battles of Thermopylae and Salamis\n                (480 BCE), and Plataea (479 BCE).\n                <br>Assignment: for Thermopylae, read Herodotus, <a href=\"http://www.parstimes.com/history/herodotus/persian_wars/polymnia.html\">Book 7, chapters 200-239</a>;\n                read the <a href=\"http://www.livius.org/he-hg/herodotus/themistocles.htm\">\"Themistocles Decree\"</a>;\n                for Salamis, read Herodotus <a href=\"http://www.parstimes.com/history/herodotus/persian_wars/urania.html\">Book 8, chapters 42-102</a>.\n                <br>\n                <br>WEEK 5 \"The great 50 years\" (ca. 480-431 BCE)\n                <br>5.1 The aftermath of the Persian Wars; the Delian League.\n                <br>Assignment: read <a href=\"http://people.ucalgary.ca/~vandersp/Courses/texts/thucydi1.html#CH.IV\">Thucydides, Book 1, chapters 89-117</a>;\n                <a href=\"http://classicpersuasion.org/pw/thucydides/jthucbk3rv2.htm\">Book 3, chapters 9-11</a>(scroll down a bit); Plutarch <a href=\"http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Pericles*.html\"><i>Life of Pericles</i> chapters 12-17</a> (scroll\n                    down).\n                    <br>5.2 From Delian League to Athenian Empire.\n                    <br>Assignment: look at <a href=\"http://uts.cc.utexas.edu/~timmoore/BeaGreekweb/Athensempire.jpg\">this map</a> which\n                    shows the extent of the Athenian Empire. Think about the main factors that\n                    led to the change from a voluntary confederacy to an empire dominated by\n                    the Athenians.\n                    <br>5.3 Pericles: aristocrat, orator, and radical democrat.\n                    <br>Assignment: read Plutarch's <i><a href=\"http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Pericles*.html\">Life of Pericles</a> </i>(again,\n                    you've already read some of this); Thucydides, <a href=\"http://www.classicpersuasion.org/pw/thucydides/thucydides-passages.php?pleaseget=2.65-69\">Book 2, chapter 65</a>.\n                    <br>5.4 Tragedy and Athenian civic life; Sophocles' <i>Antigone</i> (441 BCE).\n                    <br>Assignment: read the excellent online version <a href=\"http://records.viu.ca/~johnstoi/sophocles/antigone.htm\">of </a><i><a href=\"http://records.viu.ca/~johnstoi/sophocles/antigone.htm\">Antigone </a>.</i>\n\n                    <br>5.5 Women in Greek society.\n                    <br>Assignment: read Euripides' <i><a href=\"https://records.viu.ca/~johnstoi/euripides/medea.htm\">Medea.</a></i> \n                    <br>5.6 The Periclean building program.\n                    <br>\n                    <br>WEEK 6 The Peloponnesian War I.\n                    <br>6.1 \"Thucydides the Athenian wrote the war.\"\n                    <br>Assignment: read Thucydides, <a href=\"http://people.ucalgary.ca/~vandersp/Courses/texts/thucydi1.html#CH.I\">Book 1, chapters 1-23</a>.\n                    What do you see, at the outset, as the principal differences between Thucydides'\n                    approach to history and that of Herodotus?\n                    <br>6.2 The outbreak of the war (431 BCE) and Pericles' strategy.\n                    <br>Assignment: read Thucydides, <a href=\"http://www.bostonleadershipbuilders.com/thucydides/book02.htm\">Book 2, chapters 1-65</a>.\n                    <br>6.3 Kleon, a \"new politician.\" The Peace of Nicias (421 BCE).\n                    <br>Assignment: read Thucydides, <a title=\"Link: http://www.bostonleadershipbuilders.com/thucydides/book03.htm\" href=\"http://www.bostonleadershipbuilders.com/thucydides/book03.htm\">Book 3, chapters 36-50</a>.\n                    <br>6.4 Comedy and Athenian civic life.\n                    <br>Assignment: read Aristophanes' <i><a href=\"http://classics.mit.edu/Aristophanes/acharnians.html\">Acharnians</a></i>\n\n                    <a title=\"Link: http://classics.mit.edu/Aristophanes/acharnians.html\" href=\"http://classics.mit.edu/Aristophanes/acharnians.html\">(425 BCE).</a>\n                        <br>6.5 War resumes; the conquest of Melos (416 BCE).\n                        <br>Assignment: read the \"Melian Dialogue\" = Thucydides, <a title=\"Link: http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/historians/thucyd/thucydides8.html\" href=\"http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/historians/thucyd/thucydides8.html\">Book 5, chapters 84-116</a>.\n                        <br>6.6 Alcibiades: aristocrat, general, and libertine.\n                        <br>Assignment: read Plutarch's <i><a title=\"Link: http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Alcibiades*.html\" href=\"http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Alcibiades*.html\">Life of Alcibiades</a>. </i>\n\n                        <br>\n                        <br>WEEK 7. The end of the War. The end of the century.\n                        <br>7.1 The Sicilian Expedition (416-413 BCE) and its aftermath.\n                        <br>Assignment: read Thucydides, <a href=\"http://www.classicpersuasion.org/pw/thucydides/jthucbk6rv2.htm\">Book 6, chapters 1-24</a> for\n                        the initial debate between Nicias and Alcibiades<a href=\"http://classicpersuasion.org/pw/thucydides/jthucbk7rv2.htm\">; Book 7, chapters 8-16</a> for\n                        Nicias's letter to the Athenians (scroll down); and <a href=\"http://classicpersuasion.org/pw/thucydides/jthucbk7rv2.htm\">Book 7, chapters 86-87</a> for\n                        Thucydides' summary of the event (at the very end; scroll way down).\n                        <br>7.2 Slaves and foreigners in Athenian life.\n                        <br>Assignment: read <a href=\"http://courses.ttu.edu/gforsyth/oo.htm\">\"The Old Oligarch\"</a> with\n                        special attention to 1.1-12.\n                        <br>7.3 The last years of the War; the battles of Arginusae (406 BCE) and\n                        Aegospotami (404 BCE). The Thirty Tyrants.\n                        <br>Assignment: read [Aristotle's] <i>Constitution of Athens</i>, <a href=\"http://www.constitution.org/ari/athen_05.htm\">chapters 34-41</a> [scroll\n                        down].&nbsp;\n                        <br>7.4 Socrates.\n                        <br>Not required but recommended: read Socrates' famous speech in his own\n                        defense, the <i><a href=\"http://socrates.clarke.edu/aplg0100.htm\">Apology</a>;</i> to\n                        get a sense of \"Socratic method,\" read the section in the <i>Apology</i> that\n                        contains Socrates' withering cross-examination of one of his accusers,\n                        Meletus: <a href=\"http://socrates.clarke.edu/aplg0103.htm\">here</a> and\n                        <a href=\"http://socrates.clarke.edu/aplg0104.htm\">here</a>.\n                            <br>7.5 Conclusion.\n                            <br>\n                            <br>\n                            <br>\n                            <br>\n                            <br>\n                            <br>\n                            <br>\n                            <br>\n                            <br>", "description": "", "short_name": "ancientgreeks", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<b>* Will I get a certificate after completing this class?<br></b>Yes.\nStudents who successfully complete the course will get a \"statement of\naccomplishment\" that they have done so.\n<br>\n<br><b>* What resources will I need for this class?<br></b>As noted above,\nwhenever possible the assignments will consist of original sources in translation,\nso that students must have a reading knowledge of English. All the readings\nare available online. <b><br></b><b></b>", "category-ids": ["humanities"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "This is a survey of ancient Greek history from the Bronze Age to the death of Socrates in 399 BCE. Along with studying the most important events and personalities, we will consider broader issues such as political and cultural values and methods of historical interpretation. ", "course_format": "This will be a 7-week course, with six new lecture videos every week;\neach lecture will be between 10 and 15 minutes in length, and each will\nhave 2 integrated multiple-choice questions. In addition, there will be\na quiz of 15 - 20 multiple-choice questions at the end of every week, covering\nthat week's material.\n<br>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": null, "suggested_readings": "There is available online an excellent <i>Overview of Classical Greek History from Mycenae to Alexander</i> by\nProf. Thomas R. Martin. You can access it via the\n<img src=\"http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=TRM+OV&amp;redirect=true\">\n<br><a href=\"http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=TRM+OV&amp;redirect=true\">Perseus website</a>.\n<br>The same text has also been published in an updated and more extensive\nprint version,<i> Ancient Greece: From Prehistoric to Hellenistic Times</i> (Yale\nUniversity Press: 2000).\n<br>", "instructor": "Andrew Szegedy-Maszak", "categories": [{"mailing_list_id": 11, "description": "Our wide range of courses allows students to explore topics from many different fields of study. {"about_the_course": "<p>Throughout history, the vast majority of people around the globe have\n    believed they have, however defined, a \u201csoul.\u201d While the question of whether\n    the soul exists cannot be answered by <span>science, what\nwe can study are the causes and consequences of various <i>beliefs </i>about\nthe soul and its prospects of surviving the death of the body. Why are soul and\nafterlife beliefs so common in human history? Are there adaptive advantages to\nassuming souls exist?&nbsp; Are there brain\nstructures that have been shaped by environmental pressures that provide the\nfoundation of body/mind dualism that is such a prominent feature of many\nreligions? How do these beliefs shape the worldviews of different cultures and\nour collective lives? What is the role of competing afterlife beliefs in\nreligion, science, politics, and war? This course explores several facets of\nthis relatively unexplored but profoundly important aspect of human thought and\nbehavior.</span>\n</p>\n<br>\n<br>\n<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/e0/bdf8651505657ac79281e160a8dd6a/BD_Mummy_and_Ba.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/71/222b0df7612fb28c3fd36cfebf1957/BD_Mummy_and_Ba.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/73/a6fe18dbaaba26c95aa2ea00b0be1a/BD_Mummy_and_Ba.jpg", "video": "Y2ZzHxtfGHI", "university-ids": ["rutgers"], "id": 456, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "", "website_facebook": "", "id": 67, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Camden", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 39.9259463, "location": "Camden, NJ", "primary_color": "", "abbr_name": "Rutgers", "website": "http://www.rutgers.edu/", "description": "", "short_name": "rutgers", "location_state": "NJ", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/59/a107424bb3b0befa13a7cdd26a9a67/1280320px-v2.jpg", "name": "Rutgers University", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/2a/5d3c520f1aeb9edfb86a3acbbda9b1/360px.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/dc/23e841ad9082e89831838b9065dac1/360px.jpg", "display": true, "location_lng": -75.11961989999998, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/35/06793b9429f2bb7fa481c88824dadf/200px48px.png", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p><b>Unit 1:&nbsp; Historical Foundations of Science, Religion,\nand Worldviews</b>\n</p>\n<p>1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Introduction to the Course (Profs. {"about_the_course": "<b></b><div><b></b>Spiritual sequel to Peter Thiel's <a href=\"http://blakemasters.tumblr.com/peter-thiels-cs183-startup\">CS183</a> course on startups. Bridges the gap between academic computer science and production softwar<b></b>e engineering. Fast-paced introduction to key tools and techniques (command line, dotfiles, text editor, distributed version control, debugging, testing, documentation, reading code, deployments), featuring guest appearances by senior engineers from successful startups and large-scale academic projects. Over the course of the class, students will build a command line application, expose it as a web service, and then link other students' applications and services together to build an HTML5 mobile app. General principles are illustrated through modern Javascript and the latest web technologies, including Node, Backbone, Coffeescript, Bootstrap, Git, and Github.&nbsp;<b></b><b></b><b></b></div>", {"about_the_course": "While many people are fans of\njazz and understand that musicians are often \u201cmaking up\u201d the\nnotes they are playing during a performance, most people\u2014often\nincluding musicians, themselves, who are beginning to learn improvising\u2014aren\u2019t\nclear about what exact processes take place to enable this to happen. The\npurpose of this course is to introduce the basic concepts of improvisation and\nhow to go about mastering the different musical and mental skills involved. <br><br>Course author Gary Burton codifies a sought-after approach to improvisation that has been at the \ncore of Berklee College of Music's curriculum for decades. Students who complete\nthis course will know what to practice and how to practice the\nvarious aspects of improvising, in addition to understanding how the improviser spontaneously\ncommunicates to the listeners through their musical creations. \n\n\n\n<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/0f/457e763eac0790be019fc29e90a153/jazz-large.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/38/498a30768dadc2f431b4e906ce2d92/jazz-large.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/bb/dd4a127c81a87d90665a71334b88c0/jazz-large.jpg", "video": "pTuR6lbSh68", "university-ids": ["berklee"], "id": 218, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/10/bb37f439a00f92524143611e504b27/favicon.png", "website_facebook": "", "id": 21, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/c4/885ec60036341f549253081e8784d1/berklee_logo.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "", "primary_color": "#0088CC", "abbr_name": "Berkleemusic", "website": "", "description": "", "short_name": "berklee", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/ce/77a045e73e76620497bd0992177021/masthead.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "", "name": "Berklee College of Music", "square_logo": "", "square_logo_source": "", "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": null, "course_syllabus": "<b>Lesson 1: Overview of the Mechanics of Jazz Improvisation&nbsp; \n\n</b><blockquote><p>This lesson explores how improvisation uses our language abilities to construct\nlogical melodic phrases. It introduces the concept of musical speech with\nvocabulary and grammar, when applied to improvisation.</p></blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Lesson 2: Chord Outlines and Chord Scales </b></p>\n\n<blockquote><p>This lesson examines the use of chord outlines. It identifies the most\ncommonly occurring chord scales and how to practice them in order to\nassimilate them. </p></blockquote>\n\n\n\n<p><b>Lesson 3: Choosing the Correct Chord Scales </b></p>\n\n<blockquote><p>This lesson introduces a set of guidelines for determining the correct\nchoices for scales in various harmonic situations.</p></blockquote>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<p><b>Lesson 4: Understanding Harmonic Movement </b></p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n<blockquote><p>In this lesson, you will learn about the different types of harmony movement and\nresolution, and how the improviser uses them when playing through the different\ntypes of chord progressions. <br></p></blockquote>\n\n<p><b>Lesson 5: Making Melodies </b></p>\n\n<blockquote><p>In this lesson, you will learn about theme development and establishing continuity\nof melodic phrases and ideas to build musical story lines&nbsp; as a basis for improvisations.</p></blockquote>", "description": "", "short_name": "improvisation", "target_audience": 3, "faq": "<ul><li><b>What do I need in order to record my assignments?</b></li></ul>\n<blockquote>During the course, you will be asked to submit recorded \nexamples of your playing. Among his more than 60 recordings, twenty have been\nnominated for Grammy awards, resulting in seven Grammy wins over the past four\ndecades, including a 2013 Grammy for Best Improvised Jazz Solo. Gary is widely considered to be the number one player of the\nvibraphone and is known for introducing a number of techniques for the\ninstrument. He has worked with the some of the most accomplished players in\njazz, including Carla Bley, Keith Jarrett, Chick Corea, Steve Lacy, Pat\nMetheny, Stan Getz, Herbie Hancock, Wolfgang Muthspiel, Stephane Grappelli, and\ntango lege<span>nd \u00c1stor Piazzolla. While Gary has maintained his performance and\nrecording career, he has also distinguished himself as a music educator and\ncollege administrator. Gary began as a teacher of percussion and improvisation\nat Berklee College of Music in 1971. He then served a decade each as dean and\nexecutive vice president of the college, as well as giving numerous workshops\nand clinics on jazz improvisation in the United States, Europe, Asia,\nAustralia, and South America. Gary authored and currently teaches <a href=\"http://www.berkleemusic.com/school/course/gary-burton-jazz-improvisation?pid=4685\">Jazz\nImprovisation</a> for\n<a href=\"http://www.berkleemusic.com/?pid=4685\">Berkleemusic.com</a>, the online continuing education division of Berklee College\nof Music.</span></p>", "small_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/38/498a30768dadc2f431b4e906ce2d92/jazz-large.jpg", "course-ids": [970245], "display": true, "recommended_background": "You should have at least an intermediate level of playing ability on your instrument.&nbsp; You should have a basic knowledge of chord symbols (C7, Gm7, F7b9, Abm7, for example) and\nshould, at a minimum, have tried improvising on some basic songs such as 12-bar\nblues or some familiar standard tunes. \n\n\n\n\n\n<br>"}
{"about_the_course": "&nbsp;This course explores the\nmathematical theory of two player games without chance moves. We will cover\nsimplifying games, determining when games are equivalent to numbers, and\nimpartial games.
