{"about_the_course": "<p>The wide range of global sports businesses constitutes a multi-billion\n    dollar industry. This course will examine and explain the business\n    of sports by analyzing the economic, legal, governance and success models\n    in various sports industries. The primary focus will be on American team\n    sports but comparative global models will be contemplated as well.&nbsp;\n    We will seek to find the answers to questions such as: what lessons can\n    global sports entities learn from each other? What business strategies\n    are used to retain the profitability of world leagues, sports teams and\n    franchises? What lessons can be drawn from the United States based sports\n    models? What revised models should new entrepreneurial leagues apply in\n    order to achieve success? Substantive instruction will be drawn from the\n    likes of the Olympics, FIFA World Cup, MLB, NFL, Premier League, various\n    player unions, China, India, South Africa, Brazil and much more. &nbsp;&nbsp;Ultimately,\n    our goal is to equip the student with a framework and tools with which\n    to understand and evaluate the business side of a wide range of competitive\n    sports ventures.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/11/aff8f5199168e0c856bc2931fc3b47/WSBI-logo_final-2.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/5d/6f4eeedb1b386a955cf8c5d6ee3dea/WSBI-logo_final-2.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/e3/b196d6ba64995e225c6e9188062504/WSBI-logo_final-2.jpg", "video": "m7CPqME1gEk", "university-ids": ["penn"], "id": 354, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "@pennopencourses", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f3/2ca37fd0d5d009a94e0ba7f284c860/favicon-penn.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 6, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7c/5d03cbe2cb87974be7f83cc1080af8/logo-penn-front.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "City, State, Country", "primary_color": "#0000ff", "abbr_name": "Penn", "website": "http://provost.upenn.edu/initiatives/openlearning", "description": "The University of Pennsylvania (commonly referred to as Penn or UPenn) is a private university, located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. A member of the Ivy League, Penn is the fourth-oldest institution of higher education in the United States, and considers itself to be the first university in the United States with both undergraduate and graduate studies. ", "short_name": "penn", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/2b/573b5eebd7c7d4d249c24f4b20aaaa/quad2.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/aa/e426c7bed595843b5b5f60e85425c9/quad2.jpg", "name": "University of Pennsylvania", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/5e/4003d6fe94ae4089d5daf13129a515/penn-logo.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f1/6cc70ed0c3cedf36b8ee0a737a1512/penn-logo.png", "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p><b>Week One: &nbsp;</b><i>Sports Enterprise Structure: Where is the\nMoney?</i><b>\n</b>We will examine the structure of sports leagues and teams including\n    a broad overview of the legal and financial structures. The week will also\n    provide an introduction to the revenue generators and revenue distribution\n    models so that students will be able to analyze a variety of sports business\n    models. For example, we will study U.S. and European league governance\n    including promotion and relegation. The important role of revenues from\n    media rights fees will be introduced and more closely examined later as\n    a primary financial driver. Other revenue generating streams such as ticket\n    sales and sponsorships will be studied as well.</p>\n<p><b>Week Two:</b><span> <i>Sports\nMedia</i>. This week will focus on the revenue sources that flow from the\nplaying of sports events as well as ancillary activities. This includes the\ntraditional radio and television sources as well as the ever growing and\nemerging new media sources. Beyond the revenues that flow from these sources we\nwill also examine how the use of and partnering with these media outlets have\nevolved from an initial fear of cannibalizing the live gate to current issues\nabout the delivery of&nbsp;\"free\" content and the impact on the ever changing sports\nbusiness model.&nbsp;</span>\n</p>\n<p><b>Week Three:</b><span> <i>Stadiums and Arenas</i>. The\nfocus here will be on these facilities as both revenue and economic impact\ngenerating facilities. Is there a formula used to plan for the development of\nsports infrastructure? We will focus on stadiums and arenas and delve into the\nhistory of the construction of great sports centers and their impact.</span>\n</p>\n<p><b>Week Four:</b><span>&nbsp;<i>Unions and Sports Agents</i><b>. </b>Sports agents and unions are key stakeholders in the sports business\nindustry. Agents source and manage talent while unions use collective\nbargaining to champion for an organization of the economic system that favors\nsalary increases. We will analyze the impact these stakeholders have had on the\nindustry in different regions in the world and use case examples including\nlockouts from the past. Students will have the opportunity to compare and\ncontrast unions around the world.</span>\n</p>\n<p><b>Week Five: </b><i>The Olympics and the\nFIFA World Cup.</i> We will take a close look at the Olympics history and\n    economic impact. What goes into planning and executing the Olympics? We\n    will analyze the 4 year cycle that business persons and athletes take to\n    prepare for the Olympics. We will also examine ideas about the economic\n    impact of these games on the host country\u2019s and the world\u2019s economy. Similarly,\n    the FIFA World Cup is the world\u2019s biggest sports event.&nbsp; We will discuss\n    the role of World Cup plays on the world\u2019s business environment using the\n    following lenses to analyze the tournament: fans, countries, players, media,\n    host country, retailers and of course FIFA.</p>\n<p><b>Week Six:</b><span> <i>Sports Enterprise Global\nStrategies</i>. How do sports entity leaders develop and execute global\nstrategy? We will conclude by contrasting the different penetration levels of\nvarious sports and their presence on the global platform. We will use the framework\nwe have developed to hypothesize the globalization of various sports and\nexamine their financial and operational feasibility.&nbsp; We\u2019ll contemplate the elements needed for a\ntruly global, profitable sport entity.&nbsp;</span>\n</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "globalsportsbusiness", "target_audience": 3, "faq": "<ul>\n    <li><b>Will I get a Statement of Accomplishment\nafter completing this class?</b>\n    </li>\n</ul>\n<p>Yes as long as you opt to take the final exam to ascertain that you have\n    retained course concepts. No Statements of Accomplishment or other credentials\n    will be awarded otherwise in connection with this course.</p>\n<ul>\n    <li>&nbsp;<b>Do I earn University of\nPennsylvania credits upon completion of the course?</b>\n    </li>\n</ul>\n<p>No. However, students who successfully complete the course above a threshold\n    score will receive a&nbsp;Statement of Accomplishment&nbsp;signed by the\n    instructor.</p>\n<ul>\n    <li><b>What resources will I\nneed for this class?</b>\n    </li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>There are no requirements or prerequisites for the course. Students\nwishing to fully engage should read, <i>The\nBusiness of Sports</i>, by Scott Rosner and Kenneth L. Shropshire, as will be\nset forth in the course syllabus.</span>\n</p>\n<ul>\n    <li><b>What are the learning\noutcomes of this course and why should I take it?</b>\n    </li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>By the end of the course you will have a better understanding of the\nbusiness of sports, sports enterprise structures and the interests of various\nstakeholders in the sports business industry.<b></b></span>\n</p>", "category-ids": ["business"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "This course analyzes the business side of sports and discusses the intricacies of global sports leagues as well as various countries' sports strategies. You will be equipped with a framework and tools to understand and evaluate the business side of competitive sports around the world.", "course_format": "<p>The course will consist of short weekly lectures associated with quizzes,\n    exercises, case studies and a discussion forum. There will be an optional\n    final exam delivered for those wanting to complete the Statement of Accomplishment\n    for this course. In the lecture segments, I\u2019ll describe different sports\n    business concepts and illustrate them with examples and diagrams. I\u2019ll\n    often use real-world case studies as illustrations to make the ideas easily\n    retainable. In a few of the segments, I will interview leading sports industry\n    stakeholders and provide links to relevant web or podcasts.</p>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": null, "suggested_readings": "<p><span>You do not need to purchase anything. {"about_the_course": "With the click of a mouse, now more than ever we are able to access sounds made by people from all around the world. And yet, most of us don't listen to the wide diversity of music available to us, probably because it sounds so strange. This class will open up the world of music to you. We begin with a brief history of recording technology, the music industry and the place of world music in that narrative; you are introduced to keywords for talking about music cross-culturally; and then proceed to half a dozen musical cultures around the world. In each of these musical cultures, we examine the ways in which music works in those distant cultures, how it sounds, what it means, who may perform it; and then we ask ourselves where this music has traveled and entered into the Western popular culture as entertainment, political discourse, or artistic purpose.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/worldmusic/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/worldmusic/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/worldmusic/large-icon.png", "video": "uQ3vPGKrwVk", "university-ids": ["penn"], "id": 28, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "@pennopencourses", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f3/2ca37fd0d5d009a94e0ba7f284c860/favicon-penn.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 6, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7c/5d03cbe2cb87974be7f83cc1080af8/logo-penn-front.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "City, State, Country", "primary_color": "#0000ff", "abbr_name": "Penn", "website": "http://provost.upenn.edu/initiatives/openlearning", "description": "The University of Pennsylvania (commonly referred to as Penn or UPenn) is a private university, located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. ", "short_name": "penn", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/2b/573b5eebd7c7d4d249c24f4b20aaaa/quad2.jpg", "landing_page_banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/aa/e426c7bed595843b5b5f60e85425c9/quad2.jpg", "name": "University of Pennsylvania", "square_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/5e/4003d6fe94ae4089d5daf13129a515/penn-logo.png", "square_logo_source": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f1/6cc70ed0c3cedf36b8ee0a737a1512/penn-logo.png", "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "", "square_logo_svg": ""}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Week One:</strong> Introductions with an overview of recording technology history and ties to world music and cultures; vocabulary for talking about world music and global cultural encounters, and a case study of \u201cChant,\u201d the 1990s Gregorian chant recording that crossed over into the popular music market.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Two:</strong> Graceland, Paul Simon's \"collaborative\" album. We reflect on the two opposite meanings of the word \"appropriate,\" examine multitrack recording, and consider the \"collaborative\" process in world music production.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Three:</strong> Tuvan Throat Singers, we examine how nomadic pastoralists from the Russian republic called Tanna Tuva have become world music superstars because of a single field recording made by an ethnomusicologist in the late 1980s.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Four:</strong> Pygmy Pop? We discuss \"pygmies\" in the western imagination, and uses of \"pygmy\" music in northern hemisphere popular culture to ask about the ethics of recorded music appropriations.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Five:</strong> Australian Aboriginal group Yothu Yindi embraced a discourse of cultural and musical reconciliation, and mixed the language of rock with traditional sounds as a successful political strategy in the 1990s.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Six:</strong> Kalahari Bushmen or Khoisan, are perhaps the oldest existing human communities. We discuss their traditional music, the 1970s Gods Must Be Crazy commercial film, and appropriation and reclamation of Khoisan heritage by South Africans in post-apartheid South Africa.</li>\n<li><strong>Week Seven:</strong> Cuba, the 1990s Buena Vista Social Club sound recording and documentary film, and a brief discussion of Cuban contemporary history and music are the subject of this final class.</li>\n</ul>", "description": "", "short_name": "worldmusic", "target_audience": null, "faq": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Will I get a Statement of Accomplishment after completing this class?</strong>\n<p>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a Statement of Accomplishment signed by the instructor.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>What do I need for the class?</strong>\n<p>An inquiring mind and ears open to hearing a wide range of sound. Access to Youtube.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>What is meant by \u201cworld music\u201d?</strong>\n<p>World Music is a marketing category created by the music industry in the late 1980s for music not traditionally considered \u201cmainstream\u201d by the industry. The term doesn\u2019t mean we will cover all of the world\u2019s music in 7 weeks. Rather we focus briefly on a handful of musical cultures to examine ways in which music has been harnessed by communities and individuals in the contemporary world for a variety of purposes.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Does it matter that I don\u2019t have any music theoretical knowledge? Will I need to be able to notate music?</strong>\n<p>No. You will learn to listen to, and discuss the music you hear in several ways. Graduate students from the University of Pennsylvania provide examples of how they hear the music, to encourage you to do similarly. You are given basic musical vocabulary relevant to each unit.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>What resources will I need for this class?</strong>\n<p>All musical examples used in the class come from Youtube, though there are many online resources you may know yourselves for locating musical examples that are either free or available for a small fee. We will make reference to a range of recordings and films that you may wish to locate and view in your own time. It will be an added bonus if you know about and inform other students in the class about further resources on a subject or community discussed in this course.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>What is the coolest thing I'll learn if I take this class?</strong>\n<p>Your ears will open to new sounds, your mind to new understanding of these sounds, your playlist will grow, and you will expand your knowledge of the world through its extraordinary range of music.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>", "category-ids": ["humanities", "music"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "Learn the ideas and vocabulary for listening to world music, and examine the music of several world music cultures and how they have entered into mainstream popular culture.", "course_format": "The class will consist of lecture videos and discussions of youtube music clips, which are between 8 and 15 minutes in length. She has had grants from the National Research Foundation (South Africa), a fellowship funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities and a variety of research and teaching grants from the University of Pennsylvania. Muller has published widely on South African music at home and abroad. Her books include <i>Rituals of Fertility and the Sacrifice of Desire: Nazarite Women's Performance in South Africa</i> (Chicago with CD Rom); <i>Focus: South African Music </i>(Routledge with CD); <i>Shembe Hymns</i> (Univ. of KwaZulu Natal, with CD) and with jazz singer Sathima Bea Benjamin, <i>Musical Echoes: South African Women Thinking in Jazz</i>. Muller is actively engaged in online learning at the University of Pennsylvania, where she teaches courses for credit like this one. And she takes students to the National Arts Festival in Grahamstown, South Africa every summer for credit! She has done pioneering work in academically based community service research and teaching - see <a href=\"http://www.sas.upenn.edu/music/westphillymusic\">www.sas.upenn.edu/music/westphillymusic</a> - and her graduate students are undertaking research and teaching all over the world. {"about_the_course": "<p>You have one liver but three patients are awaiting a liver transplant. Who should get the liver? What criteria should be used to select the recipient? Is it fair to give it to an alcoholic? These are some of the questions that arise in the context of rationing and allocating scarce health care resources among particular individuals. These are called micro-allocation decisions. There are also macro-allocation decisions that focus on how health care systems distribute resources across populations. Using the cases of organs for transplantation, the rationing for vaccines in a flu pandemic, and oncology drug shortages, the course will critically examine alternative theories for allocating scarce resources among individuals. Using both the need to establish priorities for global health aid and to define an essential benefit package for health insurance, the course will critically examine diverse theories for macro-allocation from cost-effectiveness analysis to age-based rationing to accountability for reasonableness. There are no prerequisites or required knowledge to take this course.</p>\n<div></div>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/rationing/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/rationing/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/rationing/large-icon.png", "video": "jtheNsEOW5c", "university-ids": ["penn"], "id": 51, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "@pennopencourses", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/f3/2ca37fd0d5d009a94e0ba7f284c860/favicon-penn.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 6, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7c/5d03cbe2cb87974be7f83cc1080af8/logo-penn-front.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "City, State, Country", "primary_color": "#0000ff", "abbr_name": "Penn", "website": "http://provost.upenn.edu/initiatives/openlearning", "description": "The University of Pennsylvania (commonly referred to as Penn or UPenn) is a private university, located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. Emanuel is the Vice Provost for Global Initiatives, the Diane v.S. Levy and Robert M. Levy University Professor, and Chair of the Department of Medical Ethics and Health Policy at the University of Pennsylvania. He has since been a visiting professor at UCLA, the Brin Professor at Johns Hopkins Medical School, the Kovitz Professor at Stanford Medical School and visiting professor at New York University Law School. {"about_the_course": "<p><b></b>While the human genome sequence has\ntransformed our understanding of human biology, it isn\u2019t just the sequence of\nyour DNA that matters, but also how you use it! How are some genes activated\nand others are silenced? How is this controlled? The answer is epigenetics. &nbsp;</p>\n\n<p>Epigenetics has been a hot topic for research\nover the past decade as it has become clear that aberrant epigenetic control\ncontributes to disease (particularly to cancer). Epigenetic alterations are heritable\nthrough cell division, and in some instances are able to behave similarly to\nmutations in terms of their stability. Importantly, unlike genetic mutations,\nepigenetic modifications are reversible and therefore have the potential to be\nmanipulated therapeutically. It has also become clear in recent years that\nepigenetic modifications are sensitive to the environment (for example diet),\nwhich has sparked a large amount of public debate and research.</p>\n\n<p>This course will give an introduction to the\nfundamentals of epigenetic control. We will examine epigenetic phenomena that\nare manifestations of epigenetic control in several organisms, with a focus on\nmammals. We will examine the interplay between epigenetic control and the\nenvironment and finally the role of aberrant epigenetic control in disease.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/c6/bf774b544bd9718e7ed7247e0e2611/Big480x270_withcopyright.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/a3/d40a84374147e6dcb20dc0cd458f10/Big480x270_withcopyright.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/74/92c169ff99f49dfb3136297330ccb0/Big480x270_withcopyright.jpg", "video": "MId1SMqUspA", "university-ids": ["unimelb"], "id": 173, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "unimelb", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/c2/fc137263568a25c66e2cc5f98ca899/UOM_16x16pxLogo.png", "website_facebook": "melbuni", "id": 33, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/58/59304da07d93c8a2cbfc5ac4c6a269/Mel1.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, {"about_the_course": "The objective of this course is to increase participants\u2019 awareness and\nunderstanding of ethical issues that arise in the conduct of research on\nhuman subjects. The course will explore the history and future of ethical\nand policy&nbsp;challenges using a multi-disciplinary approach. Leading\nscholars in the ethics of human subject research will serve as course faculty.\n&nbsp;This course will introduce participants to the history that grounds\npolicies and debates regarding the use of humans in research. It will continue\nwith&nbsp;discussion of&nbsp;how current international and US policies\ngoverning research are applied, how ethical norms and concepts have evolved,\nand how, in some cases, changes in research have outpaced changes in policy,\nleading to an often complicated mismatch between the two.\n<br>\n<br>The lead instructor is&nbsp;Jeffrey Kahn, who&nbsp;is the Robert Henry\nLevi and Ryda Hecht Levi Professor of Bioethics and Public Policy at the\nJohns Hopkins University Berman Institute of Bioethics. &nbsp;He will be\njoined by colleagues who are all among the leading scholars in aspects\nof the ethical and policy issues related to research on human subjects,\nincluding Profs. Ruth Faden (history and theory of informed consent),&nbsp;Nancy\nKass (public health research, research in international settings), Jeremy\nSugarman (empirical approaches to research ethics, US research policy),\nDebra Mathews (US and international science and research policy), Gail\nGeller (participants' perspectives on research participation),&nbsp;Joseph\nAli (law and research oversight in US and international settings), and\nDan O'Connor (medical history, ethics and social media-based research).\n<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": {"about_the_course": "<div>Designed for non-science students, this course is a practical \nintroduction to physics and science in everyday life. It considers \nobjects from the world around us, identifying and exploring the \nscientific concepts upon which they're based. Because it starts with \nobjects and looks within them for science, it is the reverse of a \ntraditional physics class. Instead of the usual principle-driven physics\n class, How Things Work is case-study physics. In this pilot semester of\n How Things Work, we will explore the basic laws of motion in the \ncontext of six familiar objects or activities: (1) Skating, (2) Falling \nBalls, (3) Ramps, (4) Seesaws, (5) Wheels, and (6) Bumper Cars. Despite \ntheir simplicity, these topics will bring us in contact with some of the\n most important concepts in physics, including inertia, energy, and \nmomentum.</div>\n<div></div><br>", "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p>1.Week of March 4: Episode 1 \u2013 Skating</p>\n\n<p>2.Week of March 11: Episode 2 \u2013 Falling Balls</p>\n\n<p>3.Week of March 18: Episode 3 \u2013 Ramps</p>\n\n<p>4.Week of March 25: Episode 4 \u2013 Seesaws</p>\n\n<p>5.Week of April 1: Episode 5 \u2013 Wheels</p>\n\n<p>6.Week of April 8: Episode 6 \u2013 Bumper Cars</p><br>", "description": "", "short_name": "howthingswork1", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "", "category-ids": ["physics"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "An introduction to physics in the context of everyday objects.", "course_format": "<p>The course consists of six episodes, one for each of the six objects \nor activities. A new episode will be released each week on Mondays at \n6:00am EST/EDT, beginning with the release of Episode 1 \u2013 Skating at \n6:00am EST on Monday, March 4, 2013.\nEach episode consists of six to eight short video segments and a quiz \n(homework assignment), along with suggested readings in the optional \ntextbook.</p>\n\n<p>The first video segment in an episode introduces the episode's topic \nand identifies some of the physics issues that we will need to examine \nin order to understand how the topic works. It also poses five or six \nhow and why questions, each of which is subsequently addressed in its \nown video segment. The final video segment in the episode summarizes the\n physics concepts encountered during the episode while explaining how \nthe topic works.\nEach of the middle video segments, those that address how or why \nquestions, also asks you one or two questions of its own. Though \ntechnically optional, these in-video quiz questions are intended to be \nthought-provoking and to help you solidify your understanding of key \nphysics concepts as we encounter them. I hope that you will answer those\n questions and use them to help you learn physics.</p>\n\n<p>The episode's homework assignment asks you to apply the physics \nconcepts encountered in the episode's videos (and suggested reading) to \nother real-world contexts. The questions are multiple-choice and rarely \nrequire calculations. In my experience, the physics concepts themselves \nare already challenging to learn and apply, and trying to perform \ncalculations using their more formulaic aspects is a distraction, rather\n than a worthwhile activity.</p><br>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": "https://www.coursera.org/course/howthingswork1", "suggested_readings": "<p>Physics is not easy and learning its concepts requires repeated \nexposure to them. In addition to watching the videos, I encourage you to\n read my textbook: How Things Work by Louis A Bloomfield (John Wiley \n&amp; Sons). This pilot semester of the online course will cover the \nfirst two chapters of the book, with each episode corresponding to a \nsection in one of those chapters.</p>\n\n<p>The 5th edition of How Things Work was released on January 4, 2013 \nand you can obtain it, or an earlier edition, from Wiley (<a href=\"http://www.wiley.com\">www.wiley.com</a>)\n or any online bookstore. An eTextbook version of the 4th edition is \navailable at Kno Books (<a href=\"http://www.kno.com)\">www.kno.com)</a>.</p><br>", "instructor": "Louis A. Bloomfield", "categories": [{"mailing_list_id": null, "description": "", "id": 23, "short_name": "physics", "name": "Physics"}], "estimated_class_workload": "2-4 hours/week", "name": "How Things Work 1", "language": "en", "courses": [{"grading_policy_distinction": "", "ace_track_price_display": null, "signature_track_certificate_design_id": null, "ace_semester_hours": null, "start_year": 2013, "duration_string": "6 weeks", "signature_track_last_chance_time": null, "id": 388, "start_month": 3, "certificate_description": "Statements of Accomplishment are available to students according to two tracks:\n\n1) Distinguished - Students must achieve a cumulative quiz average of 80% or better.\n2) Passing - Students must achieve a cumulative quiz average of 50% or better.\n", "start_date_string": "", "eligible_for_ACE": null, "signature_track_regular_price": null, "grades_release_date": null, "creator_id": null, "signature_track_price": null, "statement_design_id": null, "signature_track_registration_open": false, "topic_id": 133, "eligible_for_signature_track": null, "start_date": null, "status": 1, "start_day": 4, "end_date": null, "notified_subscribers": true, "instructors": [735728], "active": true, "eligible_for_certificates": true, "deployed": true, "ace_close_date": null, "name": "001", "signature_track_open_time": null, "grading_policy_normal": "Course grades are based solely on weekly quiz performance (10 questions/week, for a total of 60 questions). To receive a Statement of Accomplishment, you have to obtain an average >= 50% of weekly quiz performance.", "ace_open_date": null, "home_link": "https://class.coursera.org/howthingswork1-001/", "certificates_ready": false, "proctored_exam_completion_date": null, "university_logo": null, "signature_track_close_time": null}], "about_the_instructor": "<img src=\"https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/howthingswork1/instructor-1.png\" height=\"319\" style=\"width: 240px;\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\">Louis A. Bloomfield is Professor of Physics at the University of Virginia, where he has been teaching since 1985. Bloomfield grew up taking everything apart and, with the notable exception of one recalcitrant mechanical clock, he managed to get them all back together again (or at least that's what he remembers). He also survived numerous electrical shocks and chemical accidents in his youth, not all of which were unexpected. When he arrived at Amherst College, tinkering with things wasn't offered as a major, so he chose the closest available option: he majored in physics. Bloomfield received his B.A. in 1979 summa cum laude and his Ph.D. in physics from Stanford University in 1983. He was a postdoctoral fellow at AT&amp;T Bell Laboratories until 1985, when he joined the faculty of the University of Virginia as an Assistant Professor of Physics. He has been there ever since. Bloomfield is the recipient of numerous awards for his research in atomic, condensed matter, and optical physics, including the Apker Award of the American Physical Society, a Presidential Young Investigator Award of the National Science Foundation, a Young Investigator Award of the Office of Naval Research, and an Alfred P. Sloan Fellowship, and he is a Fellow of the American Physical Society.&nbsp;\n<div><br>In 1991, Bloomfield decided to try teaching physics the way he originally learned physics: in the context of everyday things. He created a course called How Things Work and taught it to 92 students at the University of Virginia its first semester. He was hooked and evidently so were the students, because 261 of them took the course its second semester. Since then, Bloomfield has taught physics to nearly ten thousand non-science students at the University and received both a 1998 State of Virginia Outstanding Faculty Award and the 2001 Pegram Medal of the Southeastern Section of the American Physical Society for that teaching. His course became an innovative introductory textbook entitled How Things Work: The Physics of Everyday Life, 4th Edition (Wiley, 2010) and that textbook became a more comprehensive trade book entitled How Everything Works: Making Physics Out of the Ordinary (Wiley, 2008). In addition to his books, Bloomfield is the author of more than 100 publications in the fields of atomic clusters, autoionizing states, high-resolution laser spectroscopy, nonlinear optics, computer science, and general science literacy. <br><br>Bloomfield works extensively with professional societies and the media to explain physics to the general public and has appeared frequently on television and radio. He recently co-hosted the television series Some Assembly Required on the Discovery Channel (2007-2008), followed by appearances in Known Universe on the National Geographic Channel (2009) and in Capitals Red Line on Comcast SportsNet (2010-2012). Although he enjoys the challenge of explaining physics on the small screen, he is well aware that he is not an actor and that he merely plays one on television. <br><br>Bloomfield's years of experimenting with everything he can get his hands on, and reading about those he can't, have made him something rare in modern day science: a generalist. More specifically, he knows enough to be dangerous in a broad swath of the physical sciences and even some of the life sciences. That background has allowed him to serve frequently as a science consultant and as an expert witness in matters that require a broad understanding of physics and scientific issues. Although Bloomfield struggles to keep his research, teaching, and service activities from consuming every available second, he has too much fun with all of them to stop.</div>", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/howthingswork1/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [388], "display": true, "recommended_background": "None."}
{"about_the_course": "Reasoning is important. &nbsp;This course will teach you how to do it\nwell. &nbsp;You will learn some simple but vital rules to follow in thinking\nabout any topic at all and some common and tempting mistakes to avoid in\nreasoning. &nbsp;We will discuss how to identify, analyze, and evaluate\narguments by other people (including politicians, used car salesmen, and\nteachers) and how to construct arguments of your own in order to help you\ndecide what to believe or what to do. {"about_the_course": "The impact of technology and networks on our lives, culture, and society continues to increase. The very fact that you can take this course from anywhere in the world requires a technological infrastructure that was designed, engineered, and built over the past sixty years. To function in an information-centric world, we need to understand the workings of network technology. This course will open up the Internet and show you how it was created, who created it and how it works. Along the way we will meet many of the innovators who developed the Internet and Web technologies that we use today. <br><br>\n<h2>What You Will Learn</h2>\nAfter this course you will not take the Internet and Web for granted. You will be better informed about important technological issues currently facing society. You will realize that the Internet and Web are spaces for innovation and you will get a better understanding of how you might fit into that innovation. If you get excited about the material in this course, it is a great lead-in to taking a course in Web design, Web development, programming, or even network administration. At a minimum, you will be a much wiser network citizen.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/insidetheinternet/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "Week 1: Introduction to the Course and The Dawn of Electronic Computing (1940-1960)<br>Week 2: The First Internet (1960-1990)<br>Week 3: The World Wide Web (1990-1995)<br>Week 4: Commercialization and Growth (1995-2000)<br>Week 5: Internets and Packets<br>Week 6: Transports and Security<br>Week 7: Networked Applications<br>Week 8: Security - Protecting Information<br>Week 9: Security - Establishing Identity<br>Final Exam", "description": "", "short_name": "insidetheinternet", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Why history?</strong>\n<p>This is not history just to memorize dates, places, and people's names so you can answer questions on an exam. The history of the Internet and the Web is not nearly as simple as it might seem on the surface. There are heroes who saved the day and villains who tried to keep the heroes from saving the day. There were complex engineering issues that needed to be solved in a hurry. By looking at what really happened and hearing directly from those who built it, we also learn about how humans work together to solve large, complex, and undefined problems.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What is the format of the class?</strong>\n<p>The course is about 60% recorded lectures and 40% video interviews with Internet pioneers. It will be comprised of a series of 10-30 minute segments with some assessment material at the end of each segment. You should expect to spend 2-5 hours per week viewing the material, doing extra readings, participating in discussions with fellow students, and taking the assessments.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Do I need a textbook?</strong>\n<p>No. The materials are mostly self-contained and extra materials will be available on the Web or available for free from within the course.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Will we need to write programs?</strong>\n<p>No. No programs. Trust me. No programs.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What about timing? Can I take this self-paced?</strong>\n<p>Sort of. Within any week of the course, you can look at the material and take assessments whenever you have time available, regardless of your time zone. But we will move the course along and there will be due dates for each assessment to keep us all moving forward together. So you can't wait until the last week and do all the material in a day or two. We expect that you will be committed and work on the course each week as you would for any other college class.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Can we contact the professor?</strong>\n<p>The professor will be nearby and monitoring the course. If problems come up, there may be a need for online office hours or even the just-in-time development of extra materials if a lot of students get stuck on a particular topic or idea. The discussion forum is an important part of the class and your fellow students will answer many questions. Teaching staff will monitor and interact in the forums as well. You can follow the instructor on Twitter <a href=\"https://twitter.com/#!/drchuck\">@drchuck</a> to get a sense of where he is during the course.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Do we need to know HTML?</strong>\n<p>No. But after you take this course, we hope you get inspired to want to learn HTML.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Will I get a Statement of Accomplishment&nbsp;after completing this class?</strong>\n<p>Yes. {"about_the_course": "<p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</p><p>\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</p><p>In this class, we will ask and answer a series of questions\nabout the role and practice of archaeology in the world today. If archaeologists\nare trained to investigate the past, what is left for us to study?&nbsp; Who gets to be an archaeologist?&nbsp; How and why do archaeologists hunt for\n\u201ctreasures\u201d, and what do we do once we\u2019ve discovered them? &nbsp;Who pays for archaeological work?&nbsp; When did archaeology begin? &nbsp;What can we know, and not know, about people\nin the past? &nbsp;What do archaeologists know\nabout the past that most people would never guess \u2013 and why aren\u2019t we telling\nyou?&nbsp; What is an archaeologist\u2019s greatest\nfear?&nbsp; Why are people entirely willing to\nmurder each other over the fate of archaeological sites? &nbsp;Are Real Men alone capable of discovering the\ntruth behind all this?</p>\n\nArchaeology famously involves getting dirty in\nthe line of duty.&nbsp; Students will\nexperience its hands-on nature, through the use of numerous exercises and archaeological\ncase studies.&nbsp; But there are other \u2018dirty\nlittle secrets\u2019 to learn about the field: not least how the stories\narchaeologists tell about the past have been used and abused, for purposes both\ngood and bad.&nbsp; Our goal by the end of the\ncourse is to have you \u2018thinking like an archaeologist\u2019 and fully aware of the often-fraught\npolitics of doing archaeology around the globe.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<br><p></p>\n\n<p></p>", {"about_the_course": "<div>A modern VLSI chip is a remarkably complex beast: &nbsp;billions of transistors, millions of logic gates deployed for computation and control, big blocks of memory, embedded blocks of pre-designed functions designed by third parties (called \u201cintellectual property\u201d or IP blocks). &nbsp;How do people manage to design these complicated chips? &nbsp;Answer: &nbsp;a sequence of computer aided design (CAD) tools takes an abstract description of the chip, and refines it step-wise to a final design. This class focuses on the major design tools used in the creation of an Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) or System on Chip (SoC) design. &nbsp;Our focus is on the key representations that make it possible to synthesize, and to verify, these designs, as they move from logic to layout. &nbsp; <br><br>Our goal is for students to understand how the tools themselves work, at the level of their fundamental algorithms and data structures. You should be taking this course if (1) you are interested in building VLSI design tools; &nbsp;(2) you are interested in designing VLSI chips, and you want to know why the tools do what they do; &nbsp;(3) you just like cool algorithms, that work on big cool problems that involve bits, and gates, and geometry, and graphs, and matrices, and time, and...</div>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/vlsicad/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/vlsicad/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/vlsicad/large-icon.png", "video": "mh9OOGQk2cY", "university-ids": ["illinois"], "id": 130, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/57/35fedfb0feae472bc90ad4a9920e93/wordmark_coursera-360.svg", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "Illinois_Alma", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/2b/57d79bc1eb5b081e6a1b3729782566/favicon.png", "website_facebook": "illinois.edu", "id": 17, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/a9/ff5237ed042c63a02e67e2094e97c1/university-of-illinois-at-urbana-champaign.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "Urbana, Illinois, USA", "primary_color": "#003C7D", "abbr_name": "Illinois", "website": "http://illinois.edu/", "description": "The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is a world leader in research, teaching and public engagement, distinguished by the breadth of its programs, broad academic excellence, and internationally renowned faculty and alumni. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a certificate signed by the instructor.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>Am I going to learn how to use any industrial design tools in this class?</strong>\n<p>Nope. This is not a course about \u201cusing\u201d other people\u2019s tools. So, it\u2019s not a standard \u201cVLSI Design\u201d sort of a class. This is a course about building software design tools.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What resources will I need for this class?</strong>\n<p>You need access to a Windows, Mac, or Linux computer to be able to write, compile and run programs. You should be able to program in one of Java or C++. For some programming assignments, you can use any language you like, as long as you can read our input files and write our output file formats.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What is the coolest thing I'll learn if I take this class?</strong>\n<p>How it\u2019s possible to synthesize logic and layout using cool algorithms and data structures. Let\u2019s face it: you can build a Karnaugh map with about 6-7 variables, and beyond this your head explodes. Modern designs have a million gates. Clearly, something magical is happening somewhere, to pull this off. Come learn what that magic is.</p>\n</li>\n</ul>", "category-ids": ["cs-systems", "ee"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "A modern VLSI chip has a zillion parts -- logic, control, memory, interconnect, etc. \u00a0How do we design these complex chips? \u00a0Answer: CAD software tools. \u00a0Learn how to build these tools in this class.", "course_format": "<div>The class will consist of lecture videos, which are between 15 and 20 minutes in length. &nbsp;There will also be standalone problem sets (homeworks) that are not part of video lectures, a few programming assignments, and a (not optional) final exam.</div>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": "https://www.coursera.org/course/vlsicad", "suggested_readings": "<div>The course is designed to be self-contained. &nbsp;However, we will offer pointers to original source material, i.e., papers in conferences and journals. &nbsp;This area lacks a single, established \u201cfront-to-back\u201d text, that covers logic and layout, as well as representation, optimization, synthesis and verification. &nbsp;So, we will work to be as complete as possible in the lectures.</div>\n<div></div>", "instructor": "Rob A. ", "start_date_string": "", "eligible_for_ACE": false, "signature_track_regular_price": null, "grades_release_date": null, "creator_id": null, "signature_track_price": null, "statement_design_id": 15, "signature_track_registration_open": false, "topic_id": 130, "eligible_for_signature_track": false, "start_date": null, "status": 1, "start_day": 4, "end_date": null, "notified_subscribers": true, "instructors": [887472], "active": true, "eligible_for_certificates": true, "deployed": true, "ace_close_date": null, "name": "001", "signature_track_open_time": null, "grading_policy_normal": "The course comprises 8 Problem Sets, 4 Programming Assignments and 1 Final Exam.  For a Statement of Accomplishment with Achievement Badge, students must achieve ~70% of the maximum possible score, across the Problem Sets (75% of final grade) and Final Exam (25% of final grade).  For a Statement of Accomplishment with Mastery Badge, students must achieve ~70% of the maximum possible score, across the Problem Sets (40% of final grade), Programming Assignments (40% of final grade) and Final Exam (20% of final grade).", "ace_open_date": null, "home_link": "https://class.coursera.org/vlsicad-001/", "certificates_ready": false, "proctored_exam_completion_date": null, "university_logo": null, "signature_track_close_time": null}], "about_the_instructor": "<img src=\"http://spark-public.s3.amazonaws.com/playspace/Landing_Page_Assets/UIUC/vlsicad/rutenbar-head.jpg\" style=\"width: 220px;\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\">\n<div>Rob A. Rutenbar is the Abel Bliss Professor and Head of the Department of Computer Science at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. &nbsp;He received his PhD from the University of Michigan in 1984, and spent the next 25 years on the faculty at Carnegie Mellon University. &nbsp;He joined Illinois in 2010. &nbsp;He has worked on design tools for integrated circuits for the last 30 years, in areas ranging from synthesis, to optimization, to formal verification, simulation, and geometric layout. &nbsp;On a leave of absence from CMU in 1998, he cofounded Neolinear Inc. to commercialize the first successful tools for analog circuit design; &nbsp;he served as Neolinear\u2019s Chief Scientist until its acquisition by Cadence (NASDAQ: CDNS) in 2004. &nbsp;His research spans both chip design methods (with recent focus on modeling the messy statistics of nanoscale silicon) and custom silicon chip architectures (for tough tasks like speech recognition, and machine learning). <br><br>Prof. Rutenbar has won many awards for his work. &nbsp;He is a Fellow of the IEEE and the ACM. &nbsp;He received the 2001 Semiconductor Research Corporation Aristotle Award in recognition of the impact of his teaching and his students on the US semiconductor industry. &nbsp;He received the 2007 IEEE CAS Industrial Pioneer Award for his contributions to making circuit synthesis tools a commercial success. Most recently, he won the 2011 IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design Donald O. Pederson Best Paper Award for work on rare event failure statistics in nanoscale memory design.</div>", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/vlsicad/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [382], "display": true, "recommended_background": "<div>Programming experience (C++, Java) and basic knowledge of data structures and algorithms. &nbsp;An understanding of basic digital design: &nbsp;Boolean algebra, Kmaps, gates and flip flops, finite state machine design. &nbsp;Linear algebra and calculus at the level of a junior or senior in engineering. &nbsp;Exposure to basic VLSI at an undergraduate level is nice -- but it\u2019s not necessary. &nbsp;We will keep the course self-contained, but students with some VLSI will be able to skip some background material.</div>\n<div></div>"}
{"about_the_course": "<p>Phones, diesel engines, animated newspapers, medical devices, games, political campaigns, medical research, mining, transportation systems, ... and so on, and on, and on... every day more of the world around us is at least partly run by computer programs. This means that being able to design programs - or at least be able to work with people who design programs - is becoming a more and more valuable skill.</p>\n\n<p>To build your own programs you need to know two things: how to use the specific programming language and libraries needed, and the more general skill of how to design a program.</p>\n\n<p>This course presents a <b>design method</b> that will enable you to approach the design of complex programs systematically. The method will work for programs in this course as\nwell as hard to design programs you develop in the future.</p>\n\n<p>Using this method you will learn how to model the information in a problem domain, how to structure program data to mirror that information and how to further structure the data to lead to a well organized program. You will also learn to distinguish those parts of a program that are naturally data driven, from those that should use an alternative algorithmic approach. The method uses unit-tests to both produce a better developed design, and to test your program\nas you develop it.</p>\n\n<p>The course has a two-phase structure. In the first phase we use a simple teaching language to cover the core of the design method. The second phase consists of parallel tracks, with each track using a different popular programming language and focusing on a different kind of problem. This will help you bring the design method to whatever language and problem domain interests you.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/e7/a9c4480054bf8b689e86f5cf9f99e3/IntroSystematic_1280x720.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/35/e8609391fde9df1c434fb9ac0ee1c4/IntroSystematic_1280x720.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/78/95379b3e2298c62886f84192aaf6ee/IntroSystematic_1280x720.jpg", "video": "_2O5CUVch-g", "university-ids": ["ubc"], "id": 233, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d1/159770b1b64f0bb3736e0a1ad5144b/favicon.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 29, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d1/4b45f1fa68329d09b869d990e5d48e/panel_signature3.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "", "primary_color": "#0f2144", "abbr_name": "UBC", "website": "", "description": "", "short_name": "ubc", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/dd/396bbc8612e8d7bd419bdffa4c9f36/ubc4.jpg", "landing_page_banner": null, "name": "The University of British Columbia", "square_logo": null, "square_logo_source": null, "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/bf/ec7f82fa9a5710bd93265b426dcebd/s1b282.png", "square_logo_svg": null}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": null, "course_syllabus": "", "description": "", "short_name": "programdesign", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<p><b>Can students ask questions?</b><br></p>\n\n<p>We will use an on-line discussion group\nto enable students to ask and answer questions. Solutions to the problems will be\navailable both as code - to show the final result - and in video form to show the\ndesign process that produced the result. His work is directed\nat enabling programmers to write programs that, as much as possible, look like their\ndesign.\u00a0\u00a0He is best known for his work on aspect-oriented programming,\nand he led the Xerox PARC team that developed aspect-oriented programming and\nAspectJ. {"about_the_course": "Qui \u00e9tait Jean Calvin&nbsp;? Pourquoi ses id\u00e9es ont-elles exerc\u00e9 une telle influence au 16e si\u00e8cle et dans les si\u00e8cles suivants&nbsp;? Ce cours cherchera \u00e0 r\u00e9pondre \u00e0 ces deux questions.<br>Il mettra en \u00e9vidence l\u2019humanisme de Calvin, sa compr\u00e9hension de la pens\u00e9e biblique, son acuit\u00e9 th\u00e9ologique, son sens aigu des probl\u00e8mes sociaux et politiques. Nous aurons aussi l\u2019occasion d\u2019\u00e9voquer l\u2019apport de Calvin \u00e0 la culture (notamment \u00e0 la langue fran\u00e7aise, qui lui doit consid\u00e9rablement) et \u00e0 la conception de l\u2019humain devant Dieu et dans la soci\u00e9t\u00e9. Nous verrons \u00e9galement comment Calvin fit de Gen\u00e8ve la capitale d\u2019une id\u00e9e et d\u2019un id\u00e9al de vie chr\u00e9tienne, en pensant le rapport au travail et \u00e0 l\u2019argent ou en cr\u00e9ant des institutions comme la Compagnie des pasteurs, le Consistoire et l\u2019Acad\u00e9mie.<br>Ce cours mettra \u00e9galement en \u00e9vidence la place que Calvin occupe dans l\u2019histoire de la tol\u00e9rance, ou plut\u00f4t de l\u2019intol\u00e9rance, religieuse&nbsp;: l\u2019affaire Servet (du nom de ce savant espagnol condamn\u00e9 \u00e0 mort \u00e0 Gen\u00e8ve pour h\u00e9r\u00e9sie) fera ainsi l\u2019objet d\u2019une analyse sp\u00e9cifique. Nous tenterons \u00e9galement de montrer les apports de la th\u00e9ologie de Calvin (notamment la compr\u00e9hension renouvel\u00e9e d\u2019un Dieu en qui l\u2019humain peut faire confiance) et ses limites (par exemple la doctrine dite de la pr\u00e9destination).<br>Ce cours d\u2019introduction fera \u00e9galement une place \u00e0 l\u2019histoire du calvinisme en Europe (France, Allemagne, Provinces-Unies, Angleterre) et dans le monde (Am\u00e9rique, Afrique du Sud, Asie).<br><i>Le cours est donn\u00e9 en fran\u00e7ais avec sous-titres en anglais.<br>---<br></i>Who was John Calvin? Why were his ideas so influential in the 16th century and well beyond his time? This course seeks to answer these two questions.<br>We will present his humanistic leanings, his interpretation of the Bible, his theological vision, his acute sense of social and political questions. We will consider his contribution to culture, how he contributed to shaping French language, his understanding of the human before God and in society. The course will address how Calvin sought to transform the city of Geneva into an idea and an ideal of Christian life, by thinking the meaning of work and money, but also by creating educational and ecclesiastical institutions (the \u00ab&nbsp;Company of Pastors&nbsp;\u00bb, the \u00ab&nbsp;Consistory&nbsp;\u00bb and the \u00ab&nbsp;Academy&nbsp;\u00bb)<br>The course will locate Calvin within the history of religious toleration, or rather of religious intolerance. We will analyse the fate of Michel Servet, a learned Spanish man who was condemned for heresy and executed in Geneva in 1553. With regard to Calvin\u2019s theology, we will show both his lasting contribution (especially his understanding of a God in whom one may trust) as well as the limitations of his thought (for instance his doctrine of predestination).<br>Towards the end of this introductory course, we will turn our attention to the history of Calvinism in Europe (France, Germany, the United Provinces, England) and in various parts of the world (Americas, South Africa and Asia).<br><i>Course in French with English subtitles.</i><br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/e5/1561248f3efdb3ed0e08c1b91de5fb/Calvin.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/dc/f06ad4d4410fb8b0f8a75004f7e393/Calvin.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/9b/74b1b58f6ad5183a369ef568aaad29/Calvin.jpg", "video": "", "university-ids": ["unige"], "id": 385, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "UNIGEnews", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/2d/ced013338cdff809fbdde5a24f3354/UNIGE-SmallIcon-16x16.png", "website_facebook": "unigeneve", "id": 49, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/98/a4770a9c65f63ea149919431ad519e/UNIGE-Logo-MainPage.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Gen\u00e8ve", "location_country": "CH", "location_lat": 46.1983922, "location": "Geneva, Suisse", "primary_color": "#CF0063", "abbr_name": "UNIGE", "website": "http://www.unige.ch/", "description": "Founded in 1559, the University of Geneva (UNIGE) is one of Europe's leading universities. La pens\u00e9e politique, sociale et \u00e9conomique de Calvin.<br><b>Semaine 4 :</b> Succ\u00e8s et revers du calvinisme en Europe et dans le monde.<br><b>Semaine 5 : </b>Lire aujourd\u2019hui Calvin. {"about_the_course": "In this course you will learn several fundamental principles of algorithm design. You'll learn the divide-and-conquer design paradigm, with applications to fast sorting, searching, and multiplication. You'll learn several blazingly fast primitives for computing on graphs, such as how to compute connectivity information and shortest paths. Finally, we'll study how allowing the computer to \"flip coins\" can lead to elegant and practical algorithms and data structures. Learn the answers to questions such as: How do data structures like heaps, hash tables, bloom filters, and balanced search trees actually work, anyway? How come QuickSort runs so fast? What can graph algorithms tell us about the structure of the Web and social networks? Students who successfully complete the class will receive a statement of accomplishment signed by the instructor.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What is the format of the class?</strong>\n<p>The class consists of lecture videos, which are broken into small chunks, usually between eight and twelve minutes each. Some of these may contain integrated quiz questions. There will also be standalone quizzes that are not part of video lectures. There will be approximately two hours worth of video content per week.</p>\n</li>\n<li><strong>What should I know to take this class?</strong>\n<p>How to program in at least one programming language (like C, Java, or Python); familiarity with proofs, including proofs by induction and by contradiction; and some discrete probability, like how to compute the probability that a poker hand is a full house. At Stanford, a version of this course is taken by sophomore, junior, and senior-level computer science majors.</p>\n</li>\n</ul><br><ul><li><strong>How does Algorithms: Design and Analysis differ from the Princeton University algorithms course?</strong>\n<p>The two courses are complementary.  That one emphasizes implementation and testing; this one focuses on algorithm design paradigms and relevant mathematical models for analysis. At Stanford, he has taught the Design and Analysis of Algorithms course for the past eight years. His research concerns the theory and applications of algorithms, especially for networks, auctions and other game-theoretic applications, and data privacy. {"about_the_course": "Why Content Strategy is essential for professionals in any organization&nbsp;\u2013&nbsp;business, non-profit, or government.<br><br>Content Strategy is a conversation that provides thought-leadership. It starts a \u201cconversation\u201d with users and stakeholders inside and outside an organization.&nbsp; Conversations are the natural way people think about complex issues. Conversations also enable people to develop \u201cstories,\u201d which lead to understanding and helpful mental pictures. Content Strategy practitioners are at all levels of the best enterprises \u2013 in all departments and sectors from the top leader to the newcomer in the ranks.<br><br>In this complex information age, forward-thinking employees know that if they and their organizations are to thrive, they need to go beyond their job descriptions. They must master the most demanding communications frontier \u2013 creating engaging, strategic, honest stories and information that is valued by their most important audiences. In turn that will make their enterprise stand out.<br><br>Regardless of their department, area of work, or expertise, Content Strategy practitioners know how to use words, pictures, video, and social and mobile media to interact with their most important constituents with trustable, actionable information that the audience values and will use. The strategic content they produce enhances the audience\u2019s lives and&nbsp;deepens their understanding and engagement with the organization.<br><br>Content Strategy is similar to the best examples of journalism, but it is done by non-journalism organizations. Content Strategy is always honest, trustable, and transparent. It tells all sides of every story it reports. Often it is also deeper and directed at topics and audiences that traditional journalism under-serves or does not reach at all. Content Strategy is not advertising, marketing, or public relations. It is different because it never pursues the persuasive goals that are appropriate in those disciplines.<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/2d/d77f35ab4002efa08e6bc876f0450e/Content-Strategy-logo2.JPG", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/a2/5eebe5eaecd87d6eb07304cbd9ef0f/Content-Strategy-logo2.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/2e/b6ffdd5174cc93bb9b6dbe83b19879/Content-Strategy-logo2.jpg", "video": "", "university-ids": ["northwestern"], "id": 488, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "NorthwesternU", "favicon": "", "website_facebook": "NorthwesternU", "id": 54, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Evanston", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 42.0411414, "location": "Evanston, IL", "primary_color": "#480058", "abbr_name": "Northwestern", "website": "http://www.northwestern.edu/", "description": "Founded in 1851, Northwestern University is a private research and teaching university with an enrollment of approximately 8,000 full-time undergraduate students, 8,000 full-time graduate and professional students, and 2,000 part-time students on campuses in Evanston and Chicago, Illinois, and Doha, Qatar. {"about_the_course": "<p>Quantum\nphysics is the foundation for much of modern technology, provides the framework\nfor understanding light and matter from the subatomic to macroscopic domains,\nand makes possible the most precise measurements ever made.&nbsp; More than just a theory, it offers a way of\nlooking at the world that grows richer with experience and practice.&nbsp; Our course will provide some of that practice and teach \nyou \"tricks of the trade\" (not found in textbooks) that will enable you \nto solve quantum-mechanical problems yourself and understand the subject\n at a deeper level.</p>\n\n<p>The\nbasic principles of quantum physics are actually quite simple, but they lead to\nastonishing outcomes. &nbsp;Two examples that\nwe will look at from various perspectives are the prediction of the laser by\nAlbert Einstein in 1917 and the prediction of antimatter by Paul Dirac in 1928.&nbsp; Both of these predictions came from very\nsimple arguments in quantum theory, and led to results that transformed science\nand society.&nbsp; Another familiar\nphenomenon, magnetism, had been known since antiquity, but only with the advent\nof quantum physics was it understood how magnets worked, to a degree that made\npossible the discovery in the 1980\u2019s of ultrastrong rare-earth magnets.&nbsp; However, lasers, antimatter and magnets are\nareas of vibrant research, and they are all encountered in the new field of\nultracold atomic physics that will provide much of the material of \u201cExploring\nQuantum Physics\u201d.</p>\n\n<p>Richard\nFeynman once said, \u201cI think I can safely say that nobody understands quantum\nmechanics.\u201d&nbsp; We say, that\u2019s no reason not\nto try! What Feynman was referring to are some of the \u201cspooky\u201d phenomena like quantum entanglement, which are incomprehensible from the standpoint of classical physics. Even though they have been thoroughly tested by experiment, and are even being exploited for applications such as cryptography and logic processing, they still seem so counterintuitive that they give rise to extraordinary ideas such as the many-world theory. Quantum physics combines\na spectacular record of discovery and predictive success, with foundational\nperplexities so severe that even Albert Einstein came to believe that it was\nwrong.&nbsp; This is what makes it such an\nexciting area of science!</p><br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/8c/02c5aee8624624fd81fc6e0f5a8137/Preliminary_Draft_Logo_Clark_Galitski2.png", "preview_link": "https://class.coursera.org/eqp-001/lecture/preview", "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/10/c8ba4de9077e632a9bd311f5323787/Preliminary_Draft_Logo_Clark_Galitski2.png", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/c4/1c545de180c31595a29dd0f38bd7cf/Preliminary_Draft_Logo_Clark_Galitski2.png", "video": "YwTE8ldPfak", "university-ids": ["umd"], "id": 170, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "UofMaryland", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/98/81bc9a607b97fadd8a2fdd6b66bfc2/favicon_16x16.ico", "website_facebook": "UnivofMaryland", "id": 32, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/fd/01ba206b961003d2e4eb052d0ceac6/primarylogosm.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "21, Berwyn", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 38.9896967, "location": "College Park, Maryland, USA", "primary_color": "#990000", "abbr_name": "UMD", "website": "http://www.umd.edu/", "description": "The University of Maryland is the state's flagship university and one of the nation's preeminent public research universities. Early experiments <br><ul>\n<li>1.1    Richard Feynman on learning quantum physics and more</li>\n<li>1.2    Albert Einstein's Nobel prize: photo-electric effect; photons</li>\n<li>1.3    Explosion in a lab shows electrons are actually waves; electron\ndiffraction</li>\n<li>1.4 <strong></strong>\"Deriving\" the Schr\u00f6dinger equation</li>\n<li>1.5 Spreading of quantum wave-packets; Heisenberg uncertainty principle</li>\n</ul>\n\nLecture 2: Interpretation and foundational principles of quantum mechanics <br><ul>\n<li>2.1    Discussion of  Schr\u00f6dinger's and Born's Nobel prize-winning\nworks. Probabilistic interpretation of QM</li>\n<li>2.2 The continuity equation for probability. Probability current</li>\n<li>2.3 Quantum operators and expectation values</li>\n<li>2.4 Superposition principle. Dirac notations. Representations</li>\n</ul>\n\n  <br>Week 2 (April 1 - 7) <br>Lecture 3: Feynman formulation of quantum theory <br><ul>\n<li>3.1      Feynman path integral in a nutshell</li>\n<li>3.2 Propagator. Time-evolution operator</li>\n<li>3.3 Formal derivation of the path-integral, part I (difficult material - optional) </li>\n<li>3.4 Formal derivation of the path-integral, part II (difficult material - optional) </li>\n</ul>\n\nLecture 4: Using Feynman path integral&nbsp;\n<ul>\n<li>4.1 Newton's second law of motion \"hidden\" in the Feynman path integral</li>\n<li>4.2 Electrical conductivity of a metal - simple classical picture and quantum corrections to it</li>\n<li>4.3 Quantum (weak) localization. Interference between loop-trajectories</li>\n</ul>\n\n  <br>Week 3 (April 8 -14)\n\n<br>Lecture 5: Back to the Schr\u00f6dinger picture: bound states in quantum potential wells <br><ul>\n<li>5.1     Quantization in a guitar string and a quantum well. Electron in a box</li>\n<li>5.2 Electron in a finite potential well. Shallow quantum well</li>\n<li>5.3 Weakly-bound state in a 1D Dirac delta-potential (shallow well)</li>\n<li>5.4 Shallow potential in 2D and 3D  (difficult material - optional) </li>\n</ul>\n\nLecture 6: Cooper pairing in the theory of superconductivity&nbsp;\n\n<ul>\n<li>6.1 Motivation - superconductivity phenomena: zero resistance, flux\nrepulsion, levitation</li>\n<li>6.2 Quantum statistics in a nutshell: fermions and bosons</li>\n<li>6.3 Electrons in a metal - a simple picture. Fermi surface</li>\n<li>6.4 Cooper pairing: weakly-bound electron pairs</li>\n</ul>\n\n   <br>Week 4 (April 15 - 21)\n\n<br>Lecture 7: Atomic spectra <br><ul>\n<li>7.1 Atomic spectra. Overview of experimental data </li>\n<li>7.2 Bohr\u2019s theory of hydrogen atom.</li>\n<li>7.3 Derivation of the spectrum of hydrogen atom using symmetry arguments.</li>\n</ul>\n\nLecture 8: Formal solution of the Schr\u00f6dinger equation in Coulomb potential <br><ul>\n<li>8.1 Analytical approach </li>\n<li>8.2 Numerical solution </li>\n</ul>\n\n\n  <br>Week 5 (April 22 -28)\n\n<br>Lecture 9: Symmetry and conservation laws in quantum mechanics <br><ul>\n<li>9.1 Symmetry in quantum mechanics</li>\n<li>9.2 Angular momentum, parity,</li>\n<li>9.3 Discrete symmetries and time-reversal.</li>\n</ul>\n\nLecture 10: Spin&nbsp;\n<ul>\n<li>10.1 Stern\u2013Gerlach experiment </li>\n<li>10.2 Spinors, spin operators, Pauli matrices </li>\n<li>10.3 Practical applications</li>\n</ul>\n  <br>Week 6 (April 29 - May 5) <br>Lecture 11: Harmonic oscillator <br><ul>\n<li>11.1 Algebraic solution to the harmonic oscillator: Creation and\nannihilation operators</li>\n<li>11.2 Particle in a magnetic field. Landau levels</li>\n<li>11.3 Quantum Hall effect in a nutshell</li>\n</ul>\n\nLecture 12: Periodic structures in quantum mechanics&nbsp;\n<ul>\n<li>12.1&nbsp;  Spherical cow model of a crystal: a chain of harmonic oscillators</li>\n<li>12.2 Phonons. Goldstone theorem</li>\n<li>12.3 Electron in a periodic potential. Bands</li>\n<li>12.4 Topology of the bands. Topological insulators in a nutshell</li>\n</ul>\n\n  <br>Week 7: (May 6 - May 12) \n\n<br>Lecture 13: Time-dependent quantum mechanics<ul>\n<li>13.1 Sudden perturbation. Shaking of an atom</li>\n<li>13.2 Slow perturbations. Topological Berry phase</li>\n<li>13.3 Spin in a time-dependent magnetic field</li>\n</ul>\n\nLecture 14:  Quantum optics <br><ul>\n<li>14.1 Introduction to quantum optics </li>\n<li>14.2 Physics of a laser. </li>\n<li>14.3 Coherent states </li>\n</ul>\n\n  <br>Week 8: (May 13 - May 19) \n\n<br>Lecture 15: Ultra-cold quantum gases <br><ul>\n<li>15.1 Introduction to ultra-cold atoms </li>\n<li>15.2  Bose-Einstein condensation</li>\n<li>15.3 Degenerate Fermi gases</li>\n</ul>\n\n\nLecture 16: Summary of the course. Answering student's questions. He has two PhD degrees in applied mathematics and\ntheoretical condensed matter physics. Dr. Galitski is a theoretical physicist,\nworking on the forefront of quantum science. He has more than 70 publications\nin top physics journals including Nature physics, Physical Review Letters, and\nPhysical Review series. Galitski\u2019s research in quantum physics is funded\nby\u00a0 the US Department of Energy, DARPA,\nNational Science Foundation, and the US Army Research Office. Dr. Galitski is a\nrecipient of the NSF CAREER award and several other awards. He is also a\nco-author of a 1000-page book, <a href=\"http://www.amazon.com/Exploring-Quantum-Mechanics-Collection-Researchers/dp/0199232725\"> \u201cExploring quantum mechanics\u201d</a>   to be published by Oxford University Press in 2012, which is arguably the world\u2019s largest\ncollection of solved problems in quantum mechanics spanning just about the full\nscope of sub-fields of quantum physics. <br></p>\n\n<p><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/bc/4fb6e66150a13fb3ac057e9ba27c7a/Charles_Clark2crop.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"><br>  <a href=\"http://jqi.umd.edu/fellows-gallery-view/136-charles-clark.html\">Charles W.\nClark</a>  is a Fellow of  <a href=\"http://www.nist.gov/index.html\">the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)</a>  \nand is Co-Director of <a href=\"http://jqi.umd.edu/\">the Joint Quantum Institute</a>  of NIST and <a href=\"http://www.umd.edu/\">the University of Maryland</a>.\u00a0 He has a Ph.D. in theoretical atomic,\nmolecular and optical physics from the University of Chicago and has spent most\nof his career at NIST.\u00a0 Since 1997 he has\nrun a summer course on solution of physics problems for first-year graduate\nstudents of UMD, and he is co-editor of  <a href=\"http://dlmf.nist.gov\">the NIST Digital Library of\nMathematical Functions</a>, which will be used as a primary\nreference in some parts of the course.\u00a0</p><br>", "small_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/10/c8ba4de9077e632a9bd311f5323787/Preliminary_Draft_Logo_Clark_Galitski2.png", "course-ids": [970197], "display": true, "recommended_background": "The purpose of this course is to provide a \ngraduate/advanced undergraduate level introduction to&nbsp; quantum \nmechanics.&nbsp; The emphasis throughout the course will be on applications \nof general techniques to specific quantum-mechanical problems and \nphenomena. Basic understanding of calculus and linear algebra is \nessential for completing this course, and knowledge of differential \nequations and Fourier transforms is valuable. Previous exposure to \nquantum mechanics would be helpful, but is not assumed. The course will \nbe self-contained and an introduction will be provided.<br>"}
{"about_the_course": "<p><span>Intended for both newcomers who are\ncurious about video games and hard-core gamers who want to reflect on their\npassion, this course will explore what happens to stories, paintings, and films\nwhen they become the basis of massively multiplayer online games.&nbsp; <i>The\nLord of the Rings </i>trilogy\u2014the novels, films, and video game\u2014are our central\nexample of how \u201cremediation\u201d transforms familiar stories as they move across\nmedia.&nbsp; We will study <i>The Lord of the Rings Online</i> against\nthe backdrop of other games such as <i>Final Fantasy </i>, <i>Star Wars: The Old Republic</i>, and <i>Skyrim</i>; narrative theory, intermediality, and game theory; poems by Spenser, Coleridge, Keats, and Browning; fiction by\nTolkien and others;\nand art since the Pre-Raphaelites that has influenced the neo-medievalism of much fantasy literature and gaming.</span></p>\n\n<p>Drawing on centuries\nof romance narrative conventions, the twenty-first century gaming industry has\nbecome a creative and economic powerhouse.&nbsp;\nIt engages the talents of some of our brightest writers, artists,\ncomposers, computer engineers, game theorists, video producers, and marketing\nprofessionals, and in 2011, it generated an estimated $64 billion in revenue.&nbsp; Anyone interested in today\u2019s culture needs to\nbe conversant with the ways this new medium is altering our understanding of\nstories.&nbsp; Join me as we set out on an\nintellectual adventure, the quest to discover the cultural heritage of online\ngames.</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/12/c22bb29b7a6b73d60eba57bf0fe152/Cheeryble-by-moonlight.jpg", "preview_link": null,
