{"about_the_course": "<div>This course is intended to help even non-technically trained students gain basic proficiency in health&nbsp;informatics: the application of computing to healthcare delivery, public health and community-based&nbsp;clinical research. This is distinct from the related field of bioinformatics, which explores the role of&nbsp;computing in understanding the genomic and proteomic processes within cells. Weeks 1-2 cover the&nbsp;US healthcare delivery system's unique structural, economic and policy issues and how they create a&nbsp;potentially strategic role for health informatics. Week 3-5 explains at a high level the core technologies&nbsp;involved in contemporary health informatics. Weeks 6-9 explore how these technologies are being&nbsp;deployed using some of the best commercial and open source products as examples. Week 10 presents&nbsp;the instructor\u2019s personal speculation about the future of the field. There are reading assignments for each&nbsp;week. As the course progresses, students can, optionally, also read the appropriate chapters of the&nbsp;instructor\u2019s text, Health Informatics in the Cloud.</div>", "other_description": "", "photo": He is also Associate Director for Health Systems for the Institute for People and\u00a0Technology where he helps identify, create and manage research and industry partnership opportunities.</div><div><br></div><div>He received a BS from MIT in 1969 and an MD from the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC)\u00a0in 1974. After an internship at Washington University he joined the faculties of Medicine and Pharmacy\u00a0at MUSC where he developed an early fully functional ambulatory electronic medical record system\u00a0and the first reported system for the clinical management of ambulatory pharmacies. In 1978 he co-founded PROHECA to commercialize the pharmacy system. The company was acquired by National\u00a0Data Corporation (NDC) in 1981 and he ran the NDC Healthcare Division and was the company\u2019s\u00a0President and COO until he left in 1990 to co-found Patient Care Technologies (\u201cPtCT\u201d). PtCT, a provider\u00a0of electronic patient record and tele-health systems to the home care industry, graduated from Georgia\u00a0Tech\u2019s Advanced Technology Development Center (ATDC), was a 1998 Inc 500 company, and was\u00a0acquired by MEDITECH in 2007.</div><div><br></div><div>He is the author of many articles and book chapters devoted to various aspects of clinical automation.\u00a0His recent book, Health Informatics in the Cloud, parallels the approach used in this course. \u00a0He won a 1996 Entrepreneur of the Year Award\u00a0for the Southeast Region, received a 1995 Innovation in Medical Management Award from the American\u00a0Society of Physician Executives and received the 2006 Founder\u2019s Award from the American-Israel\u00a0Chamber of Commerce, Southeast Region.</div>", "small_icon": "http://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/58/fc257127332a300b5032649fe8e26d/logo.png", "course-ids": [970193], "display": true, "recommended_background": ""}
{"about_the_course": "<p>This general education course will cover concepts of work and energy and their relationship with our modern society. Porter        began his career in private industry and a mechanical engineer        focused on heating and cooling. But a restless intellect led        Porter back to academia and to the University of Florida, where        he earned his PhD in agricultural and biological engineering. <br></p><p>Dr. Porter now works in sustainable construction practices and structures        that conserve energy and resources. He teaches courses in these        areas in the Agricultural Operations Management curriculum. His        combination of ready wit and engineering precision makes him        a popular and effective teacher. Porter's research focuses on        understanding construction in specialized applications not covered        in standard construction programs. First, Porter is interested        in Florida's unique environment. Most of the United States lies        in a temperate climate zone, and many standard building practices        are based on the the requirements of these areas. However, Florida's        subtropical climate, with its heat and humidity, poses unique        challenges and presents special opportunities. {"about_the_course": "La fisica del\nXX secolo, con le teorie della relativit\u00e0 e della meccanica quantistica, ha\ncambiato radicalmente la visione del mondo che ci circonda. Dallo spazio e\ntempo assoluti e indipendenti si \u00e8 passati ad una descrizione di un mondo in cui\ndistanze ed intervalli di tempo dipendono da chi le osserva, in cui l\u2019ordine di\naccadimento di due eventi non \u00e8 univoco, in cui la velocit\u00e0 del tempo segnato\nda un orologio dipende da quali corpi si trovino vicino. Nel microscopico si \u00e8\ninvece abbandonata la descrizione della fisica classica, magari caotica, ma\nsempre deterministica, per arrivare ad una descrizione probabilistica, in cui\ngli stati e le propriet\u00e0 del mondo microscopico non sono determinati, a priori,\nintrinsecamente, ma acquisiscono realt\u00e0 solo se vengano misurati o se entrino\nin contatto con altri \u201coggetti\u201d. L\u2019abbandono della realt\u00e0 locale, del fatto\ncio\u00e8 che le azioni esercitate in un luogo, per particolari sistemi, possono\navere effetti istantanei su oggetti a distanze virtualmente infinite,\nstravolgono la descrizione di un mondo che fino al secolo scorso sembrava\nsensato e ragionevole. Nel corso verranno descritte le principali\ncaratteristiche di queste due teorie, di come abbiano cambiato il concetto del\nnostro universo e delle possibilit\u00e0 di conoscerlo, e di come abbiano influito\nnella vita quotidiana.<p></p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/db/331edd3f16a7391ffa670a6fefa03d/logo-RQM-4-1-liv.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/ca/fdede07dfdc8736b57af429144682d/logo-RQM-4-1-liv.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/7b/726abddcdeb722eb183057e5109a01/logo-RQM-4-1-liv.jpg", "video": "", "university-ids": ["sapienza"], "id": 461, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "SapienzaRoma", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/4f/07577f978824782011a597f14f2bdf/favicon-16x16-png.png", "website_facebook": "SapienzaRoma", "id": 74, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Roma", "location_country": "IT", "location_lat": 41.9015141, "location": "Roma, RM, Italia", "primary_color": " #822433", "abbr_name": "Sapienza", "website": "http://www.uniroma1.it/", "description": "Sapienza University of Rome, founded in 1303 by Pope Boniface VIII, is the oldest University in Rome and the largest in Europe.\nSince its founding over 700 years ago, Sapienza has played an important role in Italian history and has been directly involved in key changes and developments in society, economics and politics. It has contributed to the development of Italian and European science and culture in all areas of knowledge.\nThe main campus, designed by Marcello Piacentini, was opened in 1935. It is situated close to the city centre, and is the largest in Europe - a real city within a city where teaching activities are integrated with libraries and museums as well as comprehensive student services. Faculties and Departments also carry out their activities in decentralized locations in different parts of the city.  There are two other university campuses elsewhere in Lazio.\nSapienza offers a vast array of courses including degree programmes, PhD courses, one to two year professional courses, and Specialization Schools in many disciplines, run by 63 Departments and 11 Faculties. Viviamo in uno spazio\nassoluto e in un tempo assoluto. Si \u00e8 spiegato \u201cquasi tutto\u201d. Esistono leggi\ndeterministiche per conoscere lo stato di un sistema semplice, e leggi\nprobabilistiche per i&nbsp;sistemi \"complicati\".</p>\n\n<p><b>2 Lezione:</b> In realt\u00e0 non tutto torna. La velocit\u00e0 della luce non si somma\ncome dovrebbe fare secondo Galileo. Un corpo molto caldo dovrebbe emettere\nenergia infinita. Gli atomi sono tutti identici, perch\u00e9?</p>\n\n<p><b>3 Lezione:</b> A. Einstein, La Teoria della Relativit\u00e0 speciale, 1905. Lo spazio\ne il tempo non sono assoluti. La velocit\u00e0 della luce \u00e8 una costante universale. Tutte\nle leggi della fisica hanno la stessa forma. Non si pu\u00f2 definire la contemporaneit\u00e0\nassoluta di due eventi. E=mc^2 .&nbsp;</p><p><b>4 Lezione:</b> A. Einstein, La teoria della Relativit\u00e0 Generale, 1916. Lo spazio-tempo\nin cui viviamo non solo non \u00e8 assoluto, ma non \u00e8 neanche piatto (euclideo). Lo\nspazio \u00e8 curvo, e la curvatura \u00e8 causata dalle masse dei corpi. La luce si pu\u00f2\nmuovere secondo una linea curva. Vicino ai corpi gli orologi vanno pi\u00f9 veloci,\ne le distanze si accorciano. Il GPS senza le correzioni relativistiche non funzionerebbe.</p>\n\n<p><b>5 Lezione:</b> La Meccanica Quantistica (1900-1927),\nun lavoro condotto da decine di scienziati in pi\u00f9 di trent\u2019anni. La prima idea\ndi Planck (1900). L\u2019intuizione di Einstein (1905).</p>\n\n<p><b>6 Lezione:</b> La Meccanica Quantistica nell\u2019interpretazione\ndi Copenaghen (1927). Nel mondo microscopico lo stato di un sistema <b>non pu\u00f2 </b>essere descritto da posizione e\nvelocit\u00e0.</p>\n\n<p><b>7 Lezione:</b> La funzione d\u2019onda: un \u201cfantasma\u201d (?)\nche descrive completamente lo stato di un sistema fisico. La conoscenza \u00e8\nintrinsecamente probabilistica.</p>\n\n<p><b>8 Lezione:</b> Gli effetti visibili: assenza di\npropriet\u00e0 definite. Coesistenza di pi\u00f9 propriet\u00e0 inconciliabili. Heisenberg e&nbsp;Il Principio\ndi Indeterminazione. L\u2019effetto tunnel.</p>\n\n<p><b>9 Lezione:</b> La non localit\u00e0 della realt\u00e0. </p>\n\n<p><b>10 Conclusioni.</b> Il mondo com\u2019\u00e8: una realt\u00e0 o una\ncomoda descrizione?</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "rqm", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<b>Potr\u00f2 ricevere un attestato di frequenza per questo corso?</b><br>Si. {"about_the_course": "<div>In bringing about behavior change in public health, we often focus on the individual mother, student, or farmer. We should not forget the community structure and norms constrain for encouraging individual health behaviors. This course examines the community context of the changes needed to promote the public\u2019s health. We begin by examining the various definitions of \u2018community\u2019 and the processes by which we \u2018diagnose\u2019 or seek to understand the structure and characteristics of different types of communities. An appreciation of community similarities and differences is necessary lest we fall into the trap of designing one-size-fits-all interventions. We need to recognize that no matter that outsiders may view a community as poor or neglected, we can find strengths and capacities for improvement in each community. Identifying community capacities and resources is the first step in facilitating community change. Different practical and philosophical approaches to change and therefore, examined. Specific to the change process is our recognition of the need for communities to participate in the design, implementation and evaluation of any intervention. We examine the concept of participation in an effort to see how different levels of involvement may affect sustainability of community change efforts. Finally a case study of a community participatory approach to onchocerciasis control in Africa is presented. Community Directed Intervention has subsequently been successfully applied to providing other essential primary health care services by and in the community, such as insecticide treated bednets, malaria treatment, vitamin A distribution, deworming medicines, and pneumonia and diarrhea case management.<br><br></div>", "other_description": "", "photo": "<div>\n<div>After listening to, viewing, and studying the course materials, you will:</div>\n<div>\n<ul>\n<li>Provide a definition of community</li>\n<li>Identify community components, characteristics, and typologies</li>\n<li>Outline and explain the components of a community diagnosis</li>\n<li>Explain the concept of perceived community/collective efficacy</li>\n<li>Outline and He is a Professor in the Health Systems Program of the Department of International Health at The Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health and also serves as JHPIEGO\u2019s Senior Malaria Specialist. Bill taught at the African Regional Health Education Center at the University of Ibadan, Nigeria, from 1976 to 2002. He is internationally renowned for his expertise in the social and behavioral aspects of tropical disease control and prevention, with special emphasis on malaria, onchocerciasis and guineaworm. He has served as a consultant for the International Health Programs Office and the Malaria Branch of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as malaria expert for the VOICES malaria advocacy project of The Johns Hopkins University\u2019s Center for Communications Programs, and consultant to the World Bank, the African Program for Onchocerciasis Control, Unicef and various USAID implementing partners in the areas of tropical disease control, HIV/AIDS prevention, program evaluation and community participation. Bill is a member of the Mectizan Expert Committee that advises Merck\u2019s Mectizan Donation Program onchocerciasis control efforts. Bill participated in the development and field testing of the original Roll Back Malaria Needs Assessment Instruments, developed background documents for the Abuja Summit, provided consultation on overcoming bottlenecks in Global Fund malaria grants in Nigeria, conducted malaria needs assessments in Ghana and Burkina Faso and provided team building training for the National Malaria Program in Mali, and participates in the RBM Harmonization Working Group. In addition, he teaches three internet-based courses: training methods/continuing education for health workers, urban health and social and behavioral foundations of primary health care in the distance education program of The Johns Hopkins University, and is one of the coordinators of the internet-based Certificate in Global Health of the Department of International Health. He has published more than 140 scientific articles including ones focused on the social and cultural aspects of disease control, training of community health workers and peer educators, and community participation strategies in disease control efforts ranging from including malaria, onchocerciasis and guinea worm. Bill also serves on the Editorial Boards of several peer reviewed journals and provides manuscript reviews for many scientific publications. {"about_the_course": "Eating patterns that begin in childhood affect health and wellbeing across\nthe lifespan. In the USA, we are in the midst of a childhood obesity epidemic\nthat threatens to leave our children with a shorter life expectancy than\ntheir parents. As processed foods become more readily available around\nthe world, other developed nations are beginning to follow suit. This course\nexamines contemporary child nutrition in America from the individual decisions\nmade by each family to the widespread food marketing targeting our children.\n&nbsp;The health risks associated with obesity in childhood are also discussed.\nStudents will learn what constitutes a healthy diet for children and adults\nand how to prepare simple, delicious foods aimed at inspiring a lifelong\ncelebration of easy home-cooked meals. {"about_the_course": "<p>We\ntake a case-based approach to teach contemporary mathematical modeling\ntechniques.&nbsp; The course is appropriate\nfor advanced undergraduates and beginning graduate students.&nbsp; Lectures provide biological background and\ndescribe the development of both classical mathematical models and more recent\nrepresentations of biological processes.&nbsp;\nThe course will be useful for students who plan to use experimental\ntechniques as their approach in the laboratory and employ computational modeling\nas a tool to draw deeper understanding of experiments. The course should also\nbe valuable as an introductory overview for students planning to conduct\noriginal research in modeling biological systems.</p>\n\n\n\nThis course focuses on\ndynamical modeling techniques used in Systems Biology research.&nbsp; These techniques are based on biological\nmechanisms, and simulations with these models generate predictions that can\nsubsequently be tested experimentally. These testable predictions frequently\nprovide novel insight into biological processes.&nbsp; The approaches taught here can be grouped\ninto the following categories:&nbsp; 1)\nordinary differential equation-based models, 2) partial differential\nequation-based models, and 3) stochastic models.&nbsp; <br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/e8/02ae40e3741db67bf46f40941e1965/Dynamical_modeling_Logo_460X270_v2.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/67/cd059d678aea29903129739e27addf/Dynamical_modeling_Logo_460X270_v2.png", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/c9/6d1f5b8584be57df13528aab65576e/Dynamical_modeling_Logo_460X270_v2.png", "video": "", "university-ids": ["mssm"], "id": 181, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "mountsinainyc", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/6e/050cc941c1081a711d979b25b7b108/Course_catalog_page_16x16.png", "website_facebook": "MountSinaiMedicine", "id": 27, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/40/20e4ab932508164766302a9bf01c5c/mount_sinai.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "New York", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 40.7143528, "location": "New York, NY", "primary_color": "#0f487c", "abbr_name": "Mount Sinai", "website": "http://www.mssm.edu/", "description": "The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, formerly the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, is an American medical school in the borough of Manhattan in New York City. ODE Models</li><li>Modeling in Systems Biology - PDE Models</li><li>Computing with Matlab</li><li>Computing with Octave</li><li>Introduction to Dynamical Systems</li><li>Developing Models: Extracting Constants from Experimental Literature</li><li>Modeling Emergent Properties: Bistability in Biochemical Signaling I</li><li>Modeling Emergent Properties: Bistability in Biochemical Signaling II</li><li>Modeling with Cell Cycle with Systems of ODEs Cycle</li><li>ODE Model of the Action Potential</li><li>Parameter Sensitivity Analysis to assess Robustness and Fragility</li><li>Curve Fitting and Error Estimation</li><li>PDE Models of Propagating Action Potentials</li><li>PDE Models of Vesicle Transport within Cells</li><li>Modeling in Virtual Cell: ODEs and PDEs</li><li>PDE Models of Live Cell Imaging Experiments: Predictions and Verification</li><li>Introduction to Stochastic Models for Cell Biological Processes</li><li>Stochastic Modeling of Biochemical Processes: Master Equation-Gillespie Algorithm</li><li>Stochastic Model of Neurotransmitter Release </li><li>Stochastic Model of Transcription Initiation</li></ul>", "description": "", "short_name": "dynamicalmodeling", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<span>\n<li><strong>Will I get a Statement of Accomplishment after completing this class?</strong><br>\n<p>Yes. {"about_the_course": "This course is about understanding the determinants of health from a broad perspective. We focus on how social relationships and institutions -- such as familial relationships, national policies, and global economic forces -- promote or undermine the health of populations. The course covers existing evidence of health disparities, research methods, and theories relevant to the topic.<br><br>The course is interesting because it reveals the so-called fundamental causes of disease and health disparities recognizable within social groups. For example, we examine why a flu germ can affect whole groups of people differently. In short, the course challenges the notion that health is a narrowly defined medical problem.<br><br>Students in the course will listen to lectures, read provided materials, and complete quizzes and tests that examine comprehension and one's ability to synthesize ideas.<br><br><span>Upon completion of the course students should:<br></span><ul><li>have a deep appreciation for how social arrangements impact the health of populations,</li><li>be able to critically evaluate the scientific and popular health literature that address the causes of disease,</li><li>be able to measure key social drivers such as race and socioeconomic status, and&nbsp;</li><li>be able to conceive of research strategies that can answer questions critical for policy making.</li></ul>", {"about_the_course": "<span><div>Join\n              internationally-acclaimed researcher and award-winning\n              educator Richard Alley in an exploration of the role of\n              energy in our environment and our future. Energy use has\n              done great good for humans by giving those in the\n              developed world the equivalent of 100 energy \"serfs\" to do\n              our bidding, making up roughly 10% of the economy, and\n              powering most of the economy.&nbsp; However, the unintended\n              consequences of energy use are affecting people around the\n              world and changing the climate in ways that will make life\n              much harder.&nbsp; Numerous options exist for development of a\n              sustainable energy system that provides a stronger\n              economy, more jobs, and greater security that is more\n              consistent with ethical principles.&nbsp; The course explores\n              these issues.<br>\n              &nbsp;<br>\n              \u201cEnergy, the Environment, and Our Future\u201d will combine\n              student-centered instructional materials and film clips\n              from the PBS TV series&nbsp;<a href=\"http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2RyvpsIx47E\" target=\"_blank\">Earth: The Operators' Manual</a>, also\n              hosted by Richard Alley, to tell the history, present, and\n              possible futures of human energy use.&nbsp; {"about_the_course": "Two of the most inspiring, least understood, and most often derided terms in global health discourse are \u201cHealth for All\u201d and \u201cPrimary Health Care.\u201d In this course, we will explore these terms in the context of global health, their origins and meanings, the principles upon which they rest, and examples of how these principles have been implemented both at small scale as well as at large scale. We will also explore some ultra-low-cost approaches to Health for All through primary health care and the promise that primary health care holds for eventually achieving Health for All.<br><br>The {"about_the_course": "This\n course serves as an introduction to linear and discrete \noptimization from the viewpoint of a mathematician or computer \nscientist.&nbsp; Besides learning how linear and discrete optimization can be applied, we focus on \nunderstanding methods that solve linear programs and discrete optimization problems in a mathematically \nrigorous way. <br><br>We will answer&nbsp; questions like:<br><br><ul><li>Does a particular method work correctly?</li><li>Does it terminate and, if yes, in what time?</li><li>Can we prove that a solution is optimal?</li></ul>The\n course starts by discussing what a linear program is and how linear programming can be \napplied. Then, we will treat the simplex method and the theory of \nduality. We will then discuss some combinatorial optimization problems like maximum weight bipartite matching and maximum flows.&nbsp;<br><br>The\n course constitutes about half of the material on linear and discrete optimization \nthat is taught for mathematics and computer science undergraduates at \nEPFL and will feature video lectures, quizzes, programming assignments, \nand a final exam. <br>", {"about_the_course": "Learn to become an effective builder of sentences using the basic tools\nof grammar, punctuation, and writing. By dedicating yourself to the craft\nof writing, you will learn to develop the four basic sentence types into\na well-organized, detailed paragraph. This course is designed for anyone\nwho wants to become a better writer. If you need to write more clearly\nfor work, prepare for a placement test for a college, or improve your skills\nfor current writing projects, this class will definitely be beneficial.\n<br>\n<br>\n<b><i>Objectives:\n</i></b>\n<br>\n<ul>\n    <li>Students will be able to identify and correct some sentence level grammatical\n        and punctuation errors.</li>\n    <li>Students will be able to develop four sentence types: simple, compound,\n        complex and compound-complex.</li>\n    <li>Students will be able to combine sentences using all four sentence types.</li>\n    <li>Students will be able to develop a clear topic sentence.</li>\n    <li>Students will be able to write a well-organized, detailed paragraph.</li>\n</ul><b><i>Why would you want to take this course?</i></b>&nbsp; There are\na variety of reasons:\n<br>\n<ul>\n    <li>As a pre-Assessment activity</li>\n    <li>As a petition for English placement</li>\n    <li>As a brush-up for students while in writing classes</li>\n    <li>As a brush-up for students who don\u2019t/can\u2019t enroll in an English class</li>\n    <li>As a resource for flipped/blended classrooms</li>\n    <li>To become a better writer!\n        <br>\n    </li>\n</ul>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/a1/556cc99b065bcf82c23ca7f40ab739/msjc.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/06/41cc053e58c65b59e03e3b67c1e30b/msjc.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/bd/c650a4feea8765e09f7045f205649b/msjc.jpg", "video": "S0jWw-t9pvs", "university-ids": ["msjc"], "id": 469, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "", "website_facebook": "msjc.edu", "id": 44, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "San Jacinto", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 33.7839084, "location": "San Jacinto, CA", "primary_color": "", "abbr_name": "MSJC", "website": "http://www.msjc.edu/", "description": "MSJC is a comprehensive community college dedicated to student success. {"about_the_course": "<span>Optimization technology is ubiquitous in our society. It schedules planes and their crews, coordinates the production of steel, and organizes the transportation of iron ore from the mines to the ports. Optimization clears the day-ahead and real-time markets to deliver electricity to millions of people. It organizes kidney exchanges and cancer treatments and helps scientists understand the fundamental fabric of life, control complex chemical reactions, and design drugs that may benefit billions of individuals.<br><br>This class is an introduction to discrete optimization and exposes students to some of the most fundamental concepts and algorithms in the field. It covers constraint programming, local search, and mixed-integer programming from their foundations to their applications for complex practical problems in areas such as scheduling, vehicle&nbsp;routing, supply-chain optimization, and resource allocation.&nbsp;</span>", "other_description": "", "photo": Prior to that, he was professor of computer science at Brown University where he joined that faculty in 1990. His main research interests are&nbsp;the design and implementation of optimization systems and their applications to complex problems. His current research projects focus on the use of optimization in disaster management, future energy systems, as well as in logistics and supply chains. He has written five books published by the MIT Press and built&nbsp;several optimization systems that are widely used in academia and industry. He received an NSF Young investigator award in 1993, the 2002 INFORMS Computer Society Award, two Honorary Doctorate Degrees from the University of Louvain and the University of Nantes, the Philip J. Bray Award for Teaching Excellence in the Physical Sciences at Brown University, and became a fellow of AAAI in 2009. He has given plenary talks at the main conferences in artificial intelligence and operations research.&nbsp;<br><br>Pascal has been teaching discrete optimization&nbsp;at Brown University, the University of Louvain, and now the University of Melbourne&nbsp;for almost 20 years.", "small_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/b5/a1f39fe0781c1105d5b0c6787577d1/discrete_optimization.jpg", "course-ids": [970239], "display": true, "recommended_background": "Good programming skills, knowledge of fundamental algorithms, and linear algebra."}
{"about_the_course": "This course is designed to provide knowledge of equine digestion and nutrition for those with an interest in this area. The anatomy and physiology of the equine alimentary canal will be studied to provide students with an understanding of the equine digestive system. &nbsp;Nutrient sources for horses will be discussed, with emphasis placed on the health and welfare issues surrounding the inclusion of various types of feedstuffs in equine diets. &nbsp;Students will also discuss recommendations on rations for horses and ponies performing various activities and should feel better equipped to make judgements on rations for horses and ponies, in health and disease.", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/equinenutrition/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/equinenutrition/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/equinenutrition/large-icon.png", "video": "ZzmSNNeRmIk", "university-ids": ["edinburgh"], "id": 110, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "UniofEdinburgh", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d3/bcdd33b2d979d2bea9467b17f9bbbb/favicon-edinburgh.ico", "website_facebook": "UniversityOfEdinburgh", "id": 14, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7f/781467d4f282293bb644ca68683509/UoE-Logo-200x48-Left-Centred-Text-Trans-v3.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Edinburgh", "location_country": "GB", "location_lat": 55.953252, "location": "Edinburgh, United Kingdom", "primary_color": "#002675", "abbr_name": "Edinburgh", "website": "http://www.ed.ac.uk/", "description": "Delivering excellence in teaching and learning. \n\nConsistently ranked as one of the world's top 50 universities and top 3 UK provider of online Masters courses. "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<b>Week 1: Anatomy and physiology of the equine gastrointestinal tract</b><br> The expectation is that the course participants will come from varied backgrounds in relation to their previous experience of gastrointestinal tract anatomy and physiology. &nbsp;Consequently, this course begins with consideration of digestive anatomy and physiology in equids. &nbsp;The learning materials provided are directed towards ensuring a good understanding of equine digestive anatomy and physiology. <br><br> <b>Week 2: Nutrient digestion in the equine gastrointestinal tract</b><br> The learning materials during this period will focus on nutrient digestion in equids and will consider nutrient digestion in the various segments of the gastrointesintal tract. &nbsp;Discussion should focus on considering the limitations of the equid gastrointestinal tract in relation to nutrient digestion. <br><br> <b>Week 3: Equine nutrient sources and feeding management</b><br> This part of the course will consider various nutrient sources for equids. Learning materials will be provided on various feedstuffs utilised in equine diets. &nbsp;These various nutrient sources for horses will be discussed, with emphasis placed on the health and welfare issues surrounding the inclusion of various types of feedstuffs in horse diets. Discussions should involve considering how nutrients are digested within the gastrointestinal tract and how knowledge of this can enhance the dietary management of equids to ensure good health, maximise performance and prevent nutrition-related diseases/disorders. <br><br> <b>Week 4: Equine dietary management</b><br> This week of the course will explore the nutrient requirements of equids and the dietary management of these animals. Discussions should focus around considering how modern feeding practices do not always consider the anatomy and physiology of the equid digestive tract. <br><br> <b>Week 5: Equine clinical nutrition</b><br> This part of the course will focus on evaluating feeding strategies for the management and prevention of some nutrition-related diseases/disorders in equids; for example, obesity, laminitis, older horses with dental issues etc. Discussions should focus on the dietary management of individuals affected with nutrition-related problems.", "description": "", "short_name": "equinenutrition", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<ul>\n<li><strong>Will I get a certificate after completing this class?</strong>\n<p>Yes. This course is not designed to have a large amount of tutor input as this is an open access course that attracts tens of thousands of participants.  However, tutors will endeavour to answer the main queries relating to the understanding of the lecture materials and to provide a summary of the key questions raised in each of the weekly topics and clarification of any misunderstandings. Studies at the University of Edinburgh, which involves directing the Veterinary School's on-line MSc/Dip/Cert programme in Equine Science and managing the School\u2019s e-learning activities. &nbsp;Dr Murray has a degree in equine science, a postgraduate diploma in animal nutrition and a PhD in equine nutrition. She is also a British Horse Society Intermediate Instructor, a registered nutritionist with the British Nutrition Society and a Fellow of the Higher Education Academy. &nbsp;Dr Murray\u2019s main research has been focussed on improving the nutritive value of fibre-based feedstuffs for horses and investigating the effect of high-starch and high-fructan diets on the large intestinal environment of the horse. &nbsp;More recently, Dr Murray has investigated the use of supplements in horse diets and the effect of these on horse behaviour.", "small_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/equinenutrition/small-icon.hover.png", "course-ids": [312, 970719], "display": true, "recommended_background": "No background is required in equine nutrition is required.&nbsp; <br>"}
{"about_the_course": "<p>Great leaders move us through our emotions. They establish a deep emotional\n    connection with others called resonance. Their own levels of emotional\n    intelligence allow them to create and nurture these resonant relationships.\n    They use their EI as a path to resonant leadership through mindfulness,\n    hope, compassion, and playfulness. Unfortunately, most people in leadership\n    and helping positions (i.e., doctors, teachers, coaches, etc.) lose their\n    effectiveness over time because of the cumulative damage from chronic stress.\n    But humans can renew themselves, neurologically, hormonally, and emotionally.</p>\n<p>Based on decades of&nbsp;research into emotional intelligence&nbsp;competencies\n    and longitudinal studies of their development, the course will examine\n    resonance and developing \"resonant leadership\" capability,&nbsp;emotional\n    intelligence, and the experiences of mindfulness, hope, and compassion.\n    Using the latest in neuroscience, behavioral, organizational and psychological\n    research, participants will&nbsp;understand the theory, research, and experience\n    of the Positive Emotional Attractor that is an essential beginning to sustained,\n    desired change for individuals, teams, organizations and communities.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>", "other_description": "", "target_audience": 1, "faq": "<p><strong>* Will I get a Statement of Accomplishment&nbsp;after completing this\nclass?</strong>\n\n</p>\n<p>Yes. Students who successfully complete the class will receive a Statement\n    of Accomplishment&nbsp;signed by the instructor. It will say \"with practicum\"\n    for those in the Practicum Track.</p>\n<p><strong>* What resources will I need for this course?</strong>\n\n</p>\n<p>For this course, all you need is an Internet connection, and the time\n    to read and discuss the exciting materials available on line.</p>\n<p><strong>* What is the coolest thing about this course?</strong>\n\n</p>\n<p>In this course, you will delve into the mysteries of the human experience\n    of leadership. You will learn how to overcome the ravages of chronic stress\n    to become more open to learning and change,&nbsp;renew your body and mind\n    (not to mention your heart and spirit). You will learn the theory, research\n    from management, psychology, education and medicine that facilitate sustained,\n    desired change.</p>\n<p><b>* Will I be able to apply the\nlearning?</b>&nbsp;</p>\n<p><span>Yes, each module and class will include reflective exercises and action\nlearning assignments to help you understand <i>and</i>\nexperiment with the ideas at work and at home in your life. You will learn\ntechniques for renewal, inspiring hope and vision, engaging mindfulness,\nspreading compassion and being playful \u2013 building your emotional intelligence\nand improving your relationships!</span>\n\n</p>\n<p><span>* <b>Will I be able to design possible research studies to build on the\nlatest research?</b></span>\n\n</p>\n<p>Yes, the causal relationships developed through current and most recent\n    research will be explained. These will enable you to identify possible\n    research designs for your own future research.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>", "category-ids": ["business", "education", "socsci"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "Emotional intelligence, hope, mindfulness, and compassion help a person reverse the damage of chronic stress and build great leadership relationships. The Positive and Negative Emotional Attractors inspire sustained, desired change and learning at many levels. ", "course_format": "<p>This course is made up of nine classes. Each class has two to four modules\n    (except Class 6). Each module has a video, personal learning assignments\n    within each video or for each module, discussion forums, writing in your\n    Personal Journal, You Tube videos to watch, readings, quizzes and exams.\n    Students are encouraged to maintain a personal journal of thoughts, observations\n    and experiences during the course. There are two tracks in the course.\n    Satisfactory completion of the CORE Track includes the video lectures,\n    readings, You Tube videos, DIscussion Forums, Personal Journal, and Personal\n    Learning Assingments. Satisfactory completion fo the Practicum Track includes\n    the Core Track plus three action learning assignments that involve talking\n    to others and writing about it. At least one of these will be read and\n    reviewed by a small group of classmates on-line. Students are expected\n    to offer their opinions, ideas and examples from the videos, readings,\n    personal and action learning assignments in on line discussions. Each module\n    will end with a quiz. Appropriate performance on the quizzes, exams, entries\n    on the Discussion Forums and for the Practicum Track assessment of the\n    essays will constitute the successful completion of the course and respective\n    Track. The on-line discussions will be monitored by course staff.&nbsp;</p>\n<p></p>\n<p></p>", "has_full_data": true, "social_link": null, "suggested_readings": "<p>Students should read the required readings either before or soon after\n    each unit, but in advance of the next module. {"about_the_course": "<p>This course explores the basic concepts and terms needed to understand\n    the science of climate change, and the available mitigation, adaptation\n    and policy options. By the end of the course, students will be able to:</p>\n<p>\u00b7&nbsp; Tell the story of our climate, describing how interactions among\n    atmosphere, ocean, land, and life lead to climatic changes at all timescales</p>\n<p>\u00b7&nbsp; Evaluate the likely effect of historical human fossil emissions\n    and land use changes on Earth\u2019s energy balance and climate.</p>\n<p>\u00b7&nbsp; Describe the direct observations of climate change in the second\n    half of the 20th century, and articulate the evidence attributing global\n    warming in this time period to human causes.</p>\n<p>\u00b7&nbsp; Assess the utility - and limits - of climate models to predict\n    global and regional climate change.</p>\n<p>\u00b7&nbsp; Articulate the demographic, economic, technological and political\n    factors that influence both humans\u2019 impact on the climate and humans\u2019 vulnerability\n    to climate change.</p>\n<p>\u00b7&nbsp; Express an informed opinion on the scope and urgency of the efforts\n    needed to both mitigate and adapt to climate change.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;We provide the scientific basics of climate change paired with the\n    response options (mitigation and adaptation) and policy landscape. Focusing\n    exclusively on the science of climate change may not allow a nuanced understanding\n    of the social implications of this science.&nbsp; Similarly, political\n    or economic analyses of climate change frequently neglect the underlying\n    mechanics behind climate change thresholds, feedbacks, and the potential\n    for abrupt change. This course explores linkages between climate change\n    and other pressing priorities such as human health, poverty, community\n    livability, economic resilience, and other environmental problems (such\n    as biodiversity and water quality).&nbsp; We acknowledge the urgent need\n    to design innovative strategies that realize multiple objectives (or co-benefits)\n    simultaneously, and explore the particular capacity for sustainability\n    and climate change to provide an avenue for achieving these objectives.&nbsp;</p>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/34/3695b2ea7c68d91a1372216c456582/Sustainability-s-Earth01.jpg", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/52/79f2b266c299e1a83fa5adfc366192/Sustainability-s-Earth01.jpg", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/e3/7f5ab4618e5c245533c79c8454a2b5/Sustainability-s-Earth01.jpg", "video": "zB6jr34HzZY", "university-ids": ["ubc"], "id": 226, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d1/159770b1b64f0bb3736e0a1ad5144b/favicon.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 29, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d1/4b45f1fa68329d09b869d990e5d48e/panel_signature3.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "", "location_country": "", "location_lat": null, "location": "", "primary_color": "#0f2144", "abbr_name": "UBC", "website": "", "description": "", "short_name": "ubc", "location_state": "", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/dd/396bbc8612e8d7bd419bdffa4c9f36/ubc4.jpg", "landing_page_banner": null, "name": "The University of British Columbia", "square_logo": null, "square_logo_source": null, "display": true, "location_lng": null, "home_link": null, "class_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/bf/ec7f82fa9a5710bd93265b426dcebd/s1b282.png", "square_logo_svg": null}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<p>Climate Literacy is delivered in ten Modules.&nbsp; The first half of\n    the course deals mainly with climate change science and models, while the\n    second half of the course speaks to climate change impacts, response options,\n    and polices.&nbsp; The Modules are as follows:&nbsp;</p>\n<p><b>1.\n</b><b>&nbsp;Climate in the public sphere</b>\n</p>\n<p>Climate change is a pervasive and challenging phenomenon that can be viewed\n    through a multitude of lenses. A scientific lens, for instance, reveals\n    altered ecosystems and climatic tipping points while the lens of ethics\n    raises the question of the right to develop and influence the well-being\n    of others while doing so. This module will introduce you to a few of the\n    core concepts that you will need to delve deeper into the science and policy\n    of climate change. We will explore the broad findings offered by the scientific\n    community with regard to our influence on the climate system, the policy\n    tools that we have developed to respond to this challenge, and the core\n    of the climate change debate in scientific, political, and lay communities.</p>\n<p><b>2.\n</b><b>&nbsp;Introduction to the climate system</b>\n</p>\n<p>In Module 2 we\u2019re looking at the big picture, and asking: \u201cWhat\u2019s the\n    climate system made of, and how has it evolved over time?\u201d We\u2019ll paint\n    a broad sketch of how climate works by describing what we see around us\n    now and by using climate records to tell a stripped down version of the\n    last 500 million years of climate history. Drawing from your daily experience,\n    we\u2019ll also discuss and illustrate the properties of dynamic systems, and\n    see how the concept of system dynamics can help us understand how climate\n    change happens.</p>\n<p><b>3.\n</b><b>&nbsp;The\nenergy budget of the earth</b>\n</p>\n<p>This module covers the basics of climatology at the planetary scale. We\n    won\u2019t look at how regional climates are created, or how energy is distributed\n    and flows between various regions of the Earth, but rather consider the\n    planet as a whole. We will trace the path of energy coming in from the\n    Sun and leaving the planet as thermal radiation (or infrared), and explore\n    the various factors affecting these flows: greenhouse gases, aerosols,\n    ground cover albedo, and clouds. We will investigate how humans have impacted\n    these climatic controls since the Industrial Revolution, and compare these\n    anthropogenic forcings to natural forcings such as variation in solar irradiance\n    and volcanic eruptions.</p>\n<p><b>4.\n</b><b>The carbon cycle</b>\n</p>\n<p>Our planet breathes; its biosphere on land and in the oceans inhales and\n    exhales oxygen and carbon dioxide every second. Even water and rocks exchange\n    carbon dioxide with the atmosphere. Humans, particularly through deforestation\n    and fossil fuel use, are only a small part of this planetary carbon cycle,\n    but one that has had significant impact. This module explores the natural\n    carbon cycle, and the impact humans have had on it since the Industrial\n    Revolution.</p>\n<p><b>5.\n</b><b>&nbsp;Climate models</b>\n</p>\n<p>The epistemology and method of climate science (and of earth sciences\n    in general) is somewhat different than that of other sciences. Most research\n    in physics, chemistry and biology (to name only a few) happens in a laboratory.\n    There, the scientist can test her understanding of the phenomena she studies\n    by doing repeated experiments, changing a few key parameters and seeing\n    how they impact the results. Climate scientists obviously cannot learn\n    what the impact of various GHG emission scenarios might be by \u201ctrying it\n    out\u201d, or cannot see what would happen if you were to change circulation\n    patterns or increase the number of clouds. There is no laboratory large\n    enough fit the Earth, no lever long enough to change its conditions at\n    will, and no observer patient enough to look on as the experiment unfolds.\n    Or at least, we can\u2019t do it more than once!</p>\n<p>Climatologists depend on computer models to do these experiments. Of course\n    these models don\u2019t appear out of thin air \u2013 they are built on our understanding\n    of basic physics and Earth processes, which is built on field observations\n    and lab experiments. These models are calibrated and tested using data\n    from direct measurements or based on reconstructions of past climates.</p>\n<p>This module introduces climate models: how they work, how they are tested,\n    what their limits are, and how they can be used to forecast possible futures.</p>\n<p><b>6.\n</b><b>&nbsp;The\nclimate forecast</b>\n</p>\n<p>Now that we have a clearer sense of the history, principles, components\n    and assumptions of climate models, we\u2019ll look more closely at their results.\n    In the first lesson we review global projections made by the IPCC for the\n    coming century, based on the various SRES scenarios: What range of temperature\n    increases can we expect? How will that affect the climatic factors that\n    are most relevant to humans and ecosystems: precipitation, circulation\n    patterns, extreme events, melting of snow and ice, etc? These global projections\n    give us the main line of what we can expect if we embark on various emission\n    and development paths, and offer a broad view for decision-making. However,\n    for local planners and decision-makers, these results are not directly\n    relevant: the spatial scales are too large, and important local details\n    that will control the impact on a local scale are not resolved. In the\n    second lecture we address this issue and explore the tools available to\n    downscale global projections to a local scale, and discuss how these tools\n    can be used by local decision-makers in government and industry for long-term\n    strategic planning.</p>\n<p><b>7.\n</b><b>&nbsp;Climate change impacts</b>\n</p>\n<p>As we have seen, the emission of vast quantities of greenhouse gases by\n    humans fundamentally influences the global climatic system. The chain reaction\n    does not end here, however. Rising temperatures and sea levels, changing\n    precipitation patterns, and ocean acidification, for instance, trigger\n    dramatic shifts in the way that human and natural systems function.</p>\n<p>This module forms the transition between the science of climate change,\n    which we have explored in Modules 2-6, and the more human-oriented Modules\n    7-10.</p>\n<p><b>8.\n</b><b>&nbsp;Climate change mitigation: dealing with the\ncauses</b>\n</p><b>\n\n</b>\n<p>Now that we understand the central causes of anthropogenic climate change,\n    and the impacts that we can expect to (and already) experience, the next\n    step is to explore the response options that are available to us. The most\n    commonly-discussed response to climate change is mitigation: tackling the\n    causes of climate change by reducing the concentration of greenhouse gases\n    in the atmosphere. The aim of mitigation is to reduce the severity and\n    frequency of climate change impacts, thereby protecting ecosystems and\n    human societies.</p>\n<p>This module will explore the basic concept of mitigation, the core mitigation\n    strategies that we currently have available to us, the innovative action\n    that is being taken around the world, and leading-edge ideas with regard\n    to tackling the roots of climate change. By the end of this module, you\n    will be able to critique the likelihood of implementation of many of these\n    strategies, and will have a framework through which you can learn more\n    about greenhouse gas management, both at home and around the world.</p>\n<p><b>9.\n</b><b>&nbsp;Climate change adaptation: dealing with the\neffects</b>\n</p>\n<p>In contrast to the previous module, this module introduces the idea of\n    addressing the impacts of climate change rather than its causes. In particular,\n    we will explore the various adaptation strategies that are available to\n    be utilized around the world, the heated debate surrounding the equity\n    implications of adaptation, and the linkages between adaptation and mitigation.\n    By the end of this module we will have explored the difference between\n    proactive and reactive adaptation, and our track record with both. We will\n    outline the most common and effective adaptation strategies, including\n    those related to human settlements, ecosystems, and the broader issue of\n    development. Finally, we will explore the inevitable trade-offs between\n    adaptation and mitigation, setting us up to finish this course with a survey\n    of climate change response policies.</p>\n<p><b>10.\n</b><b>&nbsp;Policy\ntools for mitigation and adaptation</b>\n</p>\n<p>This Module forms a bridge between this first course in the Decision-making\n    for Climate Change series, and the three courses that will follow. Given\n    what we know now about the science behind climate change, and the strategies\n    that we have at our disposal for responding to it, we can now be introduced\n    to policies that bear this in mind. After being introduced to the fundamentals\n    of mitigation and adaptation policy, we will use the British Columbia carbon\n    tax and the proposed cap-and-trade system in the United States as relevant\n    examples. Finally, we will finish with a glimpse forward to the future\n    of climate change policy, and the most promising opportunities for both\n    managing impacts and ensuring a rapid transition to a fundamentally low-carbon\n    development path.</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "climateliteracy", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "", "category-ids": ["energy"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "Climate Literacy tackles the scientific and socio-political dimensions of climate change. This course introduces the basics of the climate system, models and predictions, human and natural impacts, mitigative and adaptive responses, and the evolution of climate policy.", "course_format": "about_the_instructor": "<p><b><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/0c/dabae0f3fa21d6590d11a1c9dd9f22/sarahburch.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"><br>Dr. Sarah Burch</b></p>\n\n<p>Sarah Burch is\na Banting Postdoctoral Research Fellow at the University of British Columbia\u2019s\nCentre for Interactive Research on Sustainability.\u00a0 Her research focuses on urban climate change governance, with an emphasis on\npractical, integrated approaches to sustainability. Sarah currently explores\nthe dynamics of potentially transformative community-level innovation in\nresponse to climate change, and the drivers of emerging partnerships between\nthe private and public sectors.\u00a0 This\naction-oriented and interdisciplinary research supports communities as they\ntransition towards sustainability and fills a critical gap in our understanding\nof transformative development path shifts.\u00a0\nSarah writes and teaches about holistic and equitable strategies for\nbuilding resilient, low-carbon communities. </p>\n\nSarah holds a PhD in\nResource Management and Environmental Studies from the University of British\nColumbia, Canada, and was a postdoctoral fellow at the Environmental Change\nInstitute, University of Oxford. She was a Contributing Author to the Fourth\nAssessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, in both Working Group II\n(Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability) and Working Group III (Mitigation of\nClimate Change).\u00a0<br><br><br><br><b>Sara Harris</b><img src=\"https://coursera-topic-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/f0/dbabb573e35ff67bce75c439ab43f6/SaraHarris_cropped_sm.jpg\" class=\"coursera-instructor-thumb\"><br><br>Sara Harris is a faculty member in Earth, Ocean & Atmospheric Sciences at the University of British Columbia where she teaches global climate change, environmental science, oceanography, and a bit of geology.\u00a0 Her research background is in paleoceanography and paleoclimatology, reconstructing past variations in ocean circulation and continental climates at orbital to tectonic time scales.\u00a0 During seven years as a chief scientist at Sea Education Association in Woods Hole, Massachusetts, she studied modern oceans and sailed thousands of miles with undergraduate students.\u00a0 Sara's current research explores how people learn climate science, what mental models of Earth's climate people bring with them to each learning experience, and which learning opportunities best help people move toward more expert-like ideas about how Earth's climate works.\u00a0\u00a0 \u00a0 <br><br>Sara holds a PhD in oceanography from Oregon State University.\u00a0 She sailed with the Ocean Drilling Program as both a sedimentologist and stratigrapher.\u00a0 She has been actively involved with the Carl Wieman Science Education Initiative to incorporate evidence-based pedagogy into university courses. \u00a0 <br><br>", "small_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/52/79f2b266c299e1a83fa5adfc366192/Sustainability-s-Earth01.jpg", "course-ids": [970253], "display": true, "recommended_background": ""}
{"about_the_course": "The goal of this course is to introduce you to the basics of how computation\nhas impacted the entire workflow of photography (i.e., from how images\nare captured, manipulated and collaborated on, and shared). &nbsp;\n<br>\n<br>The course begins with a conceptualization of&nbsp;photography as drawing\nwith light and the capturing of light to form images/videos. &nbsp;You\nwill learn about and understand how the optics and the sensor within a\ncamera are generalized, as well as learn about and understand how the lighting\nand other aspects of the environment are also generalized through computation\nto capture novel images.&nbsp;\n<br>\n<br>Pre- and post-processing techniques used to manipulate and improve images\nwill be discussed. &nbsp;Activities in this course are selected to give\nyou first hand experience with the power of the web and the Internet for\nboth analyzing and sharing images. &nbsp;\n<br>\n<br>This course is interdisciplinary and draws upon concepts and principles\nfrom computer vision, computer graphics, image processing, mathematics\nand optics.\n<br>\n<br>We look forward to your engagement and participation with both the course\nand its discussion forums.\n<br>\n<br>\n<b>About the TA</b>\n<br>Denis Lantsman is the TA for the class. Denis is a graduate of Harvey\nMudd College, and is currently finishing his MS in Machine Learning at\nGeorgia Tech. He is responsible for managing the coursera site, monitoring\nthe forums for student feedback, creating the homework assignments and\nquizzes, as well as recording weekly tutorials to help students "<p>Week 0 (Module 0): &nbsp;Introductions with an overview of the course\n    structure and content.&nbsp; Topics covered in this module include a description\n    of what is Computational Photography (i.e., whereby examples of dual photography\n    and panoramas are described) and reasons for studying this emerging interdisciplinary\n    field .</p>\n<p>Week 1 (Module 1): &nbsp;Overview of what is a digital image.&nbsp; Topics\n    covered in this module are image processing and filtering, with emphases\n    placed upon point processes, smoothing, convolution, cross-correlation,\n    gradients and edges.</p>\n<p>Week 2 (Module 2): &nbsp;Overview of cameras with emphases placed upon\n    the pinhole camera and optics (e. g., lenses, focal length), exposure time\n    and sensors.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Week 3 (Module 3): &nbsp;Feature detection, matching and correspondence.\n    The panorama pipeline and some examples. HDR and tone mapping.</p>\n<p>Week 4 (Module 4):&nbsp;Overview of light fields, texture synthesis, image\n    retargeting, video, advanced topics.</p>", "description": "", "short_name": "compphoto", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<ul>\n    <li><strong>Will I get a statement of accomplishment after completing this class?</strong>\n\n    </li>Statement of accomplishment will be provided by <a href=\"http://c21u.gatech.edu/\"> Georgia Tech C21U </a>.</ul>\n<p></p>\n<ul>\n    <li><strong>What resources will I need for this class?</strong>\n\n    </li>You will need access to a camera and access to a computer with internet,\n    and time.\n    <br>\n</ul>\n<p></p>\n<ul>\n    <li><b>How much math do I need to know?</b>\n\n    </li>College-level Mathematics (e.g., Linear Algebra, Calculus) is useful for\n    this course. &nbsp;You should know what are Matrices, Vectors, Differentiation,\n    and Integration. &nbsp;A working knowledge of Basic Probability (e.g.,\n    Probability Density Function) is needed. &nbsp;\n    <br>\n</ul>\n<p></p>\n<ul>\n    <li><b>How much programming do I need to know?</b>\n\n    </li>We will use <a href=\"http://www.python.org/\">Python </a> with <a href=\"http://opencv.org/\"> OpenCV</a>&nbsp;to\n    do the programming assignments. Irfan Essa works in the areas of Computer Vision, Computer Graphics, Computational Perception, Robotics and Computer Animation, Machine Learning, and Social Computing, with potential impact on Video Analysis and Production (e.g., Computational Photography & Video, Image-based Modeling and Rendering, etc.) Human Computer Interaction, and Artificial Intelligence research. His specific research interests are in Video Analysis & Synthesis, and Activity & Behavior Recognition. He also works in the new area of Computational Journalism. Specifically, he is interested in the analysis, interpretation, authoring, and synthesis (of video), with the goals of building aware environments & supporting healthy living, recognizing & modeling human behaviors, empowering humans to effectively interact with each other, with media & with technologies, and developing dynamic & generative representations of time-varying streams. <br><br>He has published over 150 scholarly articles in leading journals and conference venues on these topics. He has been awarded the NSF CAREER Award and within GA Tech, and he has won the College of Computing\u2019s Junior and Senior Research Faculty Awards, Outstanding Teacher Award, Outstanding Mentor Award, Institute\u2019s Educational Innovation Award, and the Dean\u2019s Award. He is also a recipient of the GVU Center\u2019s 15 years of Impact Award. He was elected to the grade of IEEE Fellow in 2011. He joined GA Tech Faculty in 1996 after his earning his MS (1990), Ph.D. (1994), and holding research faculty position at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Media Lab) [1988-1996]. {"about_the_course": "<div>Most programs are used for years and are worked on by many people. Having programs that are easy to understand is essential, in the same way that a well-organized essay is far easier to follow than a disorganized one. We\u2019ll show you an approach that helps to break down problems into smaller tasks that are easier to both solve and read.</div>\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\n<div>This design approach also makes it more straightforward to find and fix flaws. You'll be introduced to the tools that professional programmers use; they're called \"testing\" and \"debugging\".</div>\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\n<div>For most complex problems, there are many programs that solve them. Some are inherently slower than others. You'll learn how to read two programs and compare them for efficiency.</div>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/programming2/large-icon.png", "preview_link": {"about_the_course": "First-Year Composition 2.0 will help you to develop a better process and\ngain confidence in written, visual, and oral communication and to create\nand critique documents and presentations in college, in the workplace,\nand in your community. You will draft and revise the following assignments:\na personal essay, an image, and an oral presentation.\n<br>\n<br>You will develop confidence in the following areas:\n<br>\n<ul>\n    <li>Critical Thinking: Evaluate the effectiveness of personal essays, images,\n        and oral presentations. Assess your work and the work of your peers. Reflect\n        on your own processes and performance.\n        <br>\n    </li>\n    <li>Rhetoric: Analyze the ways in which you and other communicators use persuasion.\n        Think about and use context, audience, purpose, argument, genre, organization,\n        design, visuals, and conventions.\n        <br>\n    </li>\n    <li>Process: Apply processes (read, invent, plan, draft, design, rehearse,\n        revise, publish, present, and critique).\n        <br>\n    </li>\n    <li>Digital Media: Produce written, oral, and visual artifacts.\n        <br>\n    </li>\n</ul>", "description": "", "short_name": "gtcomp", "target_audience": 0, "faq": "<b>What kind of time will I need to take this course?</b>\nYou should plan 5-7 hours per week, but not in one block. We recommend\nthat you plan 30-to-60-minute blocks, so that you have time to reflect\nbetween sessions when you\u2019re working on a text, visual, or oral presentation.\n<br>\n<br><b>What are the most useful things I'll learn if I take this class?</b>\nYou\u2019ll develop a stronger sense of process (how to approach and complete\ntasks), leading to increased confidence in completing and assessing written,\nvisual, and oral communication projects.\n<br>\n<br><b>What resources will I need for this class?</b>\nBeyond a positive attitude,\ntime to do the readings and assignments, and a willingness to work, you\nwill need regular access to a computer, a connection to the Internet, and\nbasic software for doing written, visual, and oral activities. While you\ncan use commercial software if you already own it, all of the software\nyou need is free and available online (a list of some software resources\nis on the syllabus). You do not need to buy a textbook; instead, you will\nbe referred to free, online texts\u2014Writing Commons and the PurdueOWL.\n<br>\n<br><b>Will I receive transferable college course credit?</b>\nThis course is\nintended to introduce you to principles and practices of first-year composition.\nIt is not intended as a substitute for a for-credit composition course\nat any college or university. Even though this course is not intended to\nbe given college credit, it can demonstrate that you have learned a great\ndeal. To keep a record of your accomplishments in this course, you should\ncreate a portfolio of your written, visual, and oral assignments. At some\ncolleges and universities, your portfolio may form a portion of a case\nyou might make for potential transfer credit. Every college has its own\npolicy for acceptance of transfer or examination credit.\n<br>\n<br><b>Will I get feedback on my written work?</b> Yes. You will receive peer\nassessments of your work. In addition, Professor Head and her teaching\nteam will model effective feedback practices so class members can respond\nproductively to one another. Most important for developing competence and\nconfidence, you will learn how to assess your own work. We will also hold\nweekly virtual discussions and use selected projects for examples (anonymously\nand with your permission).\n<br>\n<br><b>Will this course provide instruction on grammar?</b> No. Mechanics (for\nexample, punctuation, capitalization, spelling) and grammar are important,\nso you\u2019ll be given references to check mechanics and grammar. However,\nthis course focuses on creating effective writing, visuals, and oral presentations.\n<br>\n<br><b>Is the course appropriate if a student is not very proficient in the English language?</b> This\ncourse is about composing in English, so all course work must be completed\nin English. You will need English fluency to be successful in the course.\nBecause we welcome cultural and linguistic diversity, part of our discussions\nwill focus on the ways different people use language and the different\nexpectations people bring to communication.", "category-ids": ["humanities"], "visibility": 0, "short_description": "First-Year Composition 2.0 will help you to develop a better process and gain confidence in written, visual, and oral communication and to create and critique college-level documents and presentations.", "course_format": "This class consists of two short introductory videos (a welcome video and a technology video), 24 ten-minute videos (three videos per week), plus approximately eight 20-to-30-minute streaming discussion sessions. {"about_the_course": "<p>This course\nis about the behavior of companies in\ncompetitive markets. Facing competition forces firms to look ahead and\nanticipate developments: If my rivals are likely\nto react to a price cut, I will have to take the expected reaction into account.\nWe focus on such instances of \u201cstrategic\ninterdependencies\u201d in real business situations.\nWe will first study the basic concepts of game theory as a toolbox with which we will\nthen analyze strategic \u201cgames\u201d in real-life settings. Rather than a set\nof checklists of \u201chow-to-behave\u201d in a number of\nprespecified situations, this course will teach you to think about business\nstrategy in a systematic and exciting - and\nultimately more successful - way!</p>\n\nWe will use our toolbox to\naddress and analyze different decisions firms take: Why do firms preannounce\ntheir products? How do price wars happen and when do they end? When should I\nenter a market in which firms currently make high profits? What makes strategic\npartnerships work? These are just some examples of the questions we will\ndiscuss during the course, but by the end of the course you should be able to\napply the concepts to pretty much any business situation.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<br>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/c9/aaaec0f37fe9fa9f4cad54550fd8d2/tic_tac_toe_iStock_Natasha-Japp-Photography_webl.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/41/569c7574095ce7f5ec3b012380709f/tic_tac_toe_iStock_Natasha-Japp-Photography_webl.png", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/ac/57b21e8a5cc489a45ebfc4200aaf1e/tic_tac_toe_iStock_Natasha-Japp-Photography_webl.png", "video": "4nx2z0yX4so", "university-ids": ["lmu"], "id": 459, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/0e/9145506f8bafba7c4c29fdde573a60/Unbenannt-4.png", "website_facebook": "", "id": 64, "logo": "", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "M\u00fcnchen", "location_country": "DE", "location_lat": 48.1366069, "location": "Munich, Germany", "primary_color": "#006633", "abbr_name": "LMU Munich", "website": "http://www.en.lmu.de/", "description": "As one of Europe's leading research universities, LMU Munich is committed to the highest international standards of excellence in research and teaching. {"about_the_course": "Statistics is a thriving discipline that provides the fundamental language\nof all empirical research. Biostatistics is simply the field of statistics\napplied in the biomedical sciences.\n<br>\n<br>This course puts forward key mathematical and statistical topics to help\nstudents understand biostatistics at a deeper level. After completing this\ncourse, students will have a basic level of understanding of the goals,\nassumptions, benefits and negatives of probability modeling in the medical\nsciences. His particular research interests\nare in phylogenetic perspectives linking brain mechanisms of fear and anxiety\nin animals and processing of emotional face expression in humans; methodological\nand conceptual issues in biological explanations of human psychopathology; health\npsychology, especially psychological and physiological factors in coping with\nchronic stressors such as long-term illness; and the biological and\nenvironmental contributions to gender differences in cognition and affect.</p>", "small_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/8b/337444f603516aa5f5310afc17fdae/V-multicoloured-brain.jpg", "course-ids": [970265, 970792], "display": true, "recommended_background": "<p>This is an open access course that assumes\nno previous knowledge of psychology.&nbsp;</p>"}
{"about_the_course": "<div>This course trains scientists to become more effective, efficient, and confident writers. This is a hands-on course that emphasizes interactive examples and practice. In the first four weeks, we will review principles of effective writing, examples of good and bad writing, and tips for making the writing process easier. In the second four weeks, we will examine issues specific to scientific writing, including: authorship, peer review, the format of an original manuscript, and communicating science for lay audiences. Students will complete editing exercises, write two short papers, and edit each others\u2019 work.&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>The primary audience is undergraduate science majors, graduate students in scientific disciplines, and professional scientists. Students from non-science disciplines can also benefit from the training provided in the first four weeks (on general principles of effective writing).</div>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/sciwrite/large-icon.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/sciwrite/small-icon.hover.png", "large_icon": "https://s3.amazonaws.com/coursera/topics/sciwrite/large-icon.png", "video": "4xdond91JfU", "university-ids": ["stanford"], "id": 157, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": null, "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/dc/581cda352d067023dcdcc0d9efd36e/favicon-stanford.ico", "website_facebook": "", "id": 1, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/d8/4c69670e0826e42c6cd80b4a02b9a2/stanford.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Palo Alto", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 37.4418834, "location": "Palo Alto, CA, United States", "primary_color": "#8c1515", "abbr_name": "Stanford", "website": "", "description": "The Leland Stanford Junior University, commonly referred to as Stanford University or Stanford, is an American private research university located in Stanford, California on an 8,180-acre (3,310 ha) campus near Palo Alto, California, United States.", "short_name": "stanford", "location_state": "CA", "website_youtube": "", "banner": "", "landing_page_banner": "", "name": "Stanford University", "square_logo": "", "square_logo_source": null, "display": true, "location_lng": -122.14301949999998, "home_link": "http://online.stanford.edu/", "class_logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/21/9a0294e2bf773901afbfcb5ef47d97/Stanford_Coursera-200x48_RedText_BG.png", "square_logo_svg": null}], "self_service_course_id": null, "university_logo": "", "course_syllabus": "<b>Week 1 (September 24-30): Introduction; {"about_the_course": "<p>A pesar de que una gran parte de la literatura sobre emprendimiento prepara\n    al \u201ccandidato emprendedor\u201d a c\u00f3mo hacer planes de negocio para conseguir\n    financiamiento proveniente de supuestos inversionistas, tal y como lo hace\n    la tradici\u00f3n norteamericana de ense\u00f1anza del emprendimiento, la realidad\n    de negocios nos dice que inclusive en los pa\u00edses desarrollados los proyectos\n    emprendedores inician con sus recursos financieros propios y normalmente\n    muy escasos.</p>La principal herramienta para estos emprendimientos no\nes el plan de negocios ni el financiamiento, sino la creatividad empresarial.&nbsp;\nPor lo que, para una ense\u00f1anza efectiva del proceso emprendedor, hay que\npartir de esta realidad y no solo imitar lo que sucede en universidades,\nprincipalmente norteamericanas, con un contexto muy diferente al resto\ndel mundo. Por otro lado, pareciera un misterio el por qu\u00e9 solo muy pocos\nproyectos de empresa o de negocio tienen \u00e9xito, pareciera una combinaci\u00f3n\nentre el \u201cculto\u201d a la personalidad {"about_the_course": "<p>This course analyzes the\nhistorical origins of citizenship and immigration in the United States and provides\nan overview of modern U.S. law.&nbsp; Beyond\ntraditional notions of \u201claw,\u201d the course also includes significant elements of\nimmigration policy, social science, history, political theory, and ethics. &nbsp;One goal of the course is to provide a basic\nknowledge base for students to make and influence law and policy in immigration\nand citizenship.</p>\n\n<p>Among the questions the\ncourse will explore:</p>\n\n<ul><li>How is U.S. citizenship\nacquired?&nbsp; Can it be lost?</li><li>What is the\norigin and significance of the U.S. practice of awarding citizenship to anyone\nborn here?</li><li>Who decides who\ncan enter the country, and who must leave?</li><li>What rights do\nnon-citizens have?&nbsp; What about those who\nhave entered the country illegally?</li><li>What is most needed\nfor immigration reform in the US?</li></ul>", "other_description": "", "photo": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/68/47e18d4af22dc8c40d73d197464cb1/immigration-nologo-2.png", "preview_link": null, "small_icon_hover": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/0b/5c05a126bf361e9e01b526e334bd06/immigration-nologo-2.png", "large_icon": "https://coursera-course-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/f7/f0a44adaf0265611da7ed6816d32b5/immigration-nologo-2.png", "video": "snIHU3CPu5o", "university-ids": ["emory"], "id": 201, "universities": [{"rectangular_logo_svg": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/89/d4f18b4cab9d87ed66c4355d907121/emory_horizontal_coursera.svg", "wordmark": null, "website_twitter": "EmoryUniversity", "favicon": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/a2/835a1009fc4245f378dd8add26dabc/Shield_280.jpg", "website_facebook": "EmoryUniversity", "id": 23, "logo": "https://coursera-university-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/7e/1f0e877a7a22c338bdfb128a4726f9/EU_hz_280.png", "background_color": "", "mailing_list_id": null, "location_city": "Atlanta", "location_country": "US", "location_lat": 33.7489954, "location": "Atlanta, GA, United States", "primary_color": "#002878", "abbr_name": "Emory", "website": "http://www.emory.edu/", "description": "Emory University, located in Atlanta, Georgia, is one of the world's leading research universities.
